PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating Government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament; the humble petition of the undersigned showeth:
That Kingsford-Smith Airport is becoming increasingly congested and existing facilities are inadequate to handle the number of aircraft or their passengers.

The Federal Government's plans to divert aircraft from Mascot to Bankstown and/or increase landing charges for peak periods will do little to relieve congestion and will place enormous financial and other burdens on commuter airlines and their passengers.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to take heed of airline and travel industry warnings and-
1. give immediate approval for the construction of a third runway at Mascot
2. upgrade existing radar and other traffic control facilities to enable Australia's high safety record to be maintained.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That X-rated videos harm the community, especially women and children, as outlined in evidence given to the Joint Select Committee on Video Material.
Your petitioners request that the Senate should:
Pass a bill to prohibit the registration of X-rated videos by the Commonwealth Censor. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill amends 14 Acts and one Ordinance within the portfolio as set out below. The amendments to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act 1955 and the Supreme Court Ordinance 1955 of that Territory will restore criminal trial by jury in the courts of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. The Bill provides for a court to move the venue of a criminal trial on indictment from Cocos (Keeling) Islands to another State or Territory, when necessary, and for jurors to be summoned at the new venue using the State jury list. The Bill also amends references to Chief Judge in the Norfolk Island Act 1979 by substituting Chief Justice.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments to the Australian Film, Television and Radio School Act 1975 will reduce the size of the Council from 15 to 9. This will ensure more effective governance by the Council and will reduce the cost of council meetings through reduced sitting fees and travel expenses.

The Bill provides for the Australian Film Commission, the National Museum of Australia and the Australian Heritage Commission to conduct their meetings by telephone, closed circuit television or other methods of communication. The requirement to have members physically attend is no longer mandatory.

Amendments to the investment powers of the Australia Council, Australian Film Commission, Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, Australian National Gallery and National Museum of Australia will free investments from the existing general requirement for these statutory authorities to seek ministerial approval for all financial dealings above a statutory limit. The range of available investments will, however, remain restricted to those specified in the respective enabling legislation.

The amendments relating to the Sea Installations Act 1987 seek to improve administrative efficiency and to specifically provide that a representative of the Norfolk Island Government will be included in discussions concerning the granting of permissions and exemptions under the Act in waters off Norfolk Island.

Amendments to the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988 will confer upon the Governor-General the power to make regulations dealing with the means by which an elector may dispose of the matter of having failed to vote at Australian Capital Territory elections. The maximum penalty for failing to vote is presently set by the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act at $50. The introduction of an infringement notice procedure is proposed to enable an elector, instead of being pursued through the courts, to discharge his or her liability for failing to vote by paying a penalty of $20 directly to the Electoral Commissioner. The Bill makes two further minor technical amendments which clarify the intention of the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act.

Parts 3 and 5 of the Bill contain amendments to the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 and the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Act 1988. These amendments are largely technical in nature and are necessary to ensure that effect is given to the original intention of the legislation.
I commend the Bill to the Senate, and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (ELECTORS' INITIATIVE) BILL 1989LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVE BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Macklin) agreed to:
That the following Bills be introduced:
(1) A Bill for an Act to provide a method of altering the Constitution on the initiative of the electors.
(2) A Bill for an Act to provide for the holding of referenda on bills proposed by members of the public.
Motion (by Senator Macklin) agreed to:
That these Bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-

The Australian Democrats believe that most Australians want a Constitution which reflects our aspirations for the future and which will facilitate the good government of Australia into the next century. To this end the Australian Democrats have fought a single-handed battle over the last ten years against the combined opposition of the major political parties to give citizens a greater say in the operation of government and allow them to contribute directly to the laws of the land.

In 1978, ex-Senator Colin Mason first raised the concept of citizen-initiated referendum as a method of greater public participation. The 10-year political haul culminated in the debate on the four referendum bills in May 1988 when I was able to get the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987 debated at the same time as the Government's four referendum proposals. However this progress was stifled yet again when on 26 May 1988, a motion from the Opposition to prevent further debate on this bill was supported by the government. Thus this most important concept of popular initiative, and specifically the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987, was once again shunted aside. I remind the Senate that the combined vote of the Liberal, National and Labour Parties against the Australian Democrats gagged parliamentary debate on this topic. At that time I made it clear that I believed the people of Australia should themselves have the opportunity to accept or reject my proposed alteration of the Constitution which would have enabled them to petition the government for a referendum on a proposed piece of legislation or the alteration of the Constitution.

The two bills which I am introducing today are an extension of and an improvement upon the constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987. They have taken into account the enormous public response which I have received to my 1987 Bill (and previous versions of this bill). The changes are an acknowledgement of this public comment and an attempt to gain more parliamentary political support so that real progress can be made.

My two new bills do not include provision for a voters' veto, which together with the constitutional initiative and the legislative initiative constitutes the third element of the popular initiative process. I believe that it is preferable to focus our efforts on the positive aspects of the initiative and referendum process. To this end I have introduced one bill which provides solely for a constitutional initiative and one bill which provides for a legislative initiative. Proponents of the voters' veto proposal have the fall-back option of trying to use the initiative process to have a veto introduced.

In framing these bills, the Australian Democrats accepted comments from interested groups and the public on my earlier bills and responded to the criticisms made during previous parliamentary debates. We have examined at length the situation in overseas countries where the popular initiative process has worked so well and been widely accepted by the governments and people, most notably in Switzerland and the USA. The most telling indication of the support for the initiative is that it has not been challenged-let alone dismantled or abolished-in countries where it exists. I believe a similar situation would occur if it were introduced in Australia. Most recently there have been some very interesting case studies of how the initiative process works in the USA and Switzerland.

At the United States General Election held on 6 November 1984 the voters of California were asked to vote on several topics as well as elect the US President, the Congress and the California legislature. The California Ballot Pamphlet contained the ballot titles, short summary of the proposals, the Legislative Analyst's analysis, the pro and con arguments and rebuttals, and the complete text of each proposition. It also contains the legislative vote cast for and against any measure proposed by the Legislature. There are, of course, no such vote record for citizen-sponsored initiatives.
On the 1984 Ballot Pamphlet, Californians were required to vote on (i) Bond Acts, (ii) Legislative Constitutional Amendments, and (iii) Initiative Statutes and Initiative Constitutional Amendments.

Bond Acts are approved by the State Legislature to finance specific projects and use the proceeds from the sale of general obligation bonds. The Legislative Analyst in the Ballot Pamphlet states that: ``A general obligation bond is backed by the full faith and credit of the state, meaning that, in issuing the bond, the state pledges to use its taxing power, if necessary, to assure that sufficient funds are available to pay the principal and interest on the bond.''

Legislative Constitutional Amendments are alterations to the Californian State Constitution proposed by the legislature and put to the voters for their approval. Initiative Statutes and Initiative Constitutional Amendments are alterations to the laws and Constitution of California proposed by the required number of electors and put to the voters of California for their approval.

Amongst other things, Californian electors were asked to vote on Bond Laws to increase funding for: the cleanup of hazardous substances; further purification of Californian drinking water; changes to property taxation; reapportionment of electoral boundaries; and distribution of voting materials in languages other than English.

On 8 November 1988, Americans in 41 States-in addition to choosing a new President, vice president, and assorted national, state and local officials-voted on about 230 state-wide proposals. These ranged in significance from a measure mandating closure of 2 nuclear power plants in Massachusetts to another authorising a weed-killing program in Alabama.

Many of these proposals were initiatives-or referenda that originated from the electorate rather than state legislators. This process is allowed in only 22 States. The other proposals originated from the state parliaments.

The results of the recent referenda in the USA indicate that voters cannot be bought by the weight of advertising for either the ``yes'' or ``no'' campaign. For example the insurance industry spent $75 million backing four contradictory and confusing auto-insurance referenda, but all were defeated. Proposition 19 which proposed a 25 cent tax on cigarettes to fund medical research and education passed despite the tobacco industry's $16 million campaign to defeat it. Maryland voters also rejected an expensive lobbying effort by the National Rifle Association which spent $5 million trying to kill a new state law regulating the manufacture and sale of cheap handguns, and overwhelmingly approved the legislation.
As part of the routine series of federal ballots conducted in Switzerland in 1988, national referenda were conducted on 4 December on:
(i) a town-country initiative against land speculation;
(ii) an initiative in favour of the 40-hour working week; and
(iii) an initiative in favour of the restriction of immigration.

The subject matter of these ballots, which were initiated by private citizens, is indicative of the importance and variety of issues on which ordinary electors may directly vote. Clearly some controversial issues come to a vote too. My argument is that these processes are what democracy is all about. It is important to note that just because these initiatives were on the 4 December ballot paper did not mean that they were supported by the required majorities. In fact the electors of Switzerland rejected all three proposals by a clear margin of about 2 to 1.

In the Australian context, I believe that no majority group of any political persuasion would succeed in effecting change without the voting support of the majority. This is due to the built-in safeguards enshrined in my bills which require considerable community support before a question can even proceed to the referendum stage. Moreover, even when this has been accomplished, the majority of the population is still required to approve any proposal at the ballot box before it can take effect.

Honourable Senators will be interested to know that Canadian politicians also have a long history of seeking consultation with the people on a variety of questions and an appreciation of the importance of greater citizen participation. In fact as recently as January 1988 the citizens of Prince Edward Island were asked whether they favoured a fixed link with the mainland. This was neither a new question nor a fresh issue, but certainly one of transcending importance for the Island's economy, tourism and way of life. And for all the decades of debate-about tunnels, causeways and ferry-boat services-it was the first time ever that the people who lived there were directly asked for their opinion, and the first time they had a chance to directly express it. Premier Joe Ghiz referred the question directly in a plebiscite to the people of Prince Edward Island.

Plebiscites are more a part of the democratic infrastructure of Canada than most people would believe. There have been 2 plebiscites at the national level on prohibition of liquor on 29 September 1898, and conscription for overseas military service on 27 April 1942. Over 40 plebiscites have been held at the provincial level, starting with liquor prohibition in a Prince Edward Island vote in 1878, down to the present times with the vote on independence in Quebec in May 1980, and the Northwest Territories plebiscite on territorial division in April 1982.

Apart from prohibition issues, province-wide plebiscites have dealt with such questions as women's suffrage, public health insurance, daylight saving time, ownership of power companies and marketing of coarse grains. At the municipal level, several thousand plebiscites and referendums have occurred in this century, on issues ranging from bond issues, building projects, local option prohibition, local franchises, and forms of municipal government.

Prince Edward Island is one of several provinces with a separate enabling statute for the holding of votes on ``questions''-the Plebiscite Act. The British Columbia Act contains enabling provisions for province-wide plebiscites, which have been resorted to at least 9 times since Confederation. Alberta, New Brunswick and Newfoundland have similar provisions in their election acts, while Quebec, Yukon and Northwest Territories join Prince Edward Island in having separate statutes for holding plebiscites.
When enabling legislation does not exist, a special statute has to be enacted each time a plebiscite is held. Similarly during the 2 national plebiscites, enabling legislation had to be drawn up.

Legally there is a distinction between a plebiscite, which is a formalised expression of public opinion through the ballot box, and a referendum, which is the same thing, except its results are a binding verdict of the people which must be reflected in law.

Mr Patrick Boyer MP a member of the Canadian Parliament has stated that plebiscites and referendums are ``vastly underutilized instruments of our system of popular government in this country, and that Canadian democracy will be much healthier and stronger when we permit greater direct participation of citizens in government decision-making.''

Some critics of popular initiative through plebiscite or referendum argue that the idea of giving citizens the right to decide questions of local, state or national importance reduces the standard or the role of representative democracy. It is interesting, therefore, to note that even in the United Kingdom, in what many considered a major departure from accepted constitutional practice by the mother of most of the world's parliamentary democracies, a plebiscite was held in 1975 on the question of Britain's entry into the European Common Market. This is not the only precedent. On 8 March 1973, in an attempt at a new settlement to the sectarian violence and problems of government in Northern Ireland, a plebiscite was held asking the voters whether they wanted the province to remain part of the United Kingdom.

Moreover in September 1981 the then Secretary of State for the Environment, Michael Heseltine, proposed legislation to subject high-spending local authorities to a rates referendum of local voters. However because of the low level of support within the government ranks and their ambiguous and unconvincing advocacy of the bill, the minister was forced to withdraw his proposal even before the second reading. Despite its brief existence the proposed statute raised for public view the question of whether `direct democracy'-the referendum-could exist in a society which considers itself the model of representative democracy.

Eugene C Lee, Professor of Political Science at the University of California, Berkeley, in an article titled ``Can the British Voter be Trusted? The Local Referendum and Tax Reform'' discussed the implications of this British experience. He suggested that there are three things the referendum can do that no other instrument can.

``First, it can give everyone voting an equal say on a specific question; second it can enable people to decide an issue on the basis of what is in the public interest; and thirdly it identifies the interest of the people with the government.''

All is not well with the current state of representative democracy-for example the exaggerated symbolism of the mandate and the partisan secrecy of many local council majorities. Lee argues that ``the referendum might provide a small corrective to these concerns'' without endangering parliamentary sovereignty. The referendum ``could be a useful addition to British local democracy-a half-way house between uniform central control and unrestricted local council autonomy.''

The people of Australia are well aware of the overwhelmingly positive aspects of the concept of popular initiative. It remains now for the major political parties to get their collective heads ``out of the sand'' and wake up to this unique opportunity to improve the operation of politics and government in this country. The parliament must offer the people an opportunity to contribute more to the political and governmental processes.

Honourable Senators will recall that the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987 provided that if 5 percent of enrolled electors petitioned within a 6 month time period for the introduction of (a) a specific piece of legislation or (b) an alteration of the Constitution, then a national referendum had to be held on that question within 12 months. The two bills I am introducing today are based on the 1987 bill-albeit with some substantial differences which will be outlined.
Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1989

This bill provides for at least 5 percent of electors who voted (formally) at the last federal election to petition for a national referendum on a proposal to alter the Constitution. The 1987 bill specified petitioning by 5 percent of enrolled electors. The provisions of this bill represent a relaxation of the requirements because the number of voters that vote is less than the number actually enrolled. In fact some 9,235,000 people voted formally at the 1987 election for the House of Representatives and therefore the required number of petitioners would be 462,000 people. The time period for the collection of the required signatures is again 6 months.

This bill does not provide for the introduction of a legislative initiative in the Constitution as my earlier bills did. It relates only to a constitutional initiative which would allow voters to petition for a referendum on a citizen-initiated proposal to alter the Constitution.

The Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1989 provides for a new Section 129 dealing with ``Alteration of Constitution on electors' initiative'' to be inserted into the Constitution. This bill outlines a major role for the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) in the process. Section 129 provides for the AEC to register persons or groups of persons as proponents of a proposal to alter the Constitution. Such person or persons must be qualified to vote for members of the House of Representatives to become a proponent.

The registered proponents may present a petition to the AEC ``requesting the Governor-General to cause to be put to the people by way of referendum the proposed law to amend the Constitution endorsed on, or attached to, the petition.'' The bill requires that such a proposed law may achieve a single purpose only.

The AEC is responsible for the printing of the petition and forms for signature by electors who wish to sign the petition. It is my intention that the number of forms to be printed should be at least sufficient to contain the required number of signatures for a proposal to be successful.

The bill specifies a period of 6 months for the collection of signatures. There is a 7-day waiting period for the collection period to commence while copies of the petition (in the form of the Constitution Alteration Bill) and signature collection forms are forwarded for signature. The petitions may be signed by ``any elector in a State or Territory who was qualified to vote for the election of a member of the House of Representatives at the general election that last preceded the date so fixed.''

The bill requires that at least 5 percent of electors who voted at the last general election must sign any petition before the proponent/s ``may present the petition and signatures to the AEC.'' The new Section 129 requires the AEC to verify the validity of petition signatures by undertaking random sampling of them (as is the case in some states of the USA). If after random sampling of the signatures the AEC is satisfied that the petition was signed as required, it shall present the petition to the Governor-General.

In turn the Governor-General shall ``at the next general election of the House of Representatives submit the proposed law . . . to the electors in each State and Territory.'' The requirement for the date of the referendum to coincide with the next federal election is different from my earlier bill which specified a referendum within 12 months of the presentation of the signed petition. This alteration will result in a reduced cost of the whole popular initiative procedure and effectively counters claims that is too expensive to conduct.

The requirements for a constitutional initiative proposal to be successful are the same as apply to constitutional referenda put forward by the government. Section 128 of the Constitution currently specifies that ``if in a majority of the States a majority of the electors voting approve the proposed law, and if a majority of all the electors voting also approve the proposed law, it shall be presented to the Governor-General for the Queen's assent.''

The bill provides that the AEC may arrange for proponents or opponents of a constitutional initiative to furnish their arguments at their own expense to electors. The amendments to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 which are introduced as a Schedule to the Legislative Initiative Bill 1989 require that spending by Commonwealth, State, Territory and local governments be equal between the ``yes'' and ``no'' cases. This will ensure that proponents and opponents can distribute their arguments at their own expense, and ensures that public monies are spent equally on arguments for and against any constitutional initiative proposal.

Proposed Section 129 provides that any time during the signature collection period ``the Attorney-General or any other person qualified to vote for the election of the House of Representatives may make application to the Federal Court of Australia for a declaration that the proposed law is not in the appropriate form or does not seek to change the Constitution in a manner that is practicable or legally effective.'' If the Court makes the declaration accordingly, then the petition has no force of effect.

The last paragraph of the bill provides for the parliament to make laws with respect to all matters associated with the electors' initiative process. This is done to prevent the Constitution itself becoming enmeshed in the intricate administrative detail of the process. Rather than specifically spelling out the details and seeking to have them included in the Constitution, it is my intention that the parliament make laws with respect to such things as:
(a) the registration of a proponent or proponents to a proposed petition;
(b) the registration of opponents to a petition;
(c) the random counting of signatures to a petition;
(d) the printing of copies of a petition and of forms for signatures to the petition, including the information to be supplied by persons signing the petition;
(e) the costs of, and associated with a petition;
(f) the circulation of statements for and against a proposed alteration of the Constitution; and
(g) application to the Federal Court in respect of a proposed law to change the Constitution.

This list is not complete, but it does indicate the range of important detail that the parliament will be required to legislate on after this bill has been accepted by the people. I want my intent as the legislator to be quite clear in this regard.

I believe that the Constitution is a document which belongs to the people of Australia-not the parliament or the government or the opposition. Currently section 128 stipulates that before there can be any change to the Constitution, the proposed alteration must be accepted by a majority of voters and a majority of states at a national referendum. It seems eminently sensible, therefore, to allow the people themselves, not just the government, to propose alterations to the Constitution.

In fact, one would think that if a substantial number of electors petitioned for a constitutional alteration and a referendum was held on this question as my bill would require, the government's obligations would be reduced. Currently only the government can determine if there is a referendum and what proposals of constitutional alteration are to be asked.

By allowing the people to take this initiative, the government can relieve itself of the burden of up-dating the Constitution (as was planned through the Constitutional commission) and need only concern itself with those questions which it wishes to pursue. The introduction of a constitutional initiative may well have the effect of de-politicising the Constitution-at least in the party political sense.
Legislative Initiative Bill 1989

The Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987 included provisions that if 5 percent of electors petitioned for the introduction of (a) a specific piece of legislation or (b) a change to the Constitution, then a national referendum had to be held on the matter. The Legislative Initiative Bill 1989 has solely a legislative initiative function.

Rather than seeking to alter the Constitution to put in a legislative initiative (as the 1987 sought to do), this Legislative Initiative Bill is an ordinary bill of parliament. It has been drafted in this way to avoid any possible constitutional problems which might arise under Section 1 of the Constitution which states that:

``The legislative power of the Commonwealth shall be vested in a Federal Parliament, which shall consist of the Queen, a Senate, and a House of Representatives, and which is herein-after called ``the Parliament'', or ``The Parliament of the Commonwealth''.''

By putting our legislative initiative proposals in the form of an ordinary bill we should avoid any conflict with this section by not taking the legislative power out of the hands of the federal parliament as Section 1 says.

The Legislative Initiative Bill 1989 provides that if at least 2.5 percent of electors who voted formally at the last federal election petition for the introduction of a proposed piece of legislation, then a national referendum must be held on the bill. The 2.5 percent figure represents an enormous collection of signatures and widespread support from about 231 000 people. It is not as high as the 5 percent requirement for constitutional initiatives which we believe should be considerably stricter.

This bill outlines a major role for the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC). Clause 4 of the bill provides that individuals and organisations which seek to be recognised as the proponents of a proposal shall register with the AEC.

Clause 5 states that proponents of a proposed bill may submit a draft petition and copy of the proposed bill to the AEC for printing together with the forms for the collection of signatures. The proponent is required to pay for the printing. Clause 5 (4) specifies that the number of petitions and proposed bills which are printed must be ``adequate to enable signature by electors to a number not less than the prescribed number of electors.'' The copies of the petition and forms for signature shall be numbered for identification. Petition forms shall make provision for the full name, address, signature and electoral roll number of each person who signs to be on them.

The period for the collection of signatures is specified in clause 6. It is 6 months ``commencing on a date not earlier than 7 days after the date on which the copies of the petition and of the forms for signature are made available to the proponent.'' Thus there is a built-in period of 7 days for the forms to be distributed before the 6 month signature collection period commences.
Under the provisions of clause 7, people opposed to a proposed bill may make application to the AEC to be registered as its opponents.

Clause 8 outlines the procedure for the signature of petitions. Petitioners are required to provide their full names and addresses. If petitioners do not comply then the signature is disregarded for the purposes of the Act and it is not counted. Clause 8 (3) provides that if a person knowingly provides false or misleading information then a penalty of $1 000 is incurred.

The method of presentation of petitions to the AEC is specified in clause 9. Petitions must be signed by not less than the prescribed number of eligible electors and presented after the expiration of the 6 month period. Clause 9 (2) requires the proponent to insert electoral roll numbers on the petition forms. Obviously not many, if any, people know their electoral roll number. They will not be required to know it at the time of signing a petition because the proponents can insert this information on their behalf before presentation. This provision strikes some balance between the need for strict requirements ensuring only genuine signatures are collected, and enabling proponents to supply the required information.

Clause 10 of the bill requires the AEC to verify the validity of the signatures by undertaking random sampling of not less than 5% of the total signatures collected (as is the case in some states of the USA). For the purposes of this bill the AEC would currently be required to sample some 11,500 signatures.

The Commission shall (i) check that persons who sign are eligible voters, (ii) seek confirmation from people who signed that it is their signature, and (iii) check that the required number of people have signed the petitions.

Clause 11 details the method of presentation of petitions to the Governor-General. Once the AEC is satisfied that the petitions have been signed by the prescribed number of eligible number of electors, it shall present the petition to the Governor-General. Clause 11 (2) outlines how the total number of valid signatures will be determined. For example, if 0.6 percent of sampled signatures are found to be invalid, then 0.6 percent of the total signatures collected are taken to be invalid.

Clause 12 (1) provides that when a petition has been presented to the Governor-General, the Governor-General shall ``at the next general election of the House of Representatives submit the proposed bill to which the petition relates to the electors in each State and Territory qualified to vote for the election of the House of Representatives.'' My earlier Electors' Initiative Bills specified that a referendum be held within 12 months of the signatures being collected. The requirement in this bill for the date of the referendum to coincide with the next federal election, substantially reduces the cost of the whole popular initiative procedure and counters the exaggerated claims that the referendum process is too expensive. The community should be prepared to defray the costs of institutions and practices that foster greater citizen participation and raise the standard of a democracy.

Clause 12 (2) states that: ``where a prepared bill is submitted to the electors, the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 shall apply subject to the modifications set out in the Schedule to this Act.'' These modifications require that Commonwealth, State, Territory and local government spending on the arguments in favour of, or against, a proposed bill should be equal.

Clause 12 (3) provides that if an Act ``substantially in accordance with the Bill'' is enacted before a referendum is held on a proposed bill, then a referendum shall not be held on the proposed bill. Arguments in favour of or against a legislative initiative may be prepared by proponents and opponents of a proposed bill respectively at their own expense.

Jurisdiction is conferred on the Federal Court of Australia in the following circumstances by clause 13. Firstly, ``upon application made by the proponent of a proposed bill or by an applicant to be registered as the proponent of a proposed bill, to declare whether the bill is substantially the same as another proposed bill in respect of which there is a proponent or application has been made to be registered as the proponent.'' Secondly, ``upon application made by the Attorney-General or the proponent of a proposed bill, to declare whether a particular Act is substantially in accordance with the proposed bill.''

Clause 14 provides that ``where a majority of the voters voting at a referendum vote in favour of a proposed bill, a Minister shall, subject to the Constitution, seek leave to introduce the bill into a House of Parliament within 14 sitting days of that House after the declaration of the result of the referendum.'' This is an enforcement provision which requires the government to act on legislative initiatives which have been supported by the people. There are no requirements for special majorities to support a legislative initiative because it is an ordinary bill (not a constitutional change). Therefore I have incorporated this less stringent level of electoral support in the bill as sufficient for a legislative initiative to be put to the parliament.

Clause 15 provides that this bill when passed into law should not limit the powers of the parliament (a) ``to pass or reject a bill in accordance with or substantially in accordance with the terms of a proposed bill that has been approved or rejected by the electors at a referendum; or (b) to repeal or amend an Act passed by the Parliament that is in accordance with, a proposed bill that had been approved by the electors at a referendum, being a bill that was passed by the Parliament following the holding of the referendum.'' Thus the Parliament retains the ultimate power to decide the fate of a legislative initiative put forward by the people. If the political parties refuse to pass a proposal supported at referendum, it would be done at their own electoral peril.

I believe this Bill carries a considerable onus for the government to respond positively to legislative initiatives. If a legislative initiative were supported by a majority of voters, there would be enormous political pressure on the government to pass such proposals into law. Failure to to so would be pure political arrogance and could lead to an electoral backlash at later elections.

Clause 16 of the bill refers to the costs incurred in the legislative initiative process. 16 (2) provides that registered proponents are responsible for the costs of preparing arguments in favour of a proposal and the registered opponents should prepare the arguments against any proposal.
Clause 16 (1) specifies that registered proponents are also liable for the costs of postage related to the AEC's sampling of signatures to petitions.
Clause 17 of the bill provides for the Governor-General to make regulations for carrying out this Act.

In order to require the parliament to enact successful initiatives, it is possible to use the Constitutional Alteration (Electors Initiative) Bill 1989 to petition for alteration of the Constitution such that a legislative initiative provision be incorporated into the document. That is, if the Constitutional Alteration Bill came into effect, electors could petition for alteration of the Constitution so that a legislative initiative is incorporated.
Modifications of Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984

Simultaneous with the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1989 and the Legislative Initiative Bill 1989 I am introducing a Schedule of amendments to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984. The Schedule of modifications requires Commonwealth, State, Territory and Local government expenditure on constitutional initiative and legislative initiative proposals to be equal between the ``yes'' and ``no'' cases for such proposals.

The Schedule of amendments proposes the insertion of a new Section 11A into the Principal Act which deals with advertising relating to referendums. Clause 11A (1) provides that any spending in favour of, or against, a proposed bill must be approved by the Electoral Commission. A government wishing to expend a given amount of money, must pay at least the same amount into a fund established for the purpose of promoting the other side of the argument. If the Electoral Commission approves the proposed expenditure, an ``approval certificate'' is given to the applicant.

Clause 11A (7) provides that: ``The Electoral Commission, the Commonwealth, a State, a Territory, a local governing body or an elector may institute proceedings in the Federal Court of Australia for an injunction preventing the broadcasting, publishing or printing of an advertisement relating to a referendum in respect of which an approval certificate is required but has not been issued.'' This should prevent the unauthorised expenditure of public monies on the ``yes'' or ``no'' cases until the AEC has issued an approval certificate.

On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I have introduced two initiate bills which would enable electors to take a more active role in the political and governmental processes. There is no desire to usurp the legitimate role of elected representatives or the Houses of Parliament. The aim is to give democracy in this country a boost. The initiative and referendum processes are entirely compatible with representative democracy. The proposed modifications to the relevant referendum legislation does not remove the right of governments to promote one side of referendum questions. Instead they will ensure that public monies are distributed equally between the ``yes'' and ``no'' case, and not just used to bolster the preferred side of the argument.
I commend these bills to the Senate and to the people of Australia.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of Senator Chaney, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for inquiry and report: The operations of the National Safety Council of Australia (NSCA) (Victorian Division) including:
(a) the relationship between the NSCA and the Department of Defence, including-
(i) contracts the NSCA held with the Department,
(ii) access of NSCA employees to Defence Force bases,
(iii) contact between the NSCA, departmental officials and Defence Force personnel,
(iv) security checks and clearances for NSCA personnel;

(b) the relationship between the NSCA (Victorian Division) and any other Federal Government Department, authority or organisation in so far as such relationship involves activities undertaken by the NSCA which have a bearing on Australian security, defence and foreign affairs.

It is not my intention to debate this matter as it has already had substantial debate in both chambers. Nevertheless we in the Opposition believe that it is a matter of great importance. We would have preferred it to have been dealt with by way of royal commission. As the Government was not prepared to accept our proposition on that line, we are now moving to have a parliamentary inquiry. We think it is a matter of national importance when there are such important questions raised as to our security, defence and foreign affairs as well as numerous other matters relating to the National Safety Council of Australia and its access to government. We therefore commend this matter to the Joint Committee for speedy investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased on behalf of the Australian Democrats that the Opposition has amended the motion in this way. It has broadened its scope and extended it. We still have an overriding concern about the other question we raised with regard to the need for justice to be done, to be seen to be done and for nothing to eventuate during the committee hearings that would in any way impede a fair trial. Those issues are vitally important. The question of individual justice is as important as the question of national defence, of course. I think it is very important from either perspective that there be no impediment laid before a fair trial, either so much press coverage of what is said in the hearings of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade that the prosecution could not proceed or something that would impede a proper defence. Given that there is some controversy over in camera evidence at the moment, I wanted to raise this with regard to the Committee hearings and ask that the Committee pay some attention to this particular issue. Certainly the Democrats support the motion and thank the Opposition for extending the scope of the reference after we raised these issues last week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government wishes to oppose Senator Newman's motion moved on behalf of Senator Chaney. Given what Mr Beazley said in the House of Representatives in the last week and a half, it is already clear that there is absolutely no need for an inquiry of this kind. The suggestions that Mr Friedrich, or indeed any employee of the National Safety Council of Australia (NSCA), had access to security documents of any note at all have already been well and truly refuted. I cannot understand why we should seek further to waste the time of any committee, let alone the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I think this Committee has better things to do.
—There has been a cover-up.

—I cannot imagine that the word `cover-up' could be applied to anything relating to this. The point to be made is that the NSCA is not a Commonwealth Government body, not one over which we have had control and not one that we have sought to run. That being the case, I cannot understand what Senator Newman is on about.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take the points in the motion one by one. The first matter to be looked into is the contracts the NSCA held with the Department of Defence. The reality is that the contracts that the NSCA held with the Defence Department were small in nature. The other point is that they always involved a payment for service; they involved the service occurring and a payment being made afterwards. That being the case, one wonders why we would want to investigate those contracts.

The second matter to be looked into is the access of NSCA employees to defence force bases. The reality is that every day hundreds of people enter defence establishments. As an example, 1,800 people a day enter Williamtown. One wonders what sort of security ought to have been applied to NSCA employees in particular and how that might have been done. It would not have been possible or desirable to suggest that employees from that organisation in some way should have a security clearance that all these other people did not have. The only way one could have addressed that problem would have been to apply a security clearance procedure to every one of the thousands of people that entered these defence establishments every day. That sort of procedure would be ridiculous, given that the people about whom we are speaking do not get access to classified areas-areas that are considered to be sacrosanct for ordinary mortals. Can one imagine what sort of time, effort and money would have to go into security clearances and screening for all those people? If one acted on the sorts of claims made by Senator Newman and Mr White in the House of Representatives in recent days, that would stop normal work at defence establishments for the next 12 months.
Another matter to be referred to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is:

the relationship between the NSCA (Victorian Division) and any other Federal Government Department, authority or organisation insofar as such relationship involves activities undertaken by the NSCA which have a bearing on Australian security, defence and foreign affairs.

I find this extraordinary. One wonders what that can achieve. The answer is naught. The Opposition's attempts on the NSCA in the last 10 days have been a dramatic failure. I know that Senator Newman is accustomed to failure. The reality is that, in spite of question after question in the House of Representatives, absolutely naught occurred. It was a damp squib of a debate in the House of Representatives because the Opposition had absolutely nothing on which to pursue Mr Beazley. The more the Opposition has been routed on this issue, the more we see it making noises and the more we see the debate go on here. I would be much more prepared, as would the Government, to accept the motion moved by Senator Newman if there had been any evidence presented over the last couple of weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been presented, and you know it has been presented.

—The difficulty Senator Newman has is that the Opposition has produced absolutely nothing, with the exception of one document which, of course, had been very widely circulated all around the country, and not just to police forces but to Premiers departments and the like. It is a document to which hundreds and hundreds of people had had access. So it is hardly any sort of document about which we would have security concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Defence and the armed forces have acted responsibly in their dealings with the NSCA. So the Commonwealth was never put at risk financially. There is absolutely no evidence to suggest that there have been any security breaches either. So one wonders why we would bother a committee as busy as the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade with a reference that at best can lead nowhere and at worst is a total waste of time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) has done another of these filibuster jobs on this issue. I did not think he was intending to speak in this debate, but as he has I would like to have the opportunity to draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has been totally unable to answer a question I asked of him last week in some detail about a document called the National Security Plan. It is clear that there is some difficulty within the Attorney-General's Department to brief the Minister for Justice on that matter. I would have thought that that was a very clear indication of issues that are unresolved that need resolving and will not be resolved by internal inquiries. If Ministers of state are not being properly briefed on what has happened in their departments over the last two or three years in relation to this matter, then clearly the Parliament has to inquire.

SPEECH.PARA: We have grave concerns on a number of issues which have been raised in the debate. The Government is indicating in some sense that it has concerns by the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has chosen to ask seven or eight departments for inquiries to be held. In the light of the confidential arrangements that seem to have existed between some departments and the officers of the National Safety Council of Australia, we do not believe that interdepartmental or governmental inquiries will result in information being made available to the Australian people as to what has gone on. There is much too great an opportunity for hides to be protected and for bucks to be passed. Consequently, we are committed to the view that the only way we will get at the truth of the allegations that have been made over a wide range of issues is for the Parliament to inquire. I would not have thought it would have been worth Senator Richardson's while to waste the time of the Senate by arguing a case that has already been lost.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 November 1988, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Arbitration Amendment Bill, which the Opposition supports, will amend the Arbitration (Foreign Awards and Agreements) Act 1974. That Act gives effect to the 1958 Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards, otherwise known as the New York Convention, which sets down the rules governing the recognition and enforcement in Australia of international arbitral awards and agreements. This Bill provides a legal framework for conduct of international arbitrations in Australia. It does so by bringing into Australian domestic law the model law developed over a period, I understand, of 10 years and adopted by the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law in 1985. That was part of that body's efforts to promote the unification of international trade law. The model law establishes a procedural framework for the conduct of international commercial arbitrations. As I indicated, the Opposition supports the Bill because we believe it will enhance Australia's position as a centre for international commercial arbitration. That work in this country is taking place under the auspices of the Australian Centre for International Commercial Arbitration, located in Melbourne, and the Australian Commercial Disputes Centre, located in Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: Arbitration, rather than litigation in the courts, seems to have growing support as a method of settling commercial disputes or differences. It is seen by some, certainly in some circumstances, as quicker, less expensive and often in terms more readily understood by the business people concerned with the particular dispute. In other words, it is in their language rather than in the language of the courts. That does not mean that it is always the best option; nevertheless, it is sometimes regarded by the parties to a dispute as the best way of resolving that dispute and then getting on with their business. Often international commercial disputes are complex and can easily get bogged down in the courts for long periods-even after the resolution of preliminary questions of jurisdiction, applicable laws and so forth. The idea of a model law on international commercial arbitration was to provide one framework of rules which could apply for settling disputes wherever the company might be located or based or wherever it might be carrying on business. The certainty and familiarity that can be achieved through one system of model law has wide appeal to those who might make use of that law.

I use this opportunity to commend the work of the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law, which has provided a useful tool in this area-as it has in other areas of international trade. It is another one of those United Nations (UN) bodies which are not high profile yet perform, on a day to day basis, a useful function as the world communities interrelate, in this instance in relation to trade. It reminds us that there are so many similar bodies under the auspices of the United Nations in such fields as aviation, shipping, post, telecommunications and so forth. They perform useful functions. They are not in a high profile area, but those functions are absolutely essential in today's world.

Occasionally it is worth while moving past the criticism that has occurred in the last few years of the higher profile United Nations bodies, such as the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, and of the United National International Children's Emergency Fund, which may give us feelings of a warm inner glow when we are helping the world's children, to recognise that there are many dozens of other international bodies that have been set up under the auspices of the United Nations and operate out of the limelight to make the world community a closer community.

The model law has, I understand, been adopted by Canada, Cyprus, and California, although I understand that in Canada it was adopted with some variations. But at least that indicates that we are at the forefront of the nations that are moving to set up this standard legal procedure for international commercial arbitrations. In commerce, as you would be aware, Madam Acting Deputy President, too often we are seen as insular in outlook-and I regret to say that too often we are insular in outlook. This small step of further integrating Australia within the world's commercial community is therefore to be applauded. In a modest way, it can contribute to improving our awful balance of payment position. Also it will help build expertise in Australia in an area that can also be of benefit to us financially in the future.

In 1986 the Government established a working group to examine the model law. That group recommended adoption. That recommendation was considered by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in 1987. So the pace in relation to this particular amendment to the law has been much quicker than most, and I applaud that. I suspect that the credit is probably due to officials; their efforts in moving this project along so expeditiously should also be noted.

It should be stressed that the model law does not replace the present domestic law on arbitration. It is interesting to recognise that arbitration is becoming more popular. It is used more often now in other fields of domestic dispute-the word `domestic' can be used widely because I am speaking not only of commercial disputes but also of family disputes, for example. There is a move for greater access to arbitration procedures rather than the strictures of the law. Within our domestic law and within the Australian community we have this movement of making arbitration a more popular alternative to the resolution of disputes from the traditional means in the courts. The adoption of this model law for international commercial disputes supplements the existing Australian law. It supplements it by enabling international arbitrations to be conducted in accordance with that model law.

The model is set out as a schedule to the Bill. If one looks at that schedule, one will soon appreciate that it is to cover a very wide range of commercial activities. A footnote to schedule 1 states:

The term ``commercial'' should be given a wide interpretation so as to cover matters arising from all relationships of a commercial nature, whether contractual or not. Relationships of a commercial nature include, but are not limited to, the following transactions: any trade transaction for the supply or exchange of goods or services; distribution agreement; commercial representation or agency; factoring; leasing; construction of works; consulting; engineering; licensing; investment; financing; banking; insurance; exploitation agreement or concession; joint venture and other forms of industrial or business co-operation; carriage of goods or passengers by air, sea, rail or road.

It will readily be appreciated that the schedule adopting the model law is certainly wide in its scope. It is adopted on what is referred to as an opt out basis. In other words, it becomes the law for the settling of international commercial arbitration in Australia unless the parties choose to opt out. As I understand it, it is adopted in full unless the parties choose to opt out of a particular provision. The parties may agree, as set out in the model law, to arbitrate by separate agreement or they may have a clause in their commercial arrangements that provides for arbitration in Australia in accordance with the model law provisions. So, in effect, the parties to a dispute can get to this procedure by either of those two methods.

The model law covers the sorts of things that one would expect it to cover. In fact, I think those who drafted it should be commended for its brevity. Nevertheless, it has a capacity to deal with the essential matters. It is interesting to note the specific provision that no court shall intervene in the arbitration procedure. Perhaps there is a lesson in that for other domestic tribunals. For example, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal does not seem to be able to take one step without ending up in the courts, not through any choice of that body itself.

The arbitration agreement is an agreement by the parties to submit to arbitration in all or certain disputes. So the parties have a choice to contract generally to go to arbitration or to seek to have a particular dispute arbitrated. I think that indicates the flexibility of the arrangement. Again, the parties are free to determine the numbers of arbitrators. Of course, there is a provision as to what will occur in the event of the parties being unable to agree. In most circumstances, one could expect the appointment of three arbitrators, one appointed by each of the parties and a third appointed by the first two arbitrators. Provisions obviously are included to deal with challenges to the appointment of particular arbitrators. These are the sorts of provisions that one would expect to be included.

It is interesting also to note that the arbitral tribunal may rule on its own jurisdiction which, again, avoids recourse to the courts. The parties are free to agree on the procedure to be adopted by the arbitral tribunal in conducting its proceedings. So, again, one notes the flexibility that is incorporated within the scheme. Similarly, the parties are free to agree on the place of arbitration. So we do not have the same strict rules that we have in law as to where a matter might be litigated.

We find also that what we would refer to in law as the pleadings are to be of an informal nature. The parties shall simply state the facts supporting their claim and the points at issue and the relief or remedy sought. Again one sees stressed the informality of the procedure. Again there is a greater flexibility in the provision that the tribunal may hold oral hearings or it may determine to deal with the matter on the basis of the documents that are put before it or on other materials. So it is easy to understand why, in probably a growing number of circumstances, the international business community is choosing recourse to a much more simple approach which it hopes will be less time consuming and less expensive in resolving its disputes. By adopting this model law, Australia is at the forefront of bringing this approach within our domestic legal situation and we in the Opposition are pleased to see that.

The Bill goes one step further and provides for some additional optional provisions-what are referred to as the opt-in provisions. If the parties in fact choose, under proposed new section 22 of the Bill, to bring these additional provisions into play, they will be taken into account by the arbitration tribunal. For example, under proposed new section 24 there is a procedure in relation to the consolidation of arbitral proceedings, one that we would expect to be included. Proposed new section 25 deals with interest on the award, and new section 27 deals with costs.

There are a couple of minor legal matters that I draw to the attention of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) and he might make reference to them in his reply in due course. I have just been referring to these opt-in provisions. I respectfully suggest that there does seem to be some confusion in the drafting between new section 22, which in effect sets out the right of the parties to opt for these extra provisions, and, say, new section 25, dealing with interest, which says that it will apply unless the parties to the arbitration otherwise provide; similarly with new section 27 in relation to costs, which are said to apply unless the parties otherwise agree. I do not think it is the end of the world, but there does seem to me to be some inconsistency in the drafting approach in relation to new section 22 when read in conjunction with new sections 25 and 27. The Minister might refer to that when he replies.

Similarly, in relation to the use of proposed new section 17 concerning the use of extrinsic materials in interpretation, I find it quaint that the model law, as has been determined by the international community, taking into account our Acts Interpretation Act, can now be interpreted by including an interpretation of it which we find in this Government's explanatory memorandum. I wonder whether that is the right way to approach the explanatory memorandum in this instance. We already find that under proposed new section 17 interpretation can take into account matters that had been put before the United Nations in development of the model law, which I find reasonable. But I do think there is an element of confusion. I do not know whether that possibility was addressed when including within our explanatory memorandum an interpretation of each of the provisions of the model law which is then adopted into our domestic interpretation procedure by virtue of our own Acts Interpretation Act. If the Minister's assistants will brief him during this debate, he might make some reference to that in his reply.

I do have one concern in relation to new section 29, which we raised in the other place. That section allows for the States or a Territory to adopt mirror legislation. It was our view that there could be some confusion in relation to that when looked at from the eyes of an international commercial enterprise. One of the objectives in this whole process, of course, is to provide certainty and clarity for those who may be considering the use of the Australian procedures and our expertise in resolution of these disputes. I note that the Government has listened to the expressions of concern made by the Opposition in the other place and is now proposing to delete new section 29 and that element of confusion, and I am pleased to see that. It might not be readily accepted by the purists in our federal system that we should limit the provision in this way. Nevertheless, when we are looking at our national capacity to encourage this industry to grow in Australia, if we can have a system that leaves out as many areas of confusion as possible it will be to our benefit in the longer term.

I conclude by saying that there is evidence to suggest that Australia can gain significantly from a revenue point of view in relation to this growing area of international commercial arbitration. Figures that were put to the other place by my colleague Mr Rocher indicated that in the United Kingdom, which is a little further advanced in this area than we are, revenue produced by commercial arbitrations is already exceeding some 300 million pounds per year. Located as we are in a major trading region, and a rapidly growing trading region of the world, it is easy for one to perceive the opportunities that will be present in the years ahead. We are pleased that this model law is therefore being incorporated within our domestic law to enable us to take advantage of those opportunities. It is being incorporated into an environment where we can offer to the international community a record of political stability, of judicial stability and, what is important to the companies that take these opportunities, reasonable privacy. Expertise in this area is now developing in this country, and it is our wish that that expertise further develop. We are pleased that this Bill in some way will facilitate the development of that service. As I said at the outset, we support the Bill. We hope it will encourage the development of a thriving international commercial arbitration service within Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As was noted by the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) in his second reading speech, the International Arbitration Amendment Bill is designed to implement the model law on international commercial arbitration of the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law. As Senator Hill has already pointed out, the purpose of the model law is to provide a quick and efficient method of arbitration on disputes arising out of international commercial transactions, instead of the parties to disputes having to resort to lengthy and expensive legal proceedings. Resort to arbitration, I think, is the most cost efficient way for disputes to be settled. We believe this model law, developed now over about a 10-year period, provides an appropriate legal framework for the conduct of international arbitration in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The model law was examined by a government working party in 1986, which recommended the adoption of that model law. That then went to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, which considered the working party's recommendations in 1987, and the model law now comes before us after extensive scrutiny by relevant bodies. When we look at that procedure I think we can be reasonably happy that most of the problems that may arise in this area have been ironed out. However, I wish later to mention a couple. The existing domestic law in arbitration will be supplemented, not replaced, by the model law and by enabling international arbitration to be conducted in accordance with that model law. By amending the existing Arbitration (Foreign Awards and Agreements) Act, which gives effect to the 1958 convention on the recognition and enforcement of foreign arbitral awards, relevant Commonwealth laws relating to international arbitration will now be contained within one instrument rather than many, as has been the case to date.

The model law regulates the arbitral agreement; the composition of the arbitral tribunals; the conduct of the proceedings before those tribunals; the recommendation of recognition and enforcement of awards; and, of course, recourse against those awards. It also complements the United Nations Commission's arbitration rules, which are increasingly being used in the conduct of international ad hoc arbitrations. Apart from other benefits, the Bill will facilitate the process of establishing Australia as a base for the arbitration of international dispute settlements, particularly those arising within our region. I think this ought to be seen as a developing area. We support the Government's interest in and movement towards coming to grips with the problem. We believe that Australia has distinct political advantages as a stable democracy in the region and also having a stable economic environment. We enjoy the trust and confidence of the small and large nations of the Pacific area. All of those advantages taken together have us well placed with regard to developments in this area.

It should be mentioned that both Sydney and Melbourne already possess appropriate facilities for conducting international arbitrations. The Australian Centre for International Commercial Arbitration in Melbourne and the Australian Commercial Disputes Centre in Sydney are both well regarded bodies. The passage of this Bill will give added impetus to their endeavours. The very high standards of their facilities and their international acceptance will stand them in good stead and give an enhanced role for Australia in the arbitration of international commercial disputes. Tribute should certainly be paid to the Institute of Arbitrators of Australia whose initiative led to the establishment of the Melbourne centre in 1985.

Other benefits that will flow from this Bill include the ability of parties to choose the model law to apply the conduct of their arbitration or, if they prefer, a model with additions or amendments, subject to agreement to any such amendments. In the absence of an agreement a model law will apply, and in either case the parties have a sure knowledge of the basis on which their particular arbitration will be conducted. There will no longer be the need for costly preliminary research into State and national laws before the conduct of international arbitration in Australia. The award made will almost always be final, except for a narrow range of circumstances where the courts may intervene. Precision and certainty are particularly important in this area and the adoption of the model law will certainly go a long way towards ensuring that.

The Business Council of Australia, in raising a number of items with us-it, like everybody else in the business community, is very supportive of the moves the Government is making-expressed concern about proposed section 29. Briefly, I am not sure whether it is now necessary to go into that in great detail because the Government has circulated its own amendment to leave out clause 29. I merely put on record that we believed that the argument that the Business Council of Australia, relying on legal advice, raised with us was a valid one, and we had already drafted an amendment along those lines. We would indicate at this point, however, that the amendment circulated by the Government to delete clause 29 is acceptable, although it is not a method that we would have proposed. But we would be happy to pursue the deletion of that along the lines suggested in the Government's circulated amendment.

The second point raised by the Business Council of Australia and its legal advisers is with regard to failure of the Bill to provide for foreign lawyers to practise in Australia-that is, for foreign entities to have their own foreign representatives in international commercial arbitrations. Again we believe that this is an impediment and that foreign entities could very well be deterred from making use of the facilities already here in Australia or using Australia as a venue if they are denied the right to select their own representatives. Foreign representation is permitted within the United States; we understand Singapore is moving towards that. I would suggest that, if we are to stay current and give the maximum benefit, then we ought to look at a broadening of the exercise. I would hope that the Opposition and the Government view that particular proposal in that light. It would be silly for us to be pursuing what is an excellent Government proposal and positioning ourselves well in the Pacific area with regard to international arbitration, and still have that impediment. I am not making out that it is of a massive kind but it could still be seen as an impediment and one that ought to be removed.

So we are proposing to continue with the only amendment that we had previously intended to move. In the committee stage I will be moving to allow foreign lawyers to practise in Australia by moving an amendment which, amongst other things, will seek to allow a party, who may appear in person before an arbitral tribunal, to be represented by himself or herself or by a duly qualified practitioner from any legal jurisdiction of that party's choice, or any other person of that party's choice. We believe that opening it up in that way, given the arbitral arrangement that we are dealing with, would be a reasonable proposition. We feel that it will then completely place us in a very good position in this growing region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Arbitration is becoming increasingly recognised as an efficient and cost-effective method of settling international disputes. I think it is important for Australia to be party to this model. I commend the Government on its decision to introduce the International Arbitration Amendment Bill 1988 and the changes that the Bill embodies. However, at this point I must indicate some reservations I have with what appears to be a good amendment introduced by Senator Macklin. I believe its introduction could create barriers. For example, we must acknowledge the difficulty of foreign representation. I do not think that actually exists under this Bill. If this is going to be an international Bill it has to acknowledge the freedom of movement of people as well as processes. We should acknowledge the introduction of foreign representation, as it is embodied in this amendment. It could raise the problem of solicitors moving across State boundaries. I think that would inevitably follow as a consequence of accepting this recommendation. I would like the assurance of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) on this issue when he responds to the second reading debate before we proceed to vote on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The major purpose of the International Arbitration Amendment Bill 1988 is to amend the Arbitration (Foreign Awards and Agreements) Act 1974 to implement the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL), which is model law on international commercial arbitration. Model law provides an internationally agreed legal framework for the conduct of international arbitrations. The introduction of model law will not replace the present domestic law on arbitration. Rather, it will supplement the existing system by enabling international arbitrations to be conducted in accordance with the model law. This model law covers all those disputes arising under international commercial transactions and includes those international transactions that may arise from trade relationships, from licensing arrangements, from investments, from joint ventures or from any other international commercial arrangement which could arise or exist.

The proposal in the Bill is that by means of this model law disputes arising under any of those international agreements may be arbitrated instead of the parties being obliged to resort to often lengthy and expensive legal proceedings in the courts. Australia as a whole could benefit from the introduction of this Bill as it provides the opportunity for us here in Australia to become established as a respected centre for international arbitration. To date, model law has only been applied and adopted by Canada, Cyprus, the State of California and is under active consideration by the United Kingdom, Hong Kong and New Zealand. Thus, the successful carriage of this Bill would see Australia as the first nation in the Southern Hemisphere to adopt model law. With the Australian Centre for International Commercial Arbitration in Melbourne and the Australian Commercial Disputes Centre in Sydney, we have already established bodies which could provide appropriate centres for the conducting of international disputes.

Over the past few years arbitration has emerged as an important mechanism for settling disputes without going through the procedures of the law courts, which nowadays tends to be expensive, time consuming and not always completely satisfactory in terms of the relevance of the experience and knowledge of the judges. In fact, arbitration has become the preferable means of dispute settlement compared with the alternative of the litigation processes, which often fail to cater for the needs of modern day commerce. Arbitration generally allows disputes to be resolved with minimum cost and delay and with maximum fairness and finality. Litigation, on the other hand, often involves considerable delays and excessive costs.

One most significant criticism levelled at litigation is that it is fundamentally adversarial in nature, which is often counterproductive in a business environment. Successful business is largely built on an established set of long term relationships.
