The conflict that is inherent in the litigation process disrupts this business relationship and tends to force the parties apart. In addition, the legal process involved in existing judicial mechanisms of resolution results in the dispute being resolved in a highly formalised and unpredictably lengthy battle. The outcome of the process has been questioned in that a single judge is rarely an expert in the field and as such bases his decision on the evidence to which he has been privy. This may lead to decisions that are faulty because of an inadequacy of the information or perhaps a misinterpretation of the evidence, its ramifications and meaning.

A further reason that arbitration is preferred is the degree of knowledge of technical elements of products and services which the arbitrators have. If a case were to be presented before a judge, this information would have to be painstakingly extracted in evidence. Judges have many skills, but they do not usually include an intricate knowledge of technology, technical products or the technicalities of international items of trade in goods or trade in services. A highly skilled and competently selected arbitrator will therefore provide an important level of inherent knowledge to the case which will encourage a more efficient resolution of the situation. Arbitration is frequently favoured by all parties involved because it generally has the advantages of speed, lower costs, secrecy and informality.

There are also economic benefits to Australia in providing international arbitration services in the form suggested by this amendment Bill. An example of the monetary benefits that could accrue to this country by hosting international arbitrations was provided to the members of other place by the honourable member for Curtin, Mr Allan Rocher. He pointed out that `at least $10m would be earned in Sydney and Melbourne by arbitrators in the conduct of cases involving international commercial disputes'. The incorporation of the UNCITRAL rules within the existing Act will make it imperative for businesses involved in international trade to consider arbitration as an alternative to legal proceedings. That must be a measure for the better. In addition to this, Australia has the framework on which to build a strong reputation in this area.

One reservation that I hold with respect to this Bill is that we must adopt the UNCITRAL model law for international arbitration-and this is the catch-only if we are absolutely certain and convinced that it is in the best interests of our nation as a whole. That could be a weakness, and I would like the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to consider that point. It must not simply be so that Australia is, once again, recognised as being a signatory to an international agreement. Just because an agreement is international in its application, it does not necessarily follow that it is intrinsically superior to some other mechanism that our own national government has formulated. In fact Australia should be striving to maintain and improve its reputation as having progressive and enlightened legislation in the area of commercial arbitration. The adoption of the model law as proposed by this Bill could only lead to reinforce and enhance our reputation in this field and promote an increased level of expertise in the area. It is my belief that the successful passage of this Bill will bring substantial benefits to the Australian field of arbitration as well as to the economy. With these comments in mind, I support the Bill. Before supporting the amendment moved by Senator Macklin on behalf of the Australian Democrats, I would like there to be extensive consideration of the matters I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Arbitration Amendment Bill deals with matters that are far removed from the concerns and interests of most Australians whom we represent in this chamber. Indeed, it is far removed from most of the concerns and experiences of lawyers in this country. I concede that it is a fairly esoteric subject, but it is a subject which should command the attention of this Parliament, as it has commanded the attention of the Government and of international governments. We are considering today the adoption of an international covenant adopted by the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law, a body known as UNCITRAL. That body, as its name indicates, is concerned with international trade, and this model law deals with the arbitration of international commercial disputes in that trade.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is of very limited application in Australia, but nevertheless it deals with most important matters for Australia. We are a great trading nation and Australians become involved as a result of that trade in disputes of an international character, and ultimately those disputes have to be resolved. Unfortunately, they cannot always be resolved by agreement between the parties and their representatives acting in a conciliatory way and endeavouring to settle them, but may end up in litigation-and there lies the problem. It is difficult enough for people litigating in their own courts, but when they face the international element and the possibility of litigation in the courts of other countries and of dealing with those additional problems, the dispute becomes even more difficult to settle, and certainly very much more expensive. Therefore, it is not surprising that UNCITRAL should have given attention to this important question of seeking to resolve these disputes by arbitration rather than leaving the parties to do so by litigation.

Of course, it has always been open to the parties to make their own agreements to settle a dispute by arbitration, as parties have done for many decades in domestic disputes. Something that has been overlooked a good deal in the past is that a large number of disputes, whether they are commercial disputes or disputes about other matters, are settled by private agreements to arbitrate either because a contract includes submission to arbitration if there is a dispute instead of the parties going to the court or because the parties, when faced with a dispute, make their own agreement.

Nevertheless, these methods may not always be available in another country or the laws of another country may not be satisfactory to the parties who want to enter into such an agreement. Therefore, very wisely, UNCITRAL has developed this model law. I think this Government and this Parliament would be wise to adopt that law because there can be impediments in existing law, as there may be in Australia, to the parties making the agreement they want to make. In a federation like Australia, where there could be laws on this subject in every State-and indeed are-it is desirable to have a national law on this subject so that, when parties are contemplating having an international arbitration in Australia, they will be able to readily see what the law here is. If we adopt the model law, the UNCITRAL model law, that will have international recognition and parties in other countries may be more prepared to agree to the arbitration occurring in Australia under a well-recognised law and one where there is certainty that the arbitration will not fall foul of some provision in domestic law.

That is why I think it is important that the Government has proposed an amendment to the existing Bill which qualified that principle. The original Bill certainly admitted or even may have encouraged State laws covering the same area. Lawyers in another country acting for parties would then have to fossick around in all State laws to find out what the actual law that was going to apply would be rather than simply being able to look at one law, the UNCITRAL model law.

The adoption of this legislation by the Parliament undoubtedly would facilitate agreements being reached to conduct an international commercial arbitration in Australia. That may well be a greater convenience for Australians who are party to these disputes. It may well be that Australia could develop such a reputation in this area that parties to disputes who are not Australians at all may well be interested in having their disputes settled in Australia. When all is said and done, the City, as it is called in London, apart from being a great commercial centre, became a great centre for resolution of commercial disputes through the arbitrations that have been developed in that City over many decades. Today London is still seen as a major place for the settlement of disputes. Indeed, disputes may be agreed to be settled under the laws of that country because of the reputation it has acquired throughout the commercial world.

So there is the hope that Australia may be able to develop that type of reputation. In our position in the growing Pacific trade community, a rapidly growing community, we have a good opportunity to be seen to be not only a financial centre for a lot of this trade but also a centre for the settlement of disputes in that trade. I think a lot of the thinking behind this legislation is that Australia will develop in that way. The recently retired Chief Justice of New South Wales, Sir Laurence Street, is a very great proponent of this view. In his retirement he is playing a very active role in the attempted development of Australia in his way. I pay tribute to him for it and I hope that his endeavours will be successful. He has written a very interesting article on this very subject which was published in the most recent bulletin of the Business Council of Australia. He has proposed that the legislation should be amended in two ways, one the way which the Government has adopted, to which I have referred, and the other in the way that Senator Macklin has proposed as an amendment. I will deal with that shortly. I would just like to put on record my admiration for the approach to the subject by such a distinguished Australian jurist.

I might say in passing that we should also recognise that Australian courts have made a great contribution to the resolution of commercial disputes through the ordinary court system. This is a time when there is a great deal of criticism of the Australian court system and the delays in it, which are thought to be greater than they have been in the past, although I wonder whether that is necessarily so. Certainly there is a need for great improvements in the administration of criminal justice in Australia, a need which has been highlighted in recent months by the resignation of former Mr Justice Roden of the Supreme Court of New South Wales. But in the commercial area Australian supreme courts, and particularly the New South Wales Supreme Court, have been at the very forefront of new procedures to meet the needs of the commercial community, the needs for simpler procedures, quicker procedures, better court management and so forth.

We should also take pride at a national level that the Federal Court of Australia, which was established only 12 years ago by legislation in his Parliament on the initiative of the Fraser Government, not only because of its jurisdiction but also because of the sound administration and leadership particularly of its present Chief Justice, Sir Nigel Bowen, has become a great innovator of new procedures. The easier and quicker settlement of litigation in that court is one of the reasons why it has attracted so much business and has become such a well regarded court in such a short time. Arbitration is seen by businessmen in many cases as a more satisfactory way of resolving their disputes than through the court system. This may be because of the greater delays in the court system, more technical, old-fashioned procedures and so on, but Australian courts have been meeting that criticism.

There are probably other reasons as well. Some of them have been mentioned by Senator Watson. Arbitration is a more informal process, it is in private and its procedures probably can be tailored more to the needs of the business community. However, in some cases it can be more expensive because one has to pay the costs of the arbitrators as well as the costs of the lawyers. My clients always raised this objection with me when I suggested that they seek arbitration rather than litigation. That is probably misguided because, in many cases, one can resolve a dispute quicker through the arbitration process than through the court process, thereby saving a great deal on costs, certainly of the lawyers.

Anyway, these questions are pretty far removed from the sorts of litigants who will be taking advantage of this legislation. Litigants taking advantage of this legislation will be large companies that can well afford not only the costs of the lawyers but also the added costs of the arbitrators. From their point of view they will undoubtedly see, for some of the arguments I have given and perhaps many others, reason for resolving disputes by arbitration rather than litigation. This certainly seems to be more attractive in the international arena.

I would like to mention the initiatives that have taken place in Australia to facilitate these matters. I have already mentioned Sir Laurence Street. In 1985 a body known as the Australian Centre for International Commercial Arbitration was established in Melbourne. As the title indicates, this centre is directly concerned with international commercial arbitration. That body is apparently attracting quite a lot of business. It has been referred to in some detail by my colleague the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Neil Brown, in the other place. I do not propose to repeat what he said. It has been a very interesting and very important development. We hope that it will steadily increase its role. Obviously, it provides very valuable facilities for the conduct and organisation of these arbitrations.

Mention also should be made of the body in Sydney known as the Australian Commercial Disputes Centre. Assumptions have been made in debate in another place that that body will develop a good deal of business of this character. Certainly it is interested in that type of work, namely international commercial arbitration. But, as appears to be the case in Melbourne, the Sydney body has not been established with that particular purpose in mind. The Sydney body is overwhelmingly concerned with the mediation of domestic commercial disputes. I suppose that is where its major work comes from. But it is also concerned with the mediation of international commercial disputes. Although it is not a subject of this legislation, we should bear in mind that in this whole area of alternative dispute resolution-this is a modern phrase covering this area; it is a buzz phrase in the minds of many people-the establishment of a centre such as the Australian Commercial Disputes Centre in Sydney, which is mainly concerned with settling disputes by mediation without recourse to arbitration, much less litigation, is really the way we ought to be going with the settlement of as many disputes as possible. No doubt disputes in this area of international law are settled by having lawyers acting who are prepared to conciliate and who try to reach a settlement for the party rather than encourage it to litigate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Experts?

—The lawyers will be experts and the mediators may be experts as well. That is another advantage of arbitration over litigation-one can get expert arbitrators as well. During this debate we should bear in mind that litigation or arbitration is not the desirable way of settling disputes; it is mediation between the parties themselves, assisted, no doubt, by experts and particularly lawyers. It is very important to encourage the legal profession and the parties themselves to have mediation at the forefront of their minds rather than to resort to litigation or even arbitration.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other point I wish to mention is, as I have indicated, the proposed amendment of Senator Macklin. This was also suggested by Sir Laurence Street in the article to which I referred. It appears to be a sensible proposal. If we are to have a law that encourages people of other countries to make use of Australian facilities-this debate is all about that-we should also allow them to be represented by their own lawyers in those proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or non-lawyers.

—Sure. I have not looked at the law but I am not sure that Australian legal practitioners Acts-or whatever they are called in any State-would prevent that. Perhaps the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) can give us some views on that. Hopefully he has had somebody look at it. I think that mostly Australian lawyers would be involved. If people take part in international commercial arbitration in Australia I think they would have their own lawyers from their own countries but would want the views of Australian lawyers. They would probably consult lawyers here in the setting up of such a procedure. Australian lawyers in this field are very familiar with international litigation, international arbitration and international business generally. That is why Australian legal firms have branches in other countries. It has become a new and very much more sophisticated area of legal practice. It may be a somewhat academic question-it is pretty unlikely-but it might be the case that a foreign party to an international arbitration in Australia insists on having his or her own lawyer and no Australian lawyer participating in the exercise. Well, so be it. If we encourage this sort of thing to happen in Australia, then there ought to be a provision somewhere to deal with it. In principle, I am in support of what Senator Macklin has suggested but it may not be necessary from either a legal point of view or a practical point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: It is odd that the model law is totally silent on the matter. There is a provision in article 24 of the Bill which talks about oral hearings unless the parties agree to the contrary. There are some general statements as to how they are to be conducted. It is very strange. The Bill does not deal with the point. I will be interested to hear what the Minister has to say on this subject. Perhaps this matter can be pursued further in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate on this very important matter of attempting to establish in Australia an international commercial arbitration role. It is an excellent proposition that, at a time when Australia is becoming more conscious of its role in the international commercial community, particularly in the Pacific and in the South East Asian region, we should seize the opportunity given by this legislation not only to enhance, in a sense, our reputation as a nation that has a stability, capacity and expertise that can be offered but also to help our balance of payments. One thing we have to become conscious of in Australia is that we are going to provide wealth to this nation, to be distributed equitably of course, by the provision of services to this fast growing region as much as by the provision of commodities and goods of one sort or another. In so far as we can become a centre for the provision of financial, legal and, in this case, arbitration services of particular attraction to the region, then I think we ought to undertake that with alacrity. I am very pleased that this morning it looks as though the Parliament will give its assent to the particular involvement of Australia, which has a well regarded financial and legal capacity to be of service to the international commercial community, to provide that service in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: It is well known, as Senator Durack was mentioning from time to time in his remarks, that the legal system itself is not well suited to resolving these sorts of disputes. Senator Durack placed the emphasis on the need for mediation rather than the adversarial system which prevails in the resolution of legal disputes before ordinary judicial tribunals. He even went further and said that the ideal is a mediated process. But in so far as we have here a proposal to set up an arbitration process, then I believe that that, as has been indicated, deserves and is obtaining the support of the chamber.

The particular code which parties can adopt is the international model which is found in the annexure to the International Arbitration Amendment Bill in schedule 1. As honourable senators will know, without more, the parties will have that particular model law at their disposal for the resolution of the dispute between them. They can, of course, opt in by taking up those matters which are contained in division 3 of the Bill. What this does is to provide an attractive situation for parties involved in a commercial dispute because they know that, without more, the model law will apply. There is tremendous flexibility within division 3 for the application of those various provisions dealing with matters such as the consolidation of proceedings, interest up to making of award, interest on debt under award, costs and so on. They can not only take up those optional provisions as a whole but can also vary the mix of those optional provisions. In that way, they can opt out of the opt-in in division 3 in part. This gives tremendous flexibility and makes it even more attractive to those who might wish to take advantage of this law.

Several matters have been raised, largely in reliance on-though it would have occurred independently to people, of course-a most interesting article by Sir Laurence Street, which has already been alluded to. Sir Laurence has played a key role in keeping up the momentum on the implementation of this proposal. There is obvious merit in making it clear to parties overseas that they need to look only to one statute in order to find out which law will apply. In Australia, we are familiar with the way that the federal system works, and particularly in this chamber, where we have experience with such remarkable creatures as the Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities and the various ways in which the laws around the Commonwealth are brought into harmony in that area.

We know how the federal system works and how various devices enable mirror legislation, complementary legislation, virtually identical legislation, to apply Australia-wide, though each of the parliaments plays a role. That is terribly confusing to people overseas, particularly to those who have no familiarity with a federal system. Therefore, as will become clear when I move the amendment, the deletion of proposed section 29 will make it attractive and accessible for overseas parties to come to Australia knowing that they have to pick up only one statute, available from the Commonwealth Printer, and that sets out the situation for them. That is very sensible, and I am pleased that agreement has already been signalled in the second reading debate.

So far as representation in these arbitral proceedings is concerned, as Senator Durack has said, it is not clear whether the various legal practitioners Acts in the different jurisdictions would preclude a party to one of these international commercial arbitrations from selecting a legal practitioner of his or her choice from outside the Australian jurisdiction, or even from another Australian jurisdiction, as alluded to by Senator Watson-for example, if the proceedings were being conducted in Sydney and someone from Melbourne were selected to come up. The legal practitioners Acts are unclear, although it is thought on the whole that they do not preclude the selection of a lawyer or non-lawyer to be the representative in these particular proceedings, whereas normally, of course, the closed shop provisions of the legal practitioners Acts would exclude a lawyer from another jurisdiction from appearing before a properly constituted judicial tribunal in that particular jurisdiction.

My personal view is that there is merit in Senator Macklin's proposal. He is echoing in that proposal the article mentioned by Senator Durack in which Sir Laurence Street also puts forward this view. Nevertheless, because the various State Attorneys and the Northern Territory Attorney are concerned that this be looked at more closely in relation to their legal practitioners Acts, the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General has this matter on its agenda at the moment. Therefore the Commonwealth would prefer not to support this amendment. As I say, my personal view is that, in trying to attract this business to Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —You say the position is unclear. You should not be leaving it in an unclear position, should you? Can't we expect something more?

—All I can say is that, in so far as I have been able to be briefed on this matter, the general view is that when one goes through the various legal practitioners Acts there does not appear to be a precluding of the sort of representation before the kind of proceedings that we have in mind under this particular international commercial arbitration process. Nevertheless, there is sufficient nervousness and uncertainty on the part of State Attorneys for them to want to see this matter dealt with in their ministerial forum of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.
—How long will it take them to make a decision?
—I do not think it would take them very long at all. As I understand it, it is on their active agenda.
—But then it has to go through the legislative processes of this place.

—All I am saying is that if there is a desirable political objective-and I think that there is a desirable political objective-namely, that those parties to these commercial international arbitrations have the persons of their choice presenting their point of view, then we should seek to enable that desirable objective to occur. Senator Macklin's amendment does clarify that situation in a way that will enable it to occur.
—Then why not support it?

—I am not supporting it only because of the fact that it is on the agenda of the Standing Committee. Because the Attorney is a member of that Standing Committee, it is a matter of courtesy that it not be supported in this chamber until that body has had a chance to express its view. I certainly do not believe that we should be worried about the pleas of those who would wish to circumscribe those persons who might appear in these proceedings to duly qualified legal practitioners within the arbitration jurisdiction. That would seem to me to go against all the good things which this legislation envisages. As I say, I am pleased--
—What about the matters that I raised?

—I have answered the one about the variation which can be achieved by parties in opting in and opting out of those provisions in division 3. What were the honourable senator's other questions? I thought that proposed new section 29 was the other matter that he mentioned.

—The one about the explanatory memorandum giving an interpretation of each division of the model code. Is it sensible to have that brought into play through our Acts Interpretation Act? How does that balance against the provision that already states that in interpretation they can take into account the debate that took place in the United Nations, and so on?

—If Senator Hill is referring to proposed new section 17, the fact is that the Acts Interpretation Act already allows one to take into account preparatory documents in the committee stage, and so on. An earlier part of proposed section 17 merely reinforces the fact that one can look at those working group documents.

—The model code is not your document. It has been determined by somebody else and the courts can take into account the debate that took place leading to that model code. But you are also saying it can take into account the interpretation given by Australian officials through our explanatory memorandum.

—I do not believe that the explanatory memorandum would depart from the understanding of the correct interpretation of the model code. As I understand it, these international agreements have extremely detailed preparatory documents which go a lot further than the explanatory memorandum that we are accustomed to having in the Parliament.
—Provided you are satisfied there are no inconsistencies.
—I am assured that there are no inconsistencies. I commend the Bill to the Senate. As I say, I am grateful for the support that has been signalled by all sides.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Tate-I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the amendment to be moved by the Government.
Clauses 1 to 6-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 7.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 6, clause 7, after proposed new section 28, insert the following new section:
Representation in proceedings

``28A. (1) Where, in accordance with the Model Law, with the agreement of the parties or at the request of a party, as the case may be, the arbitral tribunal holds oral hearings for the presentation of evidence or for oral argument, or conducts proceedings on the basis of documents or other materials, the following provisions shall, without prejudice to the Model Law, apply.
``(2) A party may appear in person before an arbitral tribunal and may be represented:
(a) by himself or herself;
(b) by a duly qualified legal practitioner from any legal jurisdiction of that party's choice; or
(c) by any other person of that party's choice.

``(3) A legal practitioner or a person, referred to in paragraphs (1) (b) or (c) respectively, while acting on behalf of a party to an arbitral proceeding to which Part III applies, including appearing before an arbitral tribunal, shall not thereby be taken to have breached any law regulating admission to, or the practice of, the profession of the law within the legal jurisdiction in which the arbitral proceedings are conducted.

``(4) Where, subject to the agreement of the parties, an arbitral tribunal conducts proceedings on the basis of documents and other materials, such documents and materials may be prepared and submitted by any legal practitioner or person who would, under subsection (2), be entitled to appear before the tribunal, and, in such a case, subsection (3) shall apply with the same force and effect to such a legal practitioner or person.''.

I listened to the summing up of the second reading debate by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). I presume that his position is that, by and large, his personal view accords with this amendment, but that the Attorneys-General want to look at their own laws. I am not at all sure what will occur when they look at their own laws. One of the things they could do if their laws do not allow this type of representation-I think everybody has expressed a view that it is desirable-is to amend them. Alternatively, if their laws are silent on the matter, they could leave them alone. It seems to me that certainty in this area is something that we ought to be signalling.

I now turn to the model law. When I looked at it I thought of a number of instances, but one which seems to be pertinent to this matter is article 22 relating to languages. It states that parties are free to agree on any language to be used. I am trying to think where this may be used. Certainly, one area in which I think it is likely to be used is in our relationships with countries in our region, especially bearing in mind our growing trade with China. It may very well be that one would need to seek an expert, and that expert may wish to operate in the Chinese language. After all, it is the language of a large number of people on this planet. We should not be such Anglophiles as to think that everybody has to use the English language. What we are about is an international exercise. It would be very odd if we did not want to signal to people that they can use our venues and operate with their own representatives.
I refer to the paper by Sir Laurence Street. I think he made a very good point on page 5 of that document, where he said:

Foreign entities will need to be assured of their right to select their representatives and if this is not permitted they will be deterred from choosing Australian venues. Foreign representation is allowed, for example, in the USA, Hong Kong and British Columbia international commercial arbitrations. The law in Singapore is likely to be changed quickly to permit foreign representation. These are major competitors in the Pacific field and Australia cannot afford to carry this handicap.

I concur. We are concerned not only with international arbitration but also in a very real sense with a commercial operation. I am not at all sure that we should seek to handicap Australia in what will be a very competitive, growing field. It is one in which we are already operating, and this law aims to give us a clear and precise position. It seems to me to be silly to leave aside this one point.

I do not wish to make a big deal of it. It is not necessarily a major point, but it is a point that could easily be made certain by the adoption of the amendment which I have moved. It is a clear and precise position that, as it were, the persons engaged in this arbitration may select who they like to represent them at those arbitrations. I would think it very odd if, in seeking to operate in the international field, we sought to circumscribe such people by national law. It would be even odder if they felt themselves circumscribed by State laws. We are engaged in an international exercise. We are attempting to attract-let us be honest about it-international business to that arbitration area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you choose this set of words and not the words suggested by Sir Laurence Street?

—If one looks at the amendment I have moved one will see that to a very large extent it incorporates the proposition that Sir Laurence Street has put. We were provided with advice that we would need to do two things in relation to this legislation. One related to the items raised by Sir Laurence Street. If one looks at the model law, one will see that we have adopted items which use the phraseology of the model law with regard to the operation of documents. We have tended to use the phraseology of the model law rather than that which Sir Laurence Street used, which in part comes from uniform commercial arbitration Acts, but which also seems to reflect the way in which he feels that law should be phrased. Basically, the advice given to us was that this way of going about it would be more in keeping with the model law that is already in place. We felt that that was a persuasive argument for the adoption of this method of phrasing the amendment that is before us. I recommend that we go ahead. It does not seem to me that waiting for the various Attorneys-General to act will actually achieve anything, other than to leave the situation in limbo.

SPEECH.PARA: I urge honourable senators to think of the type of constraints that operate on this chamber. It may be very well to say, `We can bring it back for amendment'. I urge honourable senators, if they think that is an easy exercise, to look at the number of Bills already on the Notice Paper. The ability of the Senate actually to reconsider this matter is restricted. I do not think the matter will be seen as such a major item-and I am not trying to make it into a major item-that it will take precedence over so many other Bills which are currently on the Notice Paper. Therefore, I can see that it could be quite some time before we are able to return to this matter. In that time the impetus and the thrust into this area could be lost.

I urge honourable senators to think of the commercial aspects of this operation. To take it at the flood, as it were, is what we really need to do. We ought to build on this. Obviously, a great deal of international attention will be drawn to the fact that we have passed this law. It provides the opportunities. It subscribes to the model law. We are there. We are in the field. We are now working. We want this to occur in Australia. It will then be seen that as a result of this debate we have decided to leave in limbo this whole business of whether they can bring their own representatives along. I suppose, in a way, even moving this amendment will make the situation worse if we fail to pass it because we now have signalled that we are happy to leave it in limbo. I do not think we should. I do not think it trespasses in any way on the rights of the States in terms of the points raised by Senator Watson. We are not necessarily looking at lawyers; we may be looking at other experts. To take Senator Durack's point about the culture of mediation, we may be looking at experts in the area of bringing that about.

I urge honourable senators to consider this so that we can wrap up this exercise here and allow the two centres currently operating in Sydney and Melbourne to get on with the business of attracting international mediation to Australia so that we can be put on the map in one move rather than get there in dribs and drabs and possibly lose some of that impetus that is currently available by the passage of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We accept and support Senator Macklin's amendment. We have had to take this matter on the run. It would have been helpful if we could have given it greater consideration. I mention that more for the future than the present. We are also a little disappointed that the Government, although it has had the article that has been referred to in debate earlier, by Sir Laurence Street which sets out, in his view, the necessity for a provision of this nature, obviously has not directed itself to that question, and that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) can simply come in here and do no more than to say that he believes the general view is that the State legal practitioners Acts would not inhibit movement across States and appearances in these commercial arbitrations. We would have thought the Minister would be able to tell us that this matter had been researched and that he was able either to indicate that he was in agreement with the argument that Sir Laurence has put or that he opposed it and for what reason. Rather, it seems, from what he has said to us, that he has some sympathy with what Sir Laurence put but that he would like some more time to think about it and to go back to the State Attorneys-General. Regrettably, practice would indicate that that can take months if not years. It seems to us that the impetus and the opportunity would be lost.

SPEECH.PARA: We are supporting the amendment because we think it is consistent with the scheme, and that is that international commercial arbitrations will take place in various countries with representatives brought from other countries. It seems to us that a party from elsewhere should be entitled to bring their own representation as it seems consistent with the whole of this approach-as a party which might have its head office in Adelaide should be entitled to bring its legal practitioner from South Australia to an arbitration that might take place in Sydney. We wonder whether the legal practitioners Acts do inhibit it. If there is any doubt we think that clarity is the better option. As I have said, we will support the amendment. We are comforted in supporting it by the fact that someone of the eminence of Sir Laurence Street believes that it is a necessary provision to be included within this Bill. Therefore, Senator Macklin's amendment will have the support of the Opposition.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 7, clause 7, proposed section 29 lines 1 to 4, leave out the proposed section.
For the reasons indicated in the second reading speech, this amendment will make it clear to the parties that they need to look only to one law for the regulation of this particular arbitration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat what I said in my speech on the second reading: we are pleased that the Government has taken up this matter, which is also on the agenda of Sir Laurence Street and was raised by my colleague the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Neil Brown, in the other place. Again, it provides greater certainty for those who want to use the opportunity presented by this scheme. We are pleased that the Government has responded positively to the concerns that we have expressed.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT (TAX AGENTS' FEES) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, three sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to make deductible expenditure incurred for the preparation, by a registered tax agent, of information required by or under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 November 1988, on motion by Senator Reynolds:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Copyright Amendment Bill 1988 and the Circuit Layouts Bill 1988. The Opposition will support both Bills, but we will be moving an important amendment at the second reading stage of the Copyright Amendment Bill. We have a number of amendments to move at the committee stage, which I will touch upon in the course of this speech to give notice and to enable some further consideration and negotiation to take place on those amendments before the committee stage of the Bill is reached. As I understand the position, we are hoping to complete the second reading stage of this Bill today; the committee debate will take place immediately upon our return after the fortnight's break. I think that is a sensible approach because of the complex amendments that will be moved at the committee stage. This will give the Government, the Australian Democrats and ourselves time to negotiate. All parties have indicated a willingness to do that in an effort to clarify the areas in dispute and to see what can be resolved. It will also enable an orderly committee debate to take place. Hopefully, that debate will take up a minimum amount of time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Copyright Amendment Bill makes important changes to the Copyright Act 1968 and the law on copyright. In general terms, the changes are: to put a royalty on blank audio tapes used for home recording-part Vc; to protect performers from unauthorised recording or broadcasting of their live performances-part XIa; to enable educational institutions to videotape television programs-part Va; to streamline the existing licences of educational institutions to photocopy educational material and for institutions assisting the handicapped to make talking books and other useful materials-part Vb; to make some changes to the law on the protection of industrial articles covered by clauses 9 and 10, which affect sections 74, 75 and 77 of the existing Act; and to streamline the statutory licence for record manufacture. So it can be seen that this Bill covers a range of matters and that not surprisingly, as is the nature of copyright and other laws which protect intellectual property, it is really quite complex.

I want to deal briefly with each of those principal matters that are addressed by the Bill. The first matter I want to refer to is the blank tape royalty scheme for home taping. The Bill proposes a royalty to be paid on blank recording tapes, known popularly as cassettes. The Liberal and National parties support this proposal. I remind the Senate that our arts policy provides that we `support . . . the introduction of royalty payments on blank tapes used for sound recording . . .'. I commend our spokesman, Senator Puplick, who is present in the chamber and who will be participating in this debate, for the leadership that he is showing in this area.

Home taping from the radio, records and other tapes is, as we all know, widespread. It is a breach of copyright but it is difficult to prevent. The result is that those whose creative endeavours are put into a work, such as composers, as well as the publishing houses and the recording companies, are having their work reproduced without receiving any compensation. After consultation, this Bill sets out a scheme to accommodate the concerns of both consumers and copyright owners. `Under the scheme, consumers will be able to continue home taping of recordings directly or off air for private and domestic use without infringement of copyright. In return, owners of copyright in the recordings will receive a royalty levied on blank recording tapes.

The royalty will be payable only on audio tapes with a playing time of more than 30 minutes and will be calculated by reference to the length of playing time. The royalty will be determined by the Copyright Tribunal. As I understand it, the Attorney-General's Department expects the royalties to be between 20c and 50c a tape. But the industry association expects it to be higher, perhaps up to $1 a tape. This is a matter that is obviously yet to be resolved. The royalty will be paid by the first seller of the tape-that is, the importer or manufacturer. Copyright owners will then be paid a share of the royalties if they are members of the single authorised collecting society to which the royalties will be paid.

Copyright owners who will benefit from the scheme include composers, lyricists and authors as well as the music publishing companies and record producers. I am advised that the recording companies have agreed that a substantial share of the royalty will be passed on to performers under their contracts. This will ordinarily amount to one-third of royalties collected by the society. I suspect that this will be a matter that my colleague, Senator Puplick, will want to develop further in his contribution to this debate.

The scheme does not apply to video taping of television programs and videotapes. Fifteen per cent of the royalty will go to those in the Australian music industry most in need of assistance and part will go to the Australian Contemporary Music Development Co. which was recently established by the Government to foster Australian contemporary music and young up-and-coming Australian musicians. The royalty will be payable on all blank tapes ordinarily used for recording audio materials, including digital audio tapes.

Institutional users-for example, schools and institutions for the blind-will be able to purchase tapes free from the royalty. Individuals or organisations which buy tapes and which do not intend to use them to record copyright material will be able to obtain a refund of the royalty if they make a statutory declaration that the tape will not be used to record a copyright sound recording.

The royalty will be collected for the benefit only of owners of Australian audio copyright materials and owners of audio copyright materials in countries which have similar schemes which provide comparable benefits to Australian owners. This will ensure that Australia adheres to the spirit of the relevant international copyright conventions without providing a windfall to foreign owners in countries which have not addressed the problem of home taping.

As I said, the Opposition supports the proposal for a royalty on blank audio tapes to provide compensation for owners of copyright whose material is presently being illegally copied. However, we have some concerns about aspects of the scheme and about the mechanism set out in the Bill to implement these changes. For this reason, in respect of the Copyright Amendment Bill, I move:
At end of the motion, add `, but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(a) upon the commencement of part Vc of the Bill, or as soon as thereafter as may be practicable, the Government should refer the following matters to the Copyright Tribunal for inquiry and report:
(i) the extent to which audio tapes purchased in Australia are purchased with the intention of using them to record copyright material and non-copyright material respectively;
(ii) whether the blank tape royalty scheme set out in part Vc of the Bill is the most practical means of implementing a blank tape royalty scheme;

(iii) whether the blank tape royalty scheme set out in part Vc of the Bill is the most effective blank tape royalty scheme for providing compensation to Australian performers whose material is recorded domestically on audio tapes in breach of copyright;

(iv) whether the proposal in proposed subsection 135zzs (3) of the Bill for a statutory declaration entitling the purchaser of a blank audio tape to a refund of the royalty paid on that tape is the most effective means of effecting a refund or waiver of the royalty when the tape is not used for recording copyright material; and

(v) whether the proposal in proposed subsection 135zzu (3) for the rules of the collecting society to make provision for the distribution of amounts collected by it is adequate to ensure that a reasonable proportion of the amounts collected is passed on or distributed to those whose own work has contributed to the making of the eligible sound recording or eligible work; and
(b) upon receipt of the report of the Copyright Tribunal on these matters, the Government should propose such amendments to the Copyright Act as may be necessary or desirable'.

Although the amendment makes it plain that we are not opposing the second reading, we believe it also indicates that there is a real need to have a close examination of the mechanics of this scheme, and we believe that this examination should be conducted by the Copyright Tribunal. In the first place, the amendment raises the question of just what proportion of tapes purchased in Australia are purchased with the intention of using them to record copyright material and what proportion are purchased with the intention of using them to record non-copyright material. Secondly, the amendment also expresses our concern that the mechanics of the scheme, as set out in the Bill, may not be the best way of channelling part of the royalty money to the musicians, artists and others who really need it and are entitled to it. The Copyright Tribunal will be able to tell us whether this is the best way of spreading the royalty moneys around. Likewise, there is clearly a case for an inquiry into the curious and cumbersome method of obtaining a rebate or refund of the royalty. The Bill provides that if the purchaser of a tape maintains that he does not intend to use the tape to record copyright material, he must make a statutory declaration to that effect and send it to the collecting society to obtain a refund. This is obviously an extremely cumbersome procedure and the Copyright Tribunal should examine it to see whether it is the most effective means of having the refund made.

Then there is the wider question of whether the scheme set out in the Bill is the most effective blank tape royalty scheme for providing compensation to Australian performers. As I have indicated, that is also covered by our amendment and the Copyright Tribunal should examine it. All of the matters, as I have said, are covered within this amendment and we therefore put to the Senate that the Copyright Tribunal should examine the questions we have raised. I hope that that amendment will be supported.

We also have some more detailed amendments in relation to this scheme which we will be putting at the committee stage. One amendment will define the prescribed organisations which will not have to pay the royalty. A second amendment will require the Attorney-General to table the annual report from the collecting society on the operation of the scheme. I will speak further to those amendments in the committee stage.

The second area covered by the Bill, which I now wish to deal with, is that of performers' protection. At the moment performers such as actors, singers, musicians, puppeteers, dancers and variety artists have little legal control over the illegal recording of their performances. Technological developments have created effective means of unauthorised commercial use of performances, namely, recording, broadcasting and diffusion by cable. The Copyright Law Review Committee has recommended that performers be given protection from this commercial exploitation of their live performances. The Government's solution is to give the performers not copyright protection, which is a property right, but a civil right of action to sue for damages for any unauthorised recording or broadcast of their performance. The new provision will provide performers with greater bargaining power when negotiating contracts. This proposal is again consistent with the coalition parties' arts policy, and we therefore support it.

The Bill also provides for a series of criminal offences for the illegal recording of performances, punishable by a fine, and for copying recordings or trading in them, punishable by a fine or imprisonment. Whilst I will not use this opportunity to go through each of those offences, it is worth noting at this second reading stage that they are numerous and that the penalties imposed are considerable, with fines up to $250,000 and, in some instances, maximum imprisonment terms of up to five years. I would have thought that would be a dissuasive influence upon someone who wishes improperly to use the creative endeavours of those performers.

The third matter I wish to deal with at this stage is that of copying. The Bill establishes several statutory licensing schemes to provide a mechanism whereby the interests of copyright owners will be balanced against the interests of educators who need to copy educational material in the most efficient manner possible. The first licence is to be a statutory licence for audio-visual copying by educational institutions. The Bill establishes a statutory licensing scheme which will allow educational institutions and institutions assisting handicapped persons to make copies of television programs in return for payment to the copyright owners. Off air copying of television programs by educational institutions is an infringement of copyright, unless permission is obtained from the copyright owners. To avoid breaching copyright, separate permission is presently required for copying the script, the sound recording, the background music, the film and the broadcast itself. The scheme introduced by the Bill follows recommendations in the 1986 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on audio visual copying by educational institutions. Under the licence proposed by the Bill, educational institutions will be able to make off air copies of television programs for educational purposes. Copyright owners will be able to claim payment for the copying of their material through a single collecting society approved by the Attorney-General. The payment will be as agreed between the parties or, in the absence of agreement, as decided by the Copyright Tribunal. Institutions will be able to elect to pay for the right to copy either by an amount per student or according to actual material copied, based on full record keeping.

The second scheme is a statutory licence for photocopying by educational institutions. The Bill revises the existing educational photocopying scheme. I think it is widely accepted that the present scheme is cumbersome and costly because of its complex record keeping requirements. The revised scheme is based largely on voluntary agreements already entered into between Copyright Agency Ltd-the authors and publishers collecting society-and a substantial number of educational institutions throughout Australia. Cooperation in this regard has largely been achieved by abandoning the record keeping requirements of the present scheme, under which payments are required for actual copying. Instead, payment is being made on the basis of agreed sampling schemes whereby estimates can be made of the amount of copying and payment made on a per student basis.

The amendments facilitate these voluntary arrangements and ensure that they can operate effectively under the legislation. The revised photocopying scheme will adopt the flexibility of the television copying scheme. It applies to literary, academic, musical and artistic works. There will be a collecting society representative of copyright owners; schools may elect to pay for copying on a per student basis or, as at present, by full record keeping, with records sent to the collecting society. This will avoid copyright owners having to carry out time consuming and costly record inspections at the thousands of schools spread around the country. This revised scheme will, in practice, be much simpler to comply with and it will substantially improve the means of remunerating copyright owners for the use of their copyright materials. The Bill also includes new provisions which will streamline copying by institutions assisting handicapped readers and intellectually handicapped persons. We support this proposal.

The next area of change is the copyright designs interaction, which is a highly complex matter. The Bill seeks to update-or at least that is the word used in the second reading speech of the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds)-the protection given to artistic works that are either registered as designs under the Designs Act 1906 or used industrially without registration. We have also been told by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) that for many reasons industrial designs are not appropriate to be protected by the Copyright Act and that there is at present a lot of overlap which is leading to confusion. We accept that that confusion exists.

In 1973 the Designs Law Review Committee report on the law relating to designs recommended that designs be protected under the Designs Act and not under the Copyright Act. The Bill amends the Copyright Act to this effect. However, we are concerned with the way in which the Bill is drafted. Its result will be that some designs will not be protected either by copyright or by the Designs Act. The result of that will be that Australian entrepreneurs will not invest in research and development resulting in industrial designs if their designs will be able to be pirated with immunity. That is an undesirable result. To prevent that undesirable result from happening we will propose amendments at the committee stage. These are amendments which were moved in the other place. Whilst I do not wish to deal with them in detail now, they would delay the commencement of this part of the Copyright Act until the Designs Act has been amended so that `corresponding designs', as they are called, can be registered under the Designs Act. Again we hope that we will receive support from at least the Australian Democrats in this place.

The next subject matter to be dealt with under the Bill is that of statutory licences for record manufacture. The Copyright Act presently contains a statutory licence for the manufacture of recordings of musical works. The relevant provisions specify conditions upon which the licence operates and a mechanism for changing the rate of royalty payable to music copyright owners. This mechanism gives the power to the Attorney-General to determine that the current rate is inequitable. There is then an inquiry and report made by the Copyright Tribunal. The Government considers that the preliminary requirement for the Attorney-General to determine the current royalty rate to be inequitable is an undesirable and inappropriate role for government. Accordingly, the Copyright Amendment Bill will introduce a simplified scheme based solely on a Copyright Tribunal determination of the rate in the absence of agreement, which will be consistent with other schemes in the Act-for example, the compulsory licence for broadcasting music. Such a scheme has industry support and will remove unnecessary government involvement in the industry. We also support this change.

The Circuit Layouts Bill 1988 will protect computer chip layouts from unfair copying. The Australian computer chip industry is small but is important and growing. Australian chips enable bionic ears and heart pacemakers to work, detect messages from space and from the ocean, and convert sunlight to power. Our specialised products have found valuable markets overseas. The Circuit Layouts Bill repeals inappropriate and uncertain Copyright Act and Designs Act protection and provides protection for original chip layouts along the lines of the laws passed recently in the United States, Japan, Scandinavia and the European Community countries. The Bill is consistent with the World Intellectual Property Organisation's draft treaty on the protection of intellectual property in respect of integrated circuits. Enactment of the Circuit Layouts Bill is wanted by the industry and is needed to obtain permanent protection for Australian circuit layouts in the United States and European markets. The Bill creates modified copyright protection. It gives the creator of an original chip layout the exclusive right to copy the layout, to make a chip in accordance with the layout and to make the first commercial exploitation of the layout or a chip made in accordance with it. The rights arise automatically. In our opinion this is a simple low cost form of protection involving no red tape. It is welcomed by the industry and therefore has our support.

As I said, we will be moving a number of amendments in the committee stage. I have already mentioned that we will be moving amendments in relation to the royalty on blank audio tapes to define the described exempt parties, and also to require the lodging of an annual report. We will also be moving amendments to allow media monitoring companies to copy and provide copies of radio and television broadcasts to people or organisations mentioned in or affected by the broadcast and to allow news clipping services a similar right without these being a breach of copyright. We will be moving amendments to restore the pre-existing right of educational institutions to photocopy, without being required to pay royalties, copies of periodical articles, anthologies and works, where they are for external students. We will be moving an amendment to make it an entitlement of performers to insist on their authority being given before there is a use made of a recording of their performance, prospective only and not retrospective. I think the Government has put before us an amendment indicating that it has accepted our representations in this regard. I am pleased to note that it has recognised the deficiency in this Bill.

We will move an amendment to allow news or current affairs programs to be rebroadcast for criticism or review without making this a performance and therefore requiring the authority of performers to be given. In other words, we extend it to cover current affairs programs, which we think is important. We will move an amendment to provide that a recording is not authorised and thereby putting the recorder at risk of being sued by the performer if it is made for use in a later soundtrack. I understand that the Government also has some amendments in this regard which we will now consider in detail to see whether they cover the concerns we have expressed. We will move amendments which have been proposed by the Australian Vice-Chancellors and Directors and Principals in Advanced Education to achieve the copying of radio broadcasts and the copying of published audiovisual material upon payment of a fee. It will provide also for fair dealing provisions in relation to audio-visual materials. That is in relation to materials used in that way by educational institutions. It is in addition to external students.

That covers all our amendments which we intend to move. I give the Senate this preview of our committee stage amendments and hope that the negotiating process which will take place over the next two weeks will be fruitful. We basically support the Bill and the scheme of the Bill and hope that in the end it will come into effect, but with the improvements we have outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Copyright Amendment Bill 1988 is a major and worthwhile contribution to copyright law reform. The changes that are incorporated in this Bill come after many years of consultations, reviews, inquiries and reports. Essentially, this is the third stage of the Government's initiatives in this area. We dealt with this Government's amendments in 1984 on works for invisible computer memory and in 1986 on the anti-piracy provisions and allowing disabled people greater access to copyright material. The basis of copyright law is to balance the rights of the owners to copyright with the legitimate needs of various groups in the community to use those materials. In particular, the most contentious area relates to educational institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to accept that the review and monitoring of copyright law can be nothing other than an ongoing process. It is an area which is particularly fraught with problems. Often the items raised by Senator Hill, in terms of the Opposition's amendments, in almost every case represent competing principles, not just a black and white context, but where principles and rights of various groups and individuals are in competition.

I was invited by a reporter yesterday to say that the Government had done a bad job with this legislation because there were to be amendments. I rejected that on the basis that I do not believe that that would assist in any rational discussion of this area. It is a difficult area; it is fraught with problems. In terms of the Bill itself, where we may differ from the Government in almost every case it is a matter of giving more weight to one particular principle against one which the Government itself has adopted. Those are matters for judgment, and one hopes that, along with the point raised by Senator Hill, the discussions we shall have on areas that need to be resolved might be conducted in a helpful way.

Among the major areas, one item that has proved quite contentious is the interaction between the copyright legislation and design protection. Here we are up against one of the areas that I have already mentioned. At the moment the current law seeks to reflect the policy adopted by the Government of distinguishing between different uses of artistic works. For example, where an artistic work, say a drawing, is used as a design for mass production, it is registrable under the Designs Act and is protected under that Act. If the same drawing is used as an illustration in a book, it is then an art work and is protected under the Copyright Act. That drawing may be used both by the designer and in a book, which can give rise to some significant problems. But by and large the copyright system is looking at the artistic works and the Designs Act is looking at designs, even for artistic works such as pottery, which may be turned into a dinner set, or a particular design may be used in relation to a car.

There is an attempt to make a more fundamental distinction, and that is between the copyright protection for intellectual property and the Designs Act for industrial property. I am not at all sure that that holds up, particularly in regard to some of the industrial areas, but that distinction is also often drawn. Copyright protection is automatic, whereas design protection is not. Copyright protection is generally based on the creator's life span, whereas design protection requires generally a much shorter level-depending on whether the artist is quite old-of protection, usually a maximum in most jurisdictions of around 16 years. What the Designs Act is attempting to do is to give designers a lead start in production and in the field. Generally that is sufficient to protect their work, though not in all cases.

In terms of this Act there is some overlap and it is not the only source. Section 77 is probably the most difficult area and provides that where work used as a design is industrially applied, the artistic work loses copyright protection in relation to use on the type of article to which it has been applied. Hence, to have protection, registration under the Designs Act is absolutely essential. This may not be possible once the industrial application has taken place and the artistic work could be left unprotected. The present system does not seem to be satisfactory to protect adequately the work of artists and of crafts people.

The scope of section 77 has been long debated, and if honourable senators wish to verify that they only have to look at the vast amount of paperwork which has flowed around since this Bill hit the table. The difficulty is that a large range of artists seem to be quite oblivious to the Designs Act requirements and to the fact that their copyright may have left them, may have been dissolved, since it should be dealt with under the Designs Act, and where no move has been made under that Act for registration. It is worth noting in advance in regard to the proposed amendments that Australia has obligations under international conventions. The International Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works and the Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property are two to which it is required we give adherence. The Bill before the Senate addresses the question of whether copyright protection should be available for artistic works industrially applied. Artists and crafts people say yes and industry says no. In fact, one commentator put the matter graphically by saying, `T shirts are in and exhaust pipes are out'. I thought that was an interesting way, if not too accurate, of trying to draw that type of distinction.

The Bill is looking at the changes in this area of overlap and the amendments allow for a review by the Attorney-General's Department in its discussion paper dealing with copyright protection for artistic works applied industrially, which was issued a couple of years ago. The new scheme will work in the following way. Artistic works that are two-dimensional will have copyright protection available. Conversely, the Bill will abolish copyright protection for industrial designs which, for technical reasons, are presently incapable of registration under the Designs Act. We believe that visual artists and crafts people will now, under these amendments, be able to rely on adequate copyright protection. The problem of losing copyright will no longer apply.

However, the situation on the industrial side is not quite so happy. There will no longer be any protection under copyright where the design is unregistrable. If it is registrable, that registration will secure protection. A number of sections of industry have reacted adversely to the proposition in this legislation. They say that it will be an obvious disincentive to research and development in Australia. They ask the question, not unnaturally, why any company should spend money on research and development of these products if the design is not registrable under the Designs Act. Competitors could, with impunity, copy those products and not have to spend any money on research and development, and hence would be able to sell in the market-place at a far lower cost, their not having to put an element for research and development into the final selling price.

Apart from the objections about loss of protection, there is also a dispute about the actual implications of the changes. I do not want to get involved in that aspect, but the dispute involves the Attorney-General's Department and the Law Council of Australia. I do not wish to wander into an area where the lawyers have been at work. If that dispute continues, obviously its final resolution will take place in the courts. On top of all this is the question whether industrial designs should be protected. The Attorney-General's Department takes the view that protection for commonplace manufactured articles could well hinder innovation in manufacturing. Industry, as I have said, would take the opposite view.

I have given the Senate a potted version of where we are in this matter. We intend to look at amendments in this area. However, it is a difficult area to consider, particularly when one looks at clauses 9 and 10. We could, for example, look at an amendment to clause 9, and consider other action on clause 10-possibly defeating it and referring it to a committee. At the end of the day we have decided not to do any of those things, for a number of reasons I shall deal with in the committee stage. I shall seek to move a second reading attachment which I shall deal with later.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is he aware that major banks have now been forced to raise both their prime lending rates and their overdraft rates to 18.75 per cent, representing an increase in the case of prime rates of 5.5 percentage points or 40 per cent over the past 12 months? Does he agree that overdrafts are the lifeblood of small businesses, including farming, and that this sort of escalation is forcing many to the verge of bankruptcy? What impact is the maintenance of this high interest rate regime likely to have on such businesses, which rely on bank overdrafts as a major source of their finance?

—I do not accept the terminology used in Senator Lewis's question, namely, that the banks have been forced to raise their interest rates, but I do accept that, for a variety of reasons, including excess demand in the economy, interest rates are high. Of course, no government has an interest in having interest rates as high as they are. Any government-any sensible government-will seek to have those--
—What sort of government?

—Sensible government. Such governments will seek to have interest rates down as soon as possible. I certainly agree that the high overdraft rate has an impact on small businesses but the impact is less, I think, than it might have been in the high interest rate regime a few years ago because of the capacity of the banking sector to make accommodations of one kind or another with businesses that they were not prepared to make in a regulated market and when there were very few major banks here. Apart from saying those things, I just repeat that of course the Government is concerned about high interest rates but we are also concerned about maintaining a steady growth in the economy and other things which are important to a vast majority of the people.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. It arises out of the statement of the Leader of the Government in the Senate that he denies the terminology that banks are `forced'. Does he deny that this Government is maintaining a policy of high interest rates?
—In so far as the Government has operated a tight monetary policy to try to reduce demand in the economy, no, I do not deny it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans. Can the Minister confirm that recently a Burmese student leader, Mr Min Ko Naing, has been arrested by the Burmese military government? If so, can the Minister indicate whether the Australian Government has made or will make representations to the Burmese Government for his immediate release? Further, can the Minister inform the Senate of what efforts have been made by the Australian Government to encourage the Burmese Government to establish a timetable for the holding of free and fair elections in Burma, which would lead to the establishment of parliamentary democracy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm the arrest by Burmese authorities on 23 March of Min Ko Naing, who is Chairman of the All Burma Students Union known as Bakatha, for alleged violations of the State Law and Order Restoration Council's orders and for planning to create disturbances on 27 March, which is the Burmese Armed Forces Day. Large numbers of other students are also understood to have been arrested around this time in Rangoon and Mandalay. The Australian Embassy in Rangoon has been instructed to make urgent representations seeking their release.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the larger political electoral environment, the Australian Government has been following political developments in Burma closely. We very much welcome the announcement by the Burmese authorities at the time of Senator Schacht's visit to that country of the timetable for holding general elections in April or May of 1990. We were prominent last August and September in calling on the Burmese authorities to accede to the widespread popular desire for democracy and political and economic reform. We are certainly convinced that holding free and fair elections is essential to resolving the crisis facing the country and opening the way for much needed national reconciliation and reconstruction. Clearly, the arrest of important student leaders such as Min Ko Naing and the continuing restrictions on freedom of speech and assembly in Burma can only set back the return to democracy. We nevertheless hope that the continued preparations for general elections will lead to early progress in establishing constitutional legal guarantees for the protection of human rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to statements by Senator Button in the Senate last Friday and also by the Treasurer in the House of Representatives yesterday that the current economic climate does not permit any easing of interest rates. Does the Minister agree with these assessments? Without expecting him to reveal any details of tonight's economic statement, I ask the Minister whether he can tell the Senate whether the overall impact of the statement will be to reduce or increase the upward pressure on interest rates?

—In regard to the first part of the question, I do not think anybody really knows what is going on right now in the economy because there is always a lag between the reality and the statistics which attempt to measure that reality. In regard to the second part of the question, I think Senator Stone had better wait until tomorrow.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a claim on page 15 in Time magazine of 20 March 1989 that, in relation to Australian aviation:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . cockpit fire extinguishers for one engine on a big twin-engine jet were known by the airline to be out of action for a month but nothing was done until the fault was discovered by surveyors.
What could be the consequences of these extinguishers being inoperative? Is the claim in Time correct? If so, what airline was involved and what were the circumstances surrounding the incident?

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to this matter I am advised that wiring problems were discovered in connection with fire extinguisher bottles in some Boeing 757, 767 and 747 aircraft overseas and some 737 aircraft in Australia.
