The faults discovered in Australian Boeing 737 engine fire bottle wiring have all been rectified. If there had been a fire in one engine of any of these Boeing 737 aircraft, the equipment, I am advised, would still have operated correctly and discharged one bottle into the correct engine. However, in the unlikely event of simultaneous fires in both engines, the effect would have been that one and a half bottles would have discharged into one engine and half a bottle into the other engine. The article in Time magazine to which Senator Colston refers appears to be referring to this problem but it incorrectly calls it a cockpit fire extinguisher for one engine. In fact, the faults were discovered in Australian aircraft by airline engineering staff acting on an authority airworthiness directive and not by authority airworthiness surveyors as is claimed in the article. May I say, finally, that this problem to which I have referred was not associated with the British Midlands crash. The cockpit warning systems in that aircraft have been cleared as a possible contributory factor in the accident. All Australian Boeing 737 cockpit warning systems have been checked and cleared.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations to the article titled `Willis answer at odds with advice' in the Canberra Times of 11 April. I ask: Is it the case that accepted legal opinion, under section 60 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904, maintains that an industrial award may be reviewed at any time if it was not correct in law at the time when it was handed down? If this is the case, can the Minister explain why, in answer to a question from Senator Jenkins last year, the former Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Ralph Willis, MP, replied that it was not the case? Does the Minister accept that Mr Willis's answer was in any way incorrect or misleading?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sanders was kind enough to give me some notice of this question, so I am able to provide a reply. In respect of the first part of the question, section 60 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 provided, in effect, that a Federal award was final and conclusive as well as being incapable of being challenged in a court. It is correct to say, however, that the High Court has held that such a clause does not prevent an application for judicial review where lack of jurisdiction is alleged against the decision-making body. I think it is true to say that that has happened quite a lot in the conciliation and arbitration jurisdiction. Accordingly, the High Court has been able to grant prerogative writs against members of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Industrial Relations Act 1988 has replaced the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Section 150 of the new Act corresponds with section 60 of the repealed Act.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the second part of the question, it is not correct to say that the former Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, denied this proposition in his answer to Question No. 397. That was the proposition that I answered in the first part of this question. Mr Willis, the Minister, was asked whether he would re-open certain award hearings. He replied correctly that he did not have power to re-open award hearings. His answer explained how, under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, the process for the Minister seeking a review of an award as of right operated. Neither the Minister's answer nor the question related to a legal challenge to the validity of the award, which is a matter I dealt with in the first part of the answer, namely, the High Court's role in that respect. The answer to the third part of the question whether Mr Willis's answer was incorrect or misleading is no.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister believe that justice has been done in this case?

—I usually assume so. I was asked to answer a question not about the specific facts of a case but about a Minister's answer as to the application of the law. That is what I did. If Senator Sanders wants a detailed answer as to the application of the law to the facts, I will seek to obtain it for him but I cannot provide it now.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SENIOR EXECUTIVES OF PUBLIC COMPANIES: PAY PACKAGES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance as Minister representing the Treasurer and relates to the pay packages of senior executives of public companies in Australia. I ask: Is it a fact that the Government's wages policies are not assisted when senior executives openly award themselves pay increases which are grossly in excess of wage increases authorised through the Australian conciliation and arbitration tribunals for ordinary Australian wage and salary earners? Is the situation any better when senior executives covertly award themselves large wage increases via techniques such as executive share incentive schemes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to both questions is yes. The achievement of a satisfactory wages income is certainly not assisted, indeed is sabotaged, if senior executives either overtly or covertly award themselves salary or payments increases vastly in excess of those which the work force in general is obtaining.

ANSWER.PARA: The second question relating to covert increases was raised last Monday by Mr Justice Dawson of the High Court at a business lawyers conference in Melbourne. According to a report on covert salary increases in yesterday's Age, Justice Dawson stated:

Another example of questionable behaviour which went unchecked and unheeded was that of executives of large public companies becoming `enriched to quite an extraordinary extent at what can ultimately only be at the expense of the shareholders.
Justice Dawson was reported as saying:
. . . even if a general meeting approved, this safeguard was illusory as shareholders were unable or unwilling to organise themselves as an effective voice, even if with a majority of votes.
Again, he was quoted as saying:

Moreover, if the company concerned is making large profits, shareholders will often fail to perceive that in achieving these results, the executives are doing no more than performing their proper function . . .

One of the worst offenders at enriching himself at the expense of the shareholders of a company is Mr Elliott of Elders IXL Ltd and President of the Liberal Party of Australia who, of course, has ruthlessly exploited 1c paid executive incentive shares.

One of the rorts that he pulled was described in some detail by Mr Terry McCrann in the Age of 15 April 1986. The McCrann article concerned the abuse of the total remuneration of executives by way of reverse takeovers. The more recent rort that Mr Elliott has been engaging in concerns the 1c bonus share issue. Having made a one-for-four bonus issue in March 1988. Elders announced a further one-for-five bonus issue on 28 September 1988.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It should not go unnoticed that the purpose of all the heckling and yahooing from the other side is to conceal from the public the knowledge of the lurks that the Federal President of the Liberal Party gets up to and the way in which he diddles both his own shareholders and the taxpayers. The 28 September fiddle was reported by the Australian Financial Review the next day. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: It certainly pays to own contributing shares these days-particularly if they are in Elders IXL. Unlike other holders of partly paid shares who have to pay the calls before they get such rewards as bonuses, the lucky contrib holders, some of whom are directors-
and one of whom is a chief executive-
took part in the generous one-for-five bonus announced yesterday.

Put in more simple language, the basis of this rort is that directors award themselves partly paid shares paid to 1c and then, the next year or even the next month, participate in a bonus issue along with all the other shareholders who do not have control of the company who have fully paid up shares. So they get, in a very short period, in return for their `investment of 1c' a multiple of that 1c of several hundred per cent. That is the rort that Mr Elliott pulls and those opposite, by way of their raucous babble, are trying to cover up.

On 27 September 1988, Mr Elliott held 15 and three-quarter million 1c contributory shares in Elders. In spite of that, he and his mates in the Liberal Party have the nerve to complain that ordinary wage earners want to get some wage increases. In my view, it is high time that the large institutional investors in Australia, principally the superannuation funds, took a closer look at executive share incentive schemes and Mr Justice Dawson's comments about them last Monday.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to a letter of 11 April and attachment entitled `A response to the Auditor-General's special audit report of March 1989', which the Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) sent to the Auditor-General commenting on the Auditor's report on the ADC. In particular, I refer to the ADC's statement at page 27:

QUESTION.PARA: The Attorney-General's Department disagreed only with some aspects of Mr Adams' numerous advices. However, on the majority of issues the Department found the Audit Office to be wrong. The Attorney-General's opinion was that only two business enterprises had been funded without authority.

Will the Minister table the ADC Chairman's letter and attachment? Will the Government now table all relevant correspondence between the ADC, the Auditor-General and the Attorney-General Department so that the Senate can judge the correctness of the ADC's very important claim?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will attempt to provide for the Senate the particular letter accompanying a response from the Aboriginal Development Commission to the special audit report. I believe that that would be a proper document to table for the interest and edification and enlightenment of honourable senators. It is best to have both sides of the argument available. I think it is proper to make that available, and I will seek the concurrence of the ADC in doing that. As honourable senators know, it is not under ministerial direction of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Nevertheless, I will seek to obtain that from the Aboriginal Development Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of the putting down of opinions, basically obtained by the Auditor-General or by the Aboriginal Development Commission, either from private counsel or from the Attorney-General, those are matters which I would have to consider more carefully. Quite clearly, I cannot give an undertaking as the opinions were not provided to me: I am not the client. That would require some consideration. I believe that the Senate will, if it obtains the response from the ADC to the auditor's report, be in a better position to understand the comprehensive nature of the review that was undertaken into the operations of the ADC. For that reason, I will certainly seek it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the importance of the Senate Estimates committees that will be considering the matter of Aboriginal affairs on Thursday and Friday this week, will the Minister seek to obtain both the letter and attachment and the various correspondence, which I appreciate he does have some reservation about, in the next few days so that it can be properly considered by the Senate Estimates committees?
—Yes.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Is the Minister aware of claims that have been made in the community that the cost of lost agricultural production each year is in the order of $600m? Is he also aware that soil conservation is being seen as the No. 1 environmental threat and that community based groups are being seen as the answer to this problem? Has the Minister seen the article in the Goulburn Post of 7 April 1989? I am sure that he has. In that article, Jock Douglas, the President of the Cattle Council of Australia, praises the concept of land care groups and calls on the Federal Government to back the proposals of the Australian Conservation Foundation and the National Farmers Federation to establish these community based groups? Can the Minister advise the Senate of this Government's attitude towards land care and the issue of land degradation in general?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to answer the people who are trying to interject because I believe there is substantial bipartisanship in Australia over the problem of land degradation.
—You have just woken up.

—It is not a matter of just having woken up; it is a matter of trying to get a cooperative basis on which to address a significant national problem. I have been asked whether I realise that lost agricultural production valued at $600m a year is caused by land degradation or soil conservation. I am aware of that, and the Senate may be interested to know that that is the approximate value of our total sugar exports, three times the value of our total fruit exports, and slightly more than the value of our total dairy product exports. So, put in terms of lost production to the economy, it is a significant problem.

ANSWER.PARA: If I can give another example to illustrate graphically the dimensions of the problem, on average about 90 million tonnes of soil are moved by soil erosion every year in this country. That is about enough to fill Sydney Harbour in just over two years-simply by simple water erosion. There are many other examples of the dimension of the problem that can be referred to, but those two graphic examples indicate that the issue of conservation and the environment is a national priority. It is not an issue that necessarily attracts as much public attention as it should. Other issues of conflict over environment or conservation seem to attract that attention. Nonetheless, it is important that we develop a bipartisan and powerful approach to addressing the issue, and the next part of the question was about that.

As it turns out, I have seen the article by Jock Douglas in the Goulburn Post of 7 April. I agree strongly with the points he makes. Indeed, the points he makes are made by a unique political combination in this country that has never been formed before. That combination is the ministerial task force that serves me, comprising the head of the Australian Conservation Foundation, Philip Toyne, and the head of the National Farmers Federation, Rick Farley. He is overseas at the moment; at his last meeting he was substituted. Both those people, representing quite different poles of the political spectrum, are united in their approach of establishing land care groups around Australia so that the land-holders can generate public support and peer group pressure in their own regions and catchments to work on the problem of land degradation.

What is the Government doing about it? On 20 April I will participate in a national television hook-up with the Minister for Primary Industries in Queensland, Neville Harper; the Minister for Agriculture and Rural Affairs in New South Wales, the Hon. Ian Armstrong; the Minister for Conservation, Forests and Roads in Victoria, Kay Setches; the Minister of Primary Industry in Tasmania, Nick Evers; the Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries in South Australia, Kym Mayes; the Minister for Water Resources in Western Australia, Ernie Bridge; and Daryl Manzie's nominee from the Northern Territory, Matty Urvet. That hook-up will launch the guidelines for the national soil conservation program for this year and announce the details of the community land care support program of that group, and also sign the Australian soil conservation strategy for the nation. This will be a quite emblematic bipartisan endorsement of a strategy to deal with what is, after all, as Senator Aulich said in his question, a major national ecological and environmental issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware of the current trade and border dispute between India and the landlocked country of Nepal, that India has closed almost every trade post on the India-Nepal border, and that this action by India has resulted in a drastic shortage of food and fuel which has led to civil unrest in Nepal? Has the action of the Indian Government severely disrupted Australia's and other countries' aid programs to Nepal? Is the action of the Indian Government in breach of international law, which requires a corridor of access to be provided to landlocked nations such as Nepal? What action, if any, will the Australian Government take in response to the conduct of the Indian Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that a problem has arisen between India and Nepal over the renewal of trade and transit agreements between the two countries. The previous agreements have now expired and Nepal is experiencing very considerable difficulties in importing and exporting goods, including essential commodities. We have had reports of demonstrations and unrest in Katmandu.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of trade and transit agreements is a bilateral one for the two governments directly concerned to address. All I can really say at this stage is that we hope the problem can be quickly and fairly resolved, particularly bearing in mind that Nepal is a landlocked, developing country and, as such, has a very fragile and vulnerable economy. We are taking steps to ensure that Australian travellers intending to go to Nepal are advised of the current situation there. I will continue to monitor the situation. If any more robust response from Australia is appropriate at some later stage, we will act accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to comments made last Monday by the Chairman of the Australian National Gallery, Mr Gough Whitlam, to the effect that the Department of Finance had used `favoured leaks' to give an impression of extravagance and waste by the Gallery. Is the Minister's Department out to avenge failed past attempts to impose Budget cuts on the Gallery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes, when one publishes a few facts, one seems to hit a few targets that were not aimed for. For example, in 1987, at the invitation of Mr Stone, as he then was I spoke to the H. R. Nicholls Society in Queensland and pointed out a few of the old rorts practised there. During questions afterwards, all sorts of people jumped up to defend themselves against accusations that were not in fact made. Something similar appears to have happened a couple of days ago. My Department seems to have borne the brunt of the decision by the Chairman of the National Gallery to smite the philistines, as he would see it. The Department of Finance has published a factual document and asked some questions arising from that document. That has happened a number of times before. I have never attempted to interfere with what the Department puts in those documents. They do not necessarily suggest a policy direction which I would support, although sometimes they do. I do not intend to stipulate which is which at this stage.

ANSWER.PARA: The discussion paper in question has been sent to museums and libraries. One was sent to the Director of the National Gallery last Wednesday and I sent a copy to the Chairman on Monday of this week, following a written request by him to make one available. Further copies are available from either the Department or my office. As Mr Whitlam said, it is true that the figures are somewhat out of date because most of the figures were put together when the survey was done in 1986. I understand that Jack Thompson, the actor, is looking for private sector support for the proposed National Museum of Australia. I commend that initiative by Mr Thompson. I hope he can find a number of people who are willing to contribute to that and, if he is willing, I suggest that he might associate himself with other appeals for voluntary donations from the public for these sorts of institutions, instead of their resorting, as they usually do, to the usual lazy practice of trying to touch the Commonwealth Budget.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to the answer he gave Senator Walters on 10 April regarding his discussions with the Wesley Vale joint partners, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: On 11 July last year the Commonwealth met with the company and told it what we expected.
Will the Minister now tell the Senate what it is that he told the companies he would expect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to give some examples of what was said. I cannot encapsulate the lot in the few moments available to me.
—Speak up. Are you afraid of being heard?
—It is very hard to be heard above Senator Newman. She never keeps quiet; she interjects all through Question Time. Nonetheless, I will manage.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Obviously the microphone was not working.

—There were discussions held on 11 July last year. That was only one of the discussions; I do not want to give the impression that it was the only discussion. As an example, on that occasion the Commonwealth informed the company of the need for baseline studies; that, as a minimum requirement for Commonwealth agreement to this proposal, there would need to be baseline studies of receiving environments. We would need to know what the hydrographics of the region were; we would also need to know what would occur when smoke went out the stack-where it would blow and how often the prevailing winds were blowing, et cetera. Those baseline studies were a requirement then. When I answered Senator Walters's question, Senator Puplick may recall that I referred to a letter sent in December which listed 85 points about which the environmental impact statement had either not addressed issues at all or inadequately addressed them. That was an agreed letter between the Tasmanian Environmental Department and my own Department. In that letter, those baseline studies were again referred to and they were again knocked back. Clearly, the company managed to ignore for six months what the Commonwealth had required and even, at the time, what the State had required. That was the first time that we saw the breakdown in process.

—I ask the Minister a supplementary question arising from his answer. Firstly, is he prepared to make available to the Senate details of the points which he put to the company on 11 July last year, to which he referred in his answer? Secondly, did the Commonwealth at any stage request that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Division of Oceanography in Hobart provide the Commonwealth with any of the hydrographic studies which were available to it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the last part of the question first. I would have to check dates, but certainly my Department attempted to find out from the CSIRO what information was available for a baseline study of Bass Strait. My recollection is that the answer was that while there was some information available, there was nothing like what we would require as a baseline study for these purposes. That was the information we received from CSIRO at that time. A number of divisions within the CSIRO needed to be consulted about that. I think Senator Puplick correctly named one of them. As far as the rest of the question is concerned, I will endeavour to find out what was presented to the company on 11 July. If it adds anything to the answer that I have given, I will be happy to provide it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINING IN NATIONAL PARKS: AUSTRALIAN LABOR PARTY POLICY

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories assure the people of Australia that, consistent with his statements in the Senate on 5 November 1987, he is fully committed to the Australian Labor Party (ALP) policy which opposes mining or any other activity in national parks which adversely affects the prime function of those parks-that is, nature conservation? If not, can he support his conversion to an alternative point of view? If so, can the Minister give a commitment that, in the event of the ALP's uranium policy review resulting in a relaxation of current restrictions which would allow uranium mining in Western Australia, he will oppose mining for uranium or any other mineral in Rudall River National Park and that he will oppose any manipulation of current park boundaries which would allow uranium mining to proceed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Like all members of my Party, I am committed to party policy. The ALP platform makes it quite clear that we are opposed to any activity in national parks which would detract from nature conservation. Obviously, as Senator Vallentine and other honourable senators would be aware, that does not mean that on every occasion we have precluded any activity. There are examples in World Heritage areas of where mining has been permitted, and there are examples where the prospect of tourism has been mooted and expressions of interest called for, but only when we have been satisfied that nature conservation in the area concerned would not be upset.
—Your policy is contradictory.

—Our policy is not contradictory. In terms of looking at what might happen following a review of Labor policy, I do not think there is any point in me, or anyone else here, commenting on what the likely outcome of a review might be. I have no idea what it might be. I am not a party to that review. I have made my views known to it, but beyond that I have no role to play. As to whether I would worry about the boundaries of national parks, I have no power whatsoever, as I am sure the honourable senator is aware, over boundaries of national parks in the States. My views on them would not be sought by any State. However, I will always oppose mining in national parks, be it Rudall River or anywhere else.

—I direct my question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Why has ministerial responsibility for the Government's costly taxpayer funded unit, the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS), been transferred to the Minister as from 6 February 1989? Which part of his portfolio does he consider the NMLS falls within-arts, sport, environment, tourism or territories? Why was there no public announcement of the transfer to the Minister from the Minister for Administrative Services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether the operative date was 6 February for the transfer to which the honourable senator referred, but I will assume that it is correct. The reality is that the National Media Liaison Service previously had resided in my Department when John Brown was the Minister, and the Prime Minister felt it appropriate to put it back there. It was a simple administrative arrangement and, I would have thought, not worthy of a public announcement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask how the Minister's answer and this transfer of responsibility fits with the statement by Senator Robert Ray on 19 October last year in Estimates Committee E, in response to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald that the NMLS would be transferred to Senator Richardson, that:

QUESTION.PARA: Why should it happen? I cannot verify every ratbag report that appears in the Sydney Morning Herald.
and that:

But it has not been the intention of government to do it: it was always intended to go, with the rest of Home Affairs, into the Department of Administrative Services . . . under the ministerial direction of Minister West.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Whatever Senator Ray would have said five months before the Prime Minister made a decision would have been relevant at the time he said it. It is up to the Prime Minister to determine appropriate administrative arrangements within the Government. If I had been asked the same question in October, I would have given the same answer. The Prime Minister changed his mind later on, as he is entitled to do, and I welcome his change of mind.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Resources. The Minister has announced that the Government will bring forward a review of the crude oil excise. What will be the terms of this review? Does this mean that the Government will renounce its secondary tax regime? Has the Government got a view of what the outcome might be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I addressed the annual Australian Petroleum Exploration Association (APEA) conference being held in Hobart and announced that the Government would honour the undertaking given by Senator Gareth Evans in June 1987 to conduct a full-scale review of excise levies on oil producers in this country. I announced that we would bring forward that review, to commence it in September this year, and would aim to conclude it in March 1990, that is, in effect, bringing it forward by about nine months from the original date prophesied in 1987 by Senator Evans. The terms of reference of the review, the timetable in which we propose to conduct the review, what the procedures will be, and what the arrangements will be to consult with petroleum organisations, consumers, State governments and others who have an interest in this matter, will be announced in detail by me next month.

ANSWER.PARA: The matter of secondary taxation is an important question because in my speech yesterday I was keen to make the point to the APEA that this Government considers that the Australian community is entitled to an economic rent, that is, a financial return for leasing off to private companies the right to produce oil-a rare and diminishing commodity-from our continental shelf. That economic rent, which is referred to as secondary taxation, must remain as a component of our package. The Australian community has a right to exploit that resource. I am pleased to see that in today's press comments Keith Orchison, the Executive Director of the APEA, recognises that point in responding to the announcement that I made at the conference yesterday.

I have also said to the APEA that the general criteria that will apply in conducting this review are the criteria and principles that have been announced from time to time by the Treasurer, setting out what this country requires as a fair and equitable taxation system and an effective taxation system. So it is within that context that the review will be conducted. All issues, as far as we are concerned, are on the table. The scope of the review will be a bit wider than originally envisaged by Senator Evans, because the industry has come up with a number of issues which concern the possibility of wider deductability against their tax payments on both resource rental tax and on excise. We will consider what proposals the industry has for wider deductability.

I have taken up with the Treasurer, as promised, the question of what tax provisions will apply for the removal of oil platforms. The Senate might know that when producing platforms in Bass Strait finish their productive life, they are required to be removed so that they do not constitute a navigational hazard. There are international conventions to which this Government is party which require them to be removed to a certain depth in the water so that they do not constitute that type of hazard. There is the question of the tax treatment of that type of removal, which the producers have raised with me and which I am pursuing. As I have said to the producers, I will try to deal with all those outstanding matters in this review so that we can wrap up these questions in one fell swoop in March, or about that time, next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I refer to the new points system for migrant selection announced by the Minister last Friday. Why is it proposed, despite the clear advice of the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies and other sound findings, that the language skills factor will not apply to the concessional family category of applicants but only to the independent migrant category? Will the Government reconsider this so that this factor applies to both? If not, will the Minister confirm that this aspect of the system will be in regulatory form disallowable by Parliament? Why is the settlement factor for family migration restricted to one characteristic only, and that is whether the sponsor has had two recent years of continuous employment? Finally, will the Minister explain the location factor that has been announced and how a designated area will be determined from time to time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —In considering a new points system there was one major feature, and that was having a separate points system for `extended family'-that is, a concessional area-and for `independent'. The application or the non-application of the English language test to the concessional area was based on the fact that we would be regarded as being grossly discriminatory in different regions of the world. It would have clearly been seen, if it were instituted, as favouring certain countries and not others. Maybe that will change in the long term. But there is no doubt that in certain regions of the world English is not a second language and in other parts of the world it is. I think it would have been quite discriminatory to do so. I do not regard it as such in the independent area which is more one of dog eat dog and with the best person emerging. As Senator Teague would know, there are costs associated with that. A higher burden is put on the adult migration education program. Trying to get a balanced immigration program that would not be seen as discriminatory was regarded as a sustainable cost.

ANSWER.PARA: The various criteria need not be put in regulation for a points test but they almost certainly will. Yes, it will be disallowable by Parliament. However, I think it is not essential to have that sort of points test included in regulation. For the moment I tend to think that is the route we should go by because the more objective one makes those criteria the more available it is to the public by regulation and, therefore, any appeal system can flow properly from it. The honourable senator asked why the employment status of sponsors has been put in to the exclusion of something else. I do not know what else the honourable senator is referring to. I do not know what other factors might be taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any other settlement criteria.

—I do not know the other settlement criteria that the honourable senator is referring to. In this case, however, one of the great arguments for extended family migration to Australia is that, on arrival, relatives will give sustainable support. It is very hard to argue that they will be in a position to do so if they have been on social security, et cetera.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no question-and I think that Senator Teague would agree-that there is an ethos in a lot of families that if they are working they make sure that the people who come out here get jobs. It is a matter of trying to get that interlinking. The point score is not necessarily the most crucial thing. I do not think 10 points will make or break in most cases. Obviously, the number of points that one scores in the skills area, when one gets up to 75 points, is the important thing. These points will make a slight difference in the case of people who are running neck and neck to the line.

The honourable senator asked me, thirdly, about the location factor. We have left it to the States to designate areas which they consider to be an appropriate location. The logic in this is that it does not force migrants to go to any particular area of Australia. I think the honourable senator will concede that there is a great likelihood that migrants will go to areas where their sponsors live. There is heaps of evidence in respect of chain migration to that effect. What we are really saying is, having taken all of these points into account, if it is a dead heat, let us make the choice in favour of those people who want to go to an area where there is less infrastructural pressure.

We have asked the States to designate areas. New South Wales has not designated any, neither has Victoria. Queensland has designated all areas in Queensland other than the Gold Coast, Brisbane, the Sunshine Coast and far western Queensland. South Australia, Northern Territory and Tasmania have designated their whole area for the location factor. I believe that Western Australia has nominated the Pilbara and one other area, I think, in the south-west as designated areas. That is a five-point position. One could virtually say that if there is a draw between someone going to Melbourne and someone going to northern Queensland, northern Queensland would then get the edge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade provide the Senate with an update of the Namibian situation and the role being played by Australian forces in current developments?
—This is the second Dorothy Dixer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would hope that the Senate is interested in this matter. It is one which has been greatly exercising a number of countries and, of course, there are questions of real significance for Australian forces involved over there. I want to say that in the light of the developments of the last few days, I am encouraged by what has been occurring, at least in so far as it has brought a halt to the senseless killing in Namibia, although there are some uncertainties in the situation which still remain. Acting on advice that the South West African People's Organisation (SWAPO) would be prepared to move to bases in Angola, members of the Namibian Joint Monitoring Commission (JMC)-that is to say, Angola, Cuba and South Africa-together with observers from the United States of America and the Soviet Union, met at Mount Etjo outside Windhoek on 9 April and, in a statement which is referred to as the Mount Etjo declaration, called on SWAPO insurgents to gather at designated assembly points in Namibia under the supervision of the United Nations Transition Assistance Group (UNTAG) and to lay down their arms and be transported to bases in Angola north of the sixteenth parallel between 11 and 21 April.

ANSWER.PARA: A response from SWAPO leader Nujoma on the terms of that declaration, in particular the request to withdraw beyond the sixteenth parallel, is still awaited, although there are press reports that SWAPO is expressing, out of its office in Luanda, uncertainties about the alleged ambiguity in some aspects of that declaration which is inhibiting the present response. It is simply not possible to assess whether ceasefire arrangements are effectively in force and holding until SWAPO forces begin gathering at their assembly points. In the meantime, South Africa has decided to continue deployment of its forces. Despite the absence of an agreed ceasefire, UNTAG is continuing with its preparations to deploy forces to establish assembly points in northern Namibia to receive the withdrawing SWAPO guerillas.

The situation so far as the use of Australian troops is concerned is that UNTAG headquarters has decided now to use elements of the Australian-British contingents to set up the assembly points in question. About 60 Australian UNTAG members are involved. The deployment to Namibia of other contingents of UNTAG is proceeding as scheduled and the main body of the rest of the Australians is expected to leave here between 13 and 16 April.

I just simply want to make the point finally, as I have so often, that it would be a tragedy for all concerned if fresh difficulties were now to arise to derail Namibia from the track to elections in November and to full independence thereafter. We certainly hope that the remaining difficulties that are apparently being experienced in bedding down a SWAPO response to the latest peace proposals and arrangements will be quickly resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. When is the Minister going to clean up that unholy mess with air traffic controllers that policies of his Government have created?
—Start on what is unholy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not describe it as an unholy mess. It is a considerable mess. I do think it is a little inappropriate for Senator MacGibbon to intrude religion into what is a situation that is already complicated enough. The situation, I am currently advised, in relation to the air traffic controllers' problems is as follows: despite an order issued by the Industrial Relations Commission (IRC) on Monday, it is the case that the air traffic controllers (ATCs) continued their overtime bans at Sydney Airport. Yesterday afternoon Commissioner Sheather inserted a stand-down clause in the air traffic controllers' award. This enables ATCs who take industrial action and who cannot be usefully employed as a result of industrial action to be stood down.

ANSWER.PARA: Last night the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) stood down one controller who refused to work overtime to replace an absent colleague. Further stand-downs are likely to occur today should other staff refuse to work in accordance with the IRC's order and the award. If stand-down orders do take effect, as expected, there will be progressive close-downs of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, as have occurred in the past.

The inconvenience to the travelling public is obviously regretted, but the Government's position is that the action at Sydney Airport had reached the stage where this was occurring in any case. The CAA considered that a firm response to the air traffic controllers' action was necessary. It took action accordingly and the Government supports that action.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer to the public concern in respect of the, perhaps I should say, unholy delay in determining the outcome of the Australian Capital Territory election. Can the Minister provide some explanation for this apparently inexcusable delay and inform us of any proposals that might overcome this delay in future elections?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe we could get the air traffic controllers to count the votes. I think essentially the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) has been following a play safe policy-that is, to be very careful in counting the votes because if it does make mistakes and a recount is demanded eventually the amount of time would be doubled before a government could be installed in the Australian Capital Territory. I also remind the honourable senator that the last New South Wales Senate election took two months to count, as he probably realised at the time. It was quite a long while.
—It was a good result.

—The same amount of defective candidates, I would suggest. It took two months to count with about 40 candidates and a more simple system. I think that is the problem. The Electoral Commission was left with a very complex system. I think there were 117 candidates on a ballot paper which goes on forever. The Electoral Commission did inform the Australian Capital Territory portfolio here before the election that it would take a couple of months to count. I understand that preferences begin to be allocated on 17 April. That is a six-stage process. I am happy to table the six stages the Commission has to go through, but I am not happy to read them out.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is one of those cases where the voting system, in theory and in concept, does cause a lot of problems in translation. A lot of people who are experts on this or that electoral system to advantage this or that group--

TALK.START.PARA: —They have not reached the difficult bit.

—Foghorn Leg-horn continues to interject. She even voted for this system but she is bleating away at the back. Maybe Senator Walters would like to go down there for the next week and help them count. Why does she not go down and scrutineer? The only trouble is that all the AEC staff members would go out on invalidity. Now back to the main game.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the difficulty is that if the Electoral Commission does get it wrong, there has to be a recount. I say this just as an editorial to Senator McMullan and everyone else: obviously it is not satisfactory that it takes two months to count any ballot, especially as elections are only three years apart. It is two years and 10 months to the next election when the members are first installed. It will be necessary to look at the system. Quite frankly, whilst I do not wish it on them, I think in the long term there is a case for the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Matters to look into the system in the cool light of day, to see what modifications and improvements can be made. I table the document.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a question relating to the provision of oxygen to residents of nursing homes. The Minister for Housing and Aged Care has provided me with an answer to that question. It is a fairly detailed answer and, rather than read it out, it might be sensible for me to seek to incorporate it in Hansard and hand the copy of the answer to the honourable senator.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
Aged and other persons requiring oxygen may receive the service free of charge in hospitals or their own home.

Under the Government's nursing home financial arrangements the supply of oxygen to residents for emergency, intermittent or infrequent episodic purposes is provided as part of nursing home care and covered by the approved fee for the nursing home at no extra charge to the resident.
However, in cases where residents require substantial and sustained use of oxygen, the nursing home may separately charge the residents where:
(i) the approved fee of the nursing home does not include the cost of oxygen for sustained use, and
(ii) the oxygen was supplied to a resident admitted after 1 July 1987.

Where the cost of providing oxygen for sustained use was included in the approved budget for a home determined prior to 1 July 1987, the policy is that these costs would continue to be met by the home for existing residents, from the approved fees determined on 1 July.

The approved fee for a nursing home is designed to enable homes to provide full nursing home care and accommodation for residents. That is, board and accommodation and the provision of care in accordance with the quality of care standards.
The approved fee does not cover certain items, such as pharmaceuticals prescribed by a doctor for an individual resident nor personal items requested by the resident.

However, the intention is to review the arrangements concerning the provision of oxygen to nursing home residents. Such a review will need to be conducted in consultation with nursing home industry representatives to determine the incidence of sustained use by nursing home residents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to my reply to Senator Crowley's question of 5 April concerning the case of the Czechoslovak dissident Peter Cibulka, the Australian Embassy in Warsaw, which is accredited to Czechoslovakia, has today confirmed that Mr Cibulka has been detained without trial since being arrested in October 1988. It is a matter for concern that Mr Cibulka's human rights have been violated in this way. His case is further evidence of the deterioration of the human rights situation in Czechoslovakia over the past six months against a background of social protest and expression of independent views. As I foreshadowed in my reply to Senator Crowley last week, the Australian Government will be expressing to the Czechoslovak authorities its concern about Mr Cibulka's case and those of other detainees, and instructions have gone today to our Warsaw Embassy to that effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, yesterday in the House of Representatives the honourable member for the Northern Territory, Mr Snowdon, in the debate on the administration of Aboriginal affairs, when referring to me, said at pages 1347 and 1348 of Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: He said that he has consulted with Aboriginal people and that he reflects their views. Let me tell honourable members that nothing could be further from the truth.
He continued:
He knows that his views are not the views of Aboriginal people and he knows that the views that he expresses are those of a minority group within the Australian community.

I would like to make it very clear that I do represent the entire constituency of the Northern Territory, which includes some 35,000 traditional Aboriginal people. The statement by Mr Snowdon is false and is an insult to the intelligence of the electorate that both he and I represent. If he had regard to my diary, which is quite public in the newspapers, he would well know that I consult very widely with Aboriginal people throughout the Northern Territory and that I do reflect their views.
The second issue I wish to raise came about in the same debate. At page 1352 the honourable member for Leichhardt, Mr Gayler said that I had written:

We have heard about this new proposal for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commissioner. We went to see Mr Hand and Yuendumu but he was gone. He only stay a short time. That no good. He should stay longer and listen to each group and not just visit big communities.

There was a meeting at Three Bore near Utopia. We heard Alan Randall talk about ATSIC. We heard about those new zones, voting for the Commission and all those things. We had a big talk about it between ourselves when we came home. We are not happy with ATSIC.
Other mobs we talk to are not happy with ATSIC either. All over Napperby, Alyawarra, Utopia outstations, we don't like to mix everyone up in one big council.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Tambling is obviously entitled to make a personal explanation, but not to use that as an occasion for putting into the record what is obviously a contribution to a substantive debate on this subject, and I ask that you bring him to order.

—Mr President, speaking to the point of order, given that Mr Gayler has said that I have written something, and it is referred to in the House of Representatives Hansard, I feel it is appropriate to also include it in the Senate Hansard. There is only one further paragraph that I would like to add and it is important to clarify the issue.

—On the point of order, I do not understand why Senator Evans is getting upset about this matter. After all, at this stage all Senator Tambling is doing is reading where he has been misquoted. Surely he is entitled to put that on the record.
—I call Senator Tambling.
—Quoting further from the letter:

SPEECH.PARA: We got map today from D.A.A. The map shows all those ATSIC regions in different colours.

Well now we got to tell you, we are not happy about ATSIC and we are not happy about that map. That map is wrong. You can't split our country up. You can't put us with all those other people from different country. That mob from south haven't got skin groups like us. You can't put us with them.
We are not happy with ATSIC and we don't want it.
We are going to talk more about this with our own people.

Mr Gayler contended, `Senator Tambling wrote the letter; I'll bet he did'. That is totally false and artificial. The letter was written by a member of the Anmatjara tribe of Central Australia, as was made very clear in the House of Representatives debate. The assertion by Mr Gayler is patronising to the genuine feelings of the tribe, the Anmatjara tribe, and only reflects the Australian Labor Party's attitude that Aboriginal people cannot think for themselves.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator WALTERS

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to ask you for clarification of a letter honourable senators received from the Clerk of the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Robert Ray-What is it about? You have not approached us on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I have had no notice of this. I do not know what letter you are referring to.
—It is a letter received from the Clerk about the Treasurer's economic statement and distribution of papers.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform the Senate that at 8.30 a.m. today Senators Puplick and Vallentine submitted letters in accordance with standing order 64, one proposing a matter of public importance, the other a matter of urgency. To decide which letter would be submitted to the Senate I determined the matter by ballot in the presence of the National Party Whip, a representative of Senator Vallentine and the Clerk of the Senate. In accordance with the result of that procedure I now read Senator Vallentine's letter:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Australian government to refuse to sign the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities (CRAMRA), and instead to promote the formulation of a comprehensive conservation convention for the Antarctic, based on the concept of an Antarctic World Park.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Australian government to refuse to sign the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities (CRAMRA), and instead to promote the formulation of a comprehensive conservation convention for the Antarctic, based on the concept of an Antarctic World Park.

I have deliberately kept the wording of this urgency motion straightforward in the hope of sticking to the substantive subject which is of concern to thousands of Australians and to the international community-that is, the future of Antarctic wilderness. The question that we need to ask is whether this area is to be retained for its beauty, its inspiration, and its scientific and biological values, or is it to be exploited in the great tradition of colonial territories everywhere else around the globe by those nations which are in the best position to conserve its multitude of environmental values.

Unlike most international fora, where Australia holds few trump cards to influence other nations in their environmental and development policies, Australia is one of the seven claimants to Antarctic territory, claiming some 43 per cent of the Antarctic continent. As a claimant nation we are in an enviable position to prevent mineral exploitation and other activities which threaten the fragile Antarctic wilderness. We have witnessed several timely reminders lately of just how dangerous it is to allow commercial imperatives to dictate inappropriate activities in the frigid environments of the Antarctic and Arctic regions. The Antarctic has already been described as the frontier of the global ecological crisis. It is in Antarctica that the first and most dramatic impacts of the ozone hole and the global warming from the greenhouse effect will be, and already have been, felt. Seventy per cent of the earth's fresh water is contained in Antarctica's ice and snow and it is now evident--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I simply ask you to enforce standing order 406-that senators shall not read their speech. Senator Vallentine does not have copious notes but a clearly prepared text which is being read into the record, as Senator Vallentine persists in doing. Standing order 406 is quite clear and I call on you to enforce it.

—Order! The senator shall not read her speech. She can only read from copious notes. There is a fair amount of give and take allowed but the standing order is quite clear-that senators shall not read their speeches.

—As I was saying, I think it is very important that we consider the water supplies that are part of Antarctica's heritage and which we should be preserving. As well as the 70 per cent of the earth's fresh water, we also know that Antarctica contains an invaluable record of the earth's climatic history and provides precious information on increases in atmospheric carbon dioxide and global pollutants such as DDT. The cold waters currently surrounding the Antarctic continent are responsible for absorbing a major proportion of atmospheric carbon dioxide-a major greenhouse gas, as I am sure the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, will appreciate. As the greenhouse effect escalates temperatures are expected to rise the fastest in Antarctica because any melting at the edge of the ice shelf will change the reflectivity of the surface exposed to sunlight. The increased ocean area will then absorb more of the sun's rays and magnify the warming trend.

SPEECH.PARA: Following a collective research effort carried out under the International Council of Scientific Unions in 1957-58, the International Geophysical Year, scientific cooperation was seen as a long term key to the Antarctic political sovereignty dilemma. The resulting 1959 Antarctic Treaty set the continent aside as a research preserve where nations freely exchange scientific results and personnel. The Treaty specifically bans military activities, nuclear explosions and the disposal of radioactive waste in the region. In other words, it is a zone of peace and learning. There is no better example anywhere in the international community of the kind of cooperation that we see existing in Antarctica. It is a case of scientists swapping information in Antarctica and learning to cooperate, particularly in extremely difficult climatic circumstances. It is a case of cooperating together or freezing separately.

Up to now the Antarctic land mass has been saved from exploitation by its harsh climate and lack of any framework for exploitation to take place. As a result, the area has remained unpolluted enough to act as an official international laboratory providing baseline data and allowing scientists to make discoveries which, among other things, have warned the human race that it is on the verge of causing its own destruction. The history of the Antarctic marine environment is much less inspiring. First the fur seals, then the whales, were driven to the edge of extinction through commercial slaughter. Now fish and the tiny crustaceans, krill-the foundation of the Antarctic food chain-remain under threat from overharvesting, despite the fishing convention established to prevent this from eventuating. In addition to commercial harvesting of Antarctic organisms is the impending loss of phytoplankton from intense solar radiation, unshielded by the ozone layer, and a type of algae thought to play a major role in cloud formation.

Tonnes of garbage, much of it non-degradable, is currently dumped overboard by ships carrying some 3,000 visitors a year. Meanwhile, the feasibility of a gigantic tourism resort complex is being investigated by Helmet Rhode and Partners for the Vestfold Hills, the most sensitive ice-free area of the Australian Territory. Refuse from more that 50 scientific research stations, all of which lack sanitation treatment facilities, is also despoiling the pristine Antarctic landscape.

On his return from a visit to Antarctica an American environmental defence fund lawyer, Bruce Manheim, described the waters surrounding the United States McMurdo base as having greater concentrations of cancer-causing polychlorinated biphenyls and heavy metals than virtually all the waterways in the United States. These toxins are now found in the tissues of Antarctic penguins and seals. The French base of Dumont-d' Urville, ostensibly established to study the Emperor penguins and other wildlife, has had the effect of reducing the breeding colony of Emperor penguins from 7,000 in 1982 to less than 3,000 today. Unfortunately, the purpose of the airstrip being built by the French is not to further the penguin studies but to service the activities of geologists, mining engineers and developers in their search for minerals beneath the ice. Incidentally, it is important to note that work on the airstrip began around the time the initial minerals convention was signed in June last year in New Zealand.

Other nations have been only too quick to jump on the band wagon. As soon as they thought the licence to go ahead with mineral exploitation of Antarctica was on the way, they stepped up their activities as well. Britain would be one of those countries which stepped up its Antarctic research efforts last year; the United States is building a new runway; and the Soviet Union and the United States have both already fitted skis to jumbo jets. The situation in Antarctica is changing quite dramatically and quite quickly since this possibility of mining was put on the international agenda following that meeting in New Zealand last June.

If we want any other warnings of the dangers of commercial mineral activities in frigid environments we need only refer to the massive 950,000 litre oil spill from the Argentinean supply vessel Bahia Paraiso near Palmerston Wildlife Research Base last January, which was followed by the catastrophic oil spill from the Exxon Valdez in Alaska this month. It has been almost impossible for America, even with its scientific expertise, to keep the lid on the position. In fact, the Americans have not been able to do so in any way at all. That has been a demonstration of the possibilities that would be more likely to occur if there were to be mining exploration, and then mining activity, in Antarctica. It would be extremely difficult to keep such accidents under control, and in the harsh and fragile environment of Antarctica there is no foreseeable accident the effect of which could be minimised, even with the most careful planning, because of the hostility of that natural environment.

Into this situation, which is undisputed by international scientists, politicians, conservationists and the majority of the Australian public, who are crying out for environmental protection for the region, emerges a convention to allow mineral exploitation of the Antarctic wilderness. (Quorum formed) Instead of promoting and formulating a convention to conserve the scientific, peace and wilderness values of Antarctica-what we need is a convention based on the concept of a cooperative Antarctic world park-we are debating the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities, or CRAMRA. Ironically, we have been told by Senator Gareth Evans that CRAMRA is about protecting the fragile environment of Antarctica and ensuring peaceful cooperation, as very little is known about the extent of mineral resources there. It could be argued that the logic of the minerals convention to achieve conservation in Antarctica is consistent with a conservation zone to achieve mining in Kakadu.

The more realistic reason for interest in Antarctica's practically inaccessible minerals is, or course, to entrench national territorial claims in Antarctica. According to yesterday's Canberra Times our own Minister for the Environment has confirmed that he is `absolutely' against any mining in Antarctica. He is also obviously concerned about development of inappropriate tourism there, as he has referred that issue for examination by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. Yet we are still talking about a minerals convention, instead of a conservation convention. It is difficult to conceive how any mineral activity, with its attendant airstrips, ports, tracks, accidents, oil leaks, waste disposal, housing, noise, air pollution and intrusion into wilderness, could pose `no significant adverse effect' when even scientific research bases are guilty of environmental impacts in Antarctica.

It is also difficult to see how a convention which is compliant with mineral exploitation in one of the most sensitive environments on earth will successfully achieve conservation objectives, when the existing Agreed Measures for the Protection of Antarctic Flora and Fauna are themselves violated by countries such as France in their bid to construct airstrips through Adelie penguin colonies. Neither has the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources of 1981 prevented the overfishing of certain species because, despite its basis on the concept of sustainable harvesting, the prescribed inspection system has never been implemented. The Australian public can be forgiven for being cynical that yet another convention based on exploitation of Antarctic resources will achieve conservation objectives. If a fishing one is not really working, why should we imagine that a mining convention will do the job? It is not a convention about monitoring mining. It is a go-ahead. The use of undefined terms such as `negligible', `substantial risk' and `significant changes' in reference to mineral exploitation in the proposed CRAMRA are especially dubious when the only feasible areas for mineral exploitation are along the coast, away from the icecap-the only habitat of terrestrial life in Antarctica. There would be a great interference in the small amount, 2 per cent of the land, which is not permanently icebound in respect of the habitat of species which most people in the world believe need to be preserved.

Finally, major flaws in CRAMRA totally undermine any confidence that people concerned for the environment of Antarctica may have had that this convention would prevent further degradation of the continent through regulation of inappropriate activities. These flaws are at least threefold. First, liability is limited as a country or company can escape financial responsibility for accidents or pollution if they occur as a result of war or conflict, sabotage or acts of aggression, and natural disasters `not reasonably foreseen'. That phrase in itself would cut out just about any accident that is likely to occur. What could one foresee in that difficult, complex and hostile environment of Antarctica?

The second flaw is that the sharing of scientific data, which has been a feature under the Antarctic Treaty, would likely become a thing of the past under CRAMRA. Much of the science conducted could be directed towards mineral activity and the data tied up under confidentiality provisions. Withheld data may contain information of environmental significance to the entire global community. Thirdly, Australia has administered the Australian Antarctic Territory for almost 30 years. In the past few years a high emphasis has been placed on environmental responsibility. If the convention goes ahead Australia will have no control over the territory that it lays claim to.

On this final point it is interesting to note that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, and the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) are opposed to the signing of CRAMRA, but I suspect for largely the wrong reasons. We would not be able to have control over the mineral resources in our specified area, and we would not be copping any financial rewards if large multinational companies were to be involved and engaged in the mining. They are the only ones who have any possibility of undertaking mining there because of the enormous expenses involved.

Australia and the other signatories have until 25 November 1989 to sign or not to sign this agreement. This is a real opportunity for Australia to respond, not only to national concern but to international concern that Antarctica be free of mining. The Government cannot pretend that a convention on mineral resource activities will stop mining occurring in Antarctica. It would be a go-ahead. What we would see in Antarctica would be akin to the grab for Africa in the 1890s-an unprecedented rush for the goodies of Antarctica. It would be a most adversarial framework, instead of what we see happening now, which is a positive example of international cooperation. Antarctica is the last continent relatively undeveloped and unpopulated by indigenous people. There is no controversy over violations of people's rights but plenty of sympathy for the violations of the penguins' rights. Much work has already been done by conservation organisations such as Greenpeace and the Australian Conservation Foundation to develop the concept of an internationally cooperative world park to conserve the wilderness and biological values of Antarctica with a ban on activities incompatible with the conservation objective.

The creation of an Antarctic world park would be consistent with the spirit of the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources, the Antarctic Treaty, the Antarctic Treaty Park proposed informally by Chile and the Antarctic Conservation Convention promoted by Australia at earlier consultative meetings. It is the only way that conservation objectives for the Antarctic wilderness can be met while ensuring that all activities taking place on the last great continent are compatible with wilderness and scientific research. I commend this urgency motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) and pursuant to contingent notice of motion, on his behalf I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) moving an amendment to the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Chaney I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after `urgency:', insert: `The need for the Australian Government to promote adequate public discussion of all of the issues arising in relation to whether or not Australia should become a signatory to the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities (CRAMRA).'.

The reason for moving the amendment to the motion which Senator Vallentine has put before the Senate today is twofold: firstly, that the Senate should not be asked to make a decision on the run about a fundamentally important question as to whether or not Australia should become a signatory to an important international convention and, secondly, because the motion of Senator Vallentine confuses two quite separate and distinct issues, namely, the convention itself and the question of the world park. The two issues are separate and are distinct. My amendment will cause the Senate to focus upon the question of the convention and Australia's attitude towards it.

I wish to turn first to the question of the world park and that part of Senator Vallentine's motion which I am seeking to amend. The Opposition is opposed to the concept of turning the Antarctic into a `world park'. We believe that this will effectively destroy the regime established under the Antarctic Treaty, a regime which we believe has served the international community, including perhaps especially Australia, particularly well in the course of some 30 years. I look, for example, at the report entitled The World Park Option for Antarctica-Background For A Fourth UN Debate, which was prepared by Greenpeace and which is dated 17 November 1986. In that document, in explaining its support for the world park concept, Greenpeace states:

Greenpeace and other members of the Antarctic and Southern Ocean Coalition (ASOC) used the term ``World Park'' to mean a status whether designated through new legal structures, existing international conventions or through evolution of the Antarctic Treaty itself, which would ensure that the natural environment of Antarctica is forever protected, free of the destruction wrought by humans on every other continent on earth.

While that may be an admirable and desirable objective, when one reads the rest of the documentation which is attached to this particular proposal, one can see a number of flaws which arise. Let me just draw attention to one or two of them. For example, Greenpeace in its document states:
Antarctica should remain a zone of limited scientific activity . . .
As to what `limited scientific activity' means, the document is quite silent. In the light of some of the comments that Senator Vallentine made it is interesting to look at page 11 of the document:
Tourism is not inconsistent with wilderness values so long as it is very carefully monitored and controlled. Some areas of special tourist interest should be set aside for this purpose.

In other words, even within the world park concept there are considerable degrees of confusion about how many scientific activities should take place, what sorts of scientific activities they should be, how much tourism should take place, whether there should be any tourism at all, whether it should be carefully controlled or, indeed, whether areas should be set aside for particular tourist activities. Frankly, from listening to Senator Vallentine's presentation today, one is left none the wiser as to precisely what it is that she and proponents of the world park concept mean by that particular terminology. One thing we can presume that they do mean is some sort of involvement by the United Nations in the operation, control and regulation of activities in the Antarctic. The Opposition parties are opposed to that. Let me spend a few moments talking about the involvement of the United Nations in the Antarctic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The honourable senator is speaking to an amendment. As I understand, we have not received copies of his suggested amendment so he is speaking to something we do not have in front of us. It seems rather peculiar that we cannot properly consider it unless we have that.
—Copies are available. The attendant is bringing you one.
—I cannot be held responsible for Senator Coulter's incompetence on this occasion-or, indeed, on any others. I was talking about the involvement--

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I object most vigorously to that remark. It is not a question of incompetence on my part if the attendant has not provided me with a copy. I came and sat in my place, and the papers which are normally here were not here. Senator Puplick has proceeded to speak to a paper which was not in front of me. I was not responsible for this. It is surely his responsibility to ensure that those papers are properly circulated.
—There is no point of order.

—I was talking about the question of the United Nations involvement with the Antarctic. I draw attention to the fact that, for example, in 1947, when this matter was first being considered by the then emergent United Nations organisation, certainly the United States through its State Department took a view that the United Nations should be involved in the administration of the Antarctic. Indeed, the State Department marked out a plan for a proposed international administration of Antarctica by the United States-not surprisingly-and seven other claimant nations. The proposal was for an eight-power trusteeship under the control of the United Nations. In 1956 the Prime Minister of New Zealand at the time, Mr Walter Nash, proposed the United Nations trusteeship and the establishment of the Antarctic as a world territory under United Nations control.

SPEECH.PARA: However, arising from the events of the International Geophysical Year from July 1957 to December 1958 it was decided that it would be better to proceed by way of the establishment of an international treaty. As a result, in 1959 the Antarctic Treaty was developed and was brought into operation. That treaty persisted without very much significant international comment until December 1982 when, at the time of the signing of the Law of the Sea Convention at Montego Bay in Jamaica, the Malaysian delegate, Ghazali Shafie, drew attention to what he claimed should be the next priority for the Third World. He said:
It is time now to focus our attention on another area of common interest . . . Antarctica where immense potentialities exist for the benefit of all mankind.

This matter was subsequently debated internationally. In November 1984 the United Nations Secretary-General himself caused to be published a paper entitled Study on the Question of Antarctica. That United Nations paper analysed the Antarctic Treaty system and demonstrated the benefits of that system. It says in part:

For nearly two and a half decades, Antarctica and its surrounding maritime areas have been free from militarisation of any kind, including nuclear weapons. No armed conflict has taken place in the area. Peace on the continent has been maintained to a large extent through the agreements embodied in the Antarctic Treaty. The Treaty has provided a frame-work for the parties to the Treaty to carry out peaceful activities related to scientific research, exploitation of marine resources and protection of the environment.
Elsewhere, the United Nations paper says:

It would appear that no major danger has so far occurred to the Antarctic eco-system. Human activities in Antarctica remain very limited . . . and are being carried out in accordance with the strict rules and regulations imposed on such activities by the Antarctic Treaty Consultative Parties.

In other words, the United Nations, in its own study, demonstrated the extent to which the Antarctic Treaty was the correct method by which we should proceed to bring about the protection of the Antarctic environment. The world park idea is, in my view, completely contrary to the maintenance of that regime.

I turn to one final point on this world park question.
