If one looks at a very instructive article entitled `Antarctica and the United Nations' by Sanjay Chaturvedi, the Senior Research Fellow at the Department of Political Science at the Punjab University at Chandigarh, which appeared in the India Quarterly at the beginning of 1986, one sees the points that he makes about the politicisation of the situation in the Antarctic. One of the points to which he draws attention is that if the United Nations is to become involved in the administration of the Antarctic and the world park concept in the Antarctic, one of the first things that will be on the agenda of the Third World nations is whether it will be possible to achieve-I quote from his paper-`the expulsion of South Africa' from the Antarctic Treaty system. That will have to be `one of the first steps in this direction'. In other words, changes that will have to be made if the world park concept, under United Nations auspices, is to go ahead will be the immediate politicisation along the lines of international political disputations of a situation which, at the moment, has avoided that. Even during the Falkland Islands dispute, the Antarctic Treaty system managed to keep Britain and Argentina talking and cooperating in the Antarctic while they were physically at war with each other only a few hundred kilometres away from the Antarctic waters. Any steps taken along this world park line will inevitably lead to a politicisation of the regime in the Antarctic, which is undesirable.

I turn to the text of the amendment that has been moved, which calls on the Government to promote adequate public discussion of the issues. I do not believe that this has so far been achieved. If one looks at the statement made by Senator Evans on 22 November in a news release, which was tabled in this chamber, when he put down details of the text of the Convention which we are now addressing, one sees that he said:
The Government's purpose in tabling the Convention is to promote community discussion.

There has been no real community discussion on this matter. A large number of issues need to be addressed and they have not so far been addressed because the Government has not lived up to its promise to promote community discussion on this matter. Our amendment calls upon the Government to do so.

Let me indicate the issues upon which we would expect community discussion to be fostered. The first is whether this Convention is entirely consistent with the provisions of the Antarctic Treaty. It is an operation which might become more exclusive, more exploitative and, indeed, majoritarian rather than based upon decisions being made on the principle of unanimity. Is it in fact entirely at one with the Antarctic Treaty itself? Secondly, as a result of the signing of this Treaty, is there some potential for conflict? For the first time, states in the Antarctic, parties to the Treaty, will be required to make judgments about the relative economic and financial benefits which some may gain and others may not; the Treaty parties as a whole might gain and those who are not Treaty parties will not. In other words, there will be the potential for conflict arising on that basis.

The third issue to be addressed is: what is the import of the secrecy provisions contained in Article 37, subsections 11 and 12, providing for commercial secrets to be maintained in a regime where previously all information has been made available to all members of the community? The fourth question is: from Australia's point of view, is there any loss of sovereignty by our entering into this particular regime? Will we lose the veto power on activities taking place within our sovereign areas? That matter has to be addressed, especially once an explorer has been granted a permit from the Mineral Resources Commission, which is to be established under the regulatory arrangements provided within the framework of the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities. The next issue is: will there be a loss of revenue to Australia? Will we, as a sovereign nation, derive royalties from mineral activity, exploration and exploitation which may take place within our sovereign territory in that part of the Antarctic? The next issue is subsidised mining. In the Chairman's draft, a document known as MC/17 revision 5, there was originally a subclause (f) in Article 2 requiring the parties to:
follow orderly mining practices and act in an economically rational manner.

That requirement, which was seen by Australia as an anti-subsidy clause, was subsequently removed by the time we got to the final draft in June 1988. The question of the exact meaning of that needs to be addressed within the framework of promotion of adequate public discussion.

The next question that arises is the question to which Senator Vallentine has referred-that of limited liability in terms of damage done to the Antarctic. It relates very much to my next concern, which is the control of oil pollution. We have seen oil pollution from a leaking Argentinean vessel and the sinking of a Peruvian vessel within Antarctic waters. Nobody would be unaware of the disaster that has occurred as a result of the accident involving the Exxon Valdez in Arctic waters. There is no doubt that those major questions need to be addressed.

There are questions about the diversion of resources-whether it is appropriate for countries such as Australia to divert resources from scientific and other activities to mining and exploitative activities. There is a large number of matters related to our environmental concerns. They concern the consequences of natural disasters, the impact of additional activity on areas such as the very limited Emperor penguin rookeries, the impact on scarce fresh water resources, bearing in mind the Davis base has already drained Station Tarn Lake to provide regular supplies to a small station. There is the question of the disposal of waste from the Antarctic. Recently when Senator Calvert and I were in Hobart we inspected the waste being brought back from Casey base in the Antarctic. We looked at the cases of waste material being brought back for disposal in Australia. There are questions about infrastructure concerns. There is the question of French activity at Dumont D'Urville and, indeed, the loss of the last vestiges of true wilderness character within the Antarctic environment. All of those are very significant issues. They all need to be addressed as a result of the public discussion which should flow from the promotion of debate about whether we sign this Treaty.

I know that there are divisions of opinion within the Government on this matter. We know that Senator Richardson and Senator Evans are concerned to sign the Convention. They believe that, in the absence of signing the Convention, the whole Antarctic Treaty system will somehow unravel. They believe in the old principle of half of loaf being better than none. We know that Mr Keating and Senator Cook have a different view on the matter. They are concerned about subsidised mining, royalties and the economic benefit for a limited number of operators within the Antarctic regime.

The Opposition, at this stage, has not yet concluded considerations of this matter. There is a paper which I have already indicated in public statements I have submitted to the shadow Cabinet in my capacity as shadow Minister for the environment for shadow Cabinet to address on questions relating to whether Australia should become a signatory to the Antarctic mineral resources convention. My view is that this process can be achieved only if there is an adequate level of public debate, which by this amendment we call on the Government to facilitate. It is not adequate for the Senate to take this matter on the run. It is clearly not satisfactory to move from the Antarctic Treaty to the world park concept, for the reasons that I have outlined. It is for those reasons that I put forward this amendment and seek the support of the Senate in the carriage of that amendment in substitution for the original motion moved by Senator Vallentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have no objection to Senator Puplick's amendment. Quite clearly, there is a need for wide-ranging public discussion. However, we are disappointed that Senator Puplick is closing off the other option and presenting them as two alternatives whereas one would like to see both wide-ranging public discussion and a commitment to the rejection of the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities (CRAMRA). For that reason, although it might sound a bit strange, we will be forced to vote against his amendment and for the original motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Typically, Senator Puplick has attempted to narrow down the range of debate to some very grubby, exploitative and obscene discussion. When one is considering the opening up of the last great essentially untouched continent on earth to exploitation and mineral development-`development' is a horrible term-then one needs to step back and seriously consider where we are as a human species on the face of this planet and what we are doing. It is only in that context that one gets a clearer view of what is going on.

As a species, the human animal is very young. The evidence, such as it is, indicates that we separated from our last common ancestor about six million years ago. Cosmologists suggest that the earth would be capable of supporting animals of a human sort for about another 500 million years. If we compare our life with that of other animal species, we find that we are indeed a very, very young species. We have probably had on this earth about one per cent of our potential life span.

Astronomers have been searching the heavens for many centuries, but particularly in the last couple of decades, to see whether there is in our vicinity life at least as technically advanced as life on earth. In the last couple of decades that search has been very intense. So far we have failed to find any other life as technically advanced as our own. While there may be life elsewhere in the universe as advanced as our own, the indications are that it is certainly not in our corner of the universe. If we accept relativity, that means that it is very likely that there is no other habitable place in our corner of the universe to which we could move and occupy. It means that the Earth is both our origin and our destiny and that we had better look after it.

Compared with the six million years that we have had on this planet as a separate species, we have been involved in intense industrial development for only about 200 years. In that time, we have succeeded in making a very substantial mess of this one corner of the universe which is capable of supporting human life. We have discovered in recent years that there are a number of environmental problems on a global scale-the greenhouse problem. We have substantially changed the composition of the atmosphere and are continuing to move away from its conventional composition, as we now know it has been over the last several hundred thousand years. We have a massive problem with ozone depletion. We have major habitat changes on a global scale. We have loss of species diversity. We have simplification and loss of cultural diversity. We have massive and global deforestation. If, in addition to all these things, in barely 200 years we have brought our resource exploitation to the point where we need to move to the last available continent and exploit that for resources, then we should be thinking that we desperately need to curb the voracious appetite of homo sapiens for these resources. Quite clearly, if we are looking for another 500 million years on this planet, we are running out of space very quickly; we are running out of resources that will support the sorts of lifestyles we are choosing to lead. Indeed, we are dealing with the Earth as if it were a business in liquidation, as if any resource can simply be turned into cash and frittered away in an incredibly short period. I believe that is the background against which we need to set the discussion in relation to possible exploitation of the Antarctic continent.

We are considering whether Australia should or should not sign CRAMRA. This convention, which is now up for signing, is set in place against the background of the Antarctic Treaty, which has guaranteed, as Senator Vallentine pointed out, international peace, scientific cooperation and nature conservation in the Antarctic since 1957. Under the proposed convention, Australia would be in an extremely strong position. Under CRAMRA, the claimant states, of which Australia is one, have the right of veto. In exercising that right by not ratifying the convention, it would be possible for us to ensure that CRAMRA does not succeed as an international convention. Therefore, we could begin the process of setting in place an alternative convention which would ensure into the indefinite future the protection of the Antarctic in whatever form. I point out here that Senator Puplick has attempted to trivialise the debate by pointing to simply one model of a possible world park. There are many models, and clearly that would be something that Australia could initiate by opening the debate on a far more comprehensive and protective convention.

The risks to the Antarctic from environmental damage are extremely high. Several other speakers and people in other places have mentioned the recent holing of the Exxon Valdez in Alaska. I point out that the environmental conditions there were not as extreme as one would experience in the Antarctic. Indeed, there is a large population in the vicinity which was able to address that spill. Nonetheless, that has been a complete disaster and, clearly, attempts to do anything about that major oil spill have been totally inadequate. Senator Puplick referred to the Chilean ship in the Antarctic, which I understand still contains some 300 tonnes of oil. Because the ship is now frozen in and will remain frozen in until next summer, there is no ability to go in and clean up that spill. One simply hopes and prays that that ship will not break up before the next Antarctic summer.

In these major spills there is no clean-up which can reverse the environmental damage that occurs. There is no dollar compensation which can in any sense even begin to address these massive problems of environmental damage. Low temperatures ensure that the speed of degradation of waste products, oil and anything else which gets into that environment is extremely slow. One needs to remember, of course, that one is dealing with a particularly fragile biological environment with extremely short food chains. Some Antarctic whales feed directly on plankton. Essentially, there is a two-step food chain which could be quite seriously disturbed very quickly. These very tight biological associations are very fragile and very easily disturbed. They are basically unstable.

Most serious and major accidents, particularly in recent years, have resulted from human error. I think that is worth stressing in the context of an attempt to get an agreement which relies on technical fixes, technical solutions, to ensure that those accidents do not occur. One could refer to the accident at Three Mile Island, which clearly did not occur because of a technical fault in the nuclear power station, but because of a failure of training and a misreading of the dials in the power station control room. The accident at Chernobyl arose due to a failure to train staff and also an inability to understand and observe the critical conditions which were developing in that reactor. We were told that the Exxon Valdez accident arose because of the drunkenness of the skipper. There was a major spill of iron chloride monomer in Victoria, which came about through the ineptitude of plumbers who were looking after a large tanker of the material. There was a serious toxic spill in Port Adelaide which again came about through human carelessness. I must stress that we cannot legislate for human perfection. In dealing with an extremely fragile environment it does not matter what conditions one puts into an international agreement. If mining should go ahead, accidents will occur as a result of human frailty and the damage caused by those accidents will simply be irreparable.

The record of environmental protection in the Antarctic has been poor, despite the existing Antarctic Treaty. One could refer to the International Whaling Commission, which has pointed repeatedly to the progressive run-down in populations of species of whales. As each species has been forced to near extinction-or certainly their numbers have fallen below an economically viable level-despite the protestations of the International Whaling Commission the whaling industry has simply harvested another species.

The convention concerning fishing depends ultimately on all nations reaching a consensus on what should be done about overfishing. Despite the fact that this convention was signed only in 1977, by 1983 a number of species had been quite seriously depleted. In regard to waste management in the Antarctic, we saw on a Four Corners program that a number of Antarctic bases are simply pushing their waste into the environment, despite international agreements to the contrary. These international agreements have not been well observed and in some cases have led to serious general damage and in other cases to quite serious specific damage.

Under CRAMRA, Australia would lose its power to veto mining. If that convention comes into force, an application to mine would be considered by a committee. Australia would lose its ability to veto a decision to go ahead with mining, even on its own territory. It may be a somewhat arrogant view, but I hope that our controls would be somewhat better than those that might be imposed by some of our other Antarctic partners.

It has been claimed that exploitation of the Antarctic may help less developed countries with respect to access to resources. One need only look at the International Law of the Sea Convention and how that was originally set up as a way of helping all countries to gain access to deep sea resources. That was torpedoed, essentially, by President Reagan, who supported the technically advanced and rich companies which were capable of exploiting things like manganese nodules from the seabed. CRAMRA has been strongly supported not by the less developed nations but by the United States, the United Kingdom, France, West Germany and Japan.

In conclusion, in view of the fact that Parliament would need to pass legislation before the Government would ratify the convention I strongly press the Government not even to bring the legislation forward but simply to refuse to ratify the CRAMRA agreement. If it does bring it forward, I urge the Senate to reject CRAMRA. I believe that Australia should take a lead in rejecting CRAMRA and then immediately bring forward proposals for an international convention on the protection of the Antarctic for the purposes of environmental protection and not for the purposes of mineral exploration and exploitation. I believe that Australia should take a lead in this matter, and has an opportunity to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —A vast amount is spoken about the Antarctic by people-like me-who have not been there. What they say always far outweighs what is said by the people with practical, open-minded and first hand experience. The first alternative to be determined in this matter clearly is whether there should be any human contact. Without a doubt, there has to be. The management and purpose of that contact is what has to be considered. For a start, the extreme fragility of the basic Antarctic Treaty cannot be ignored. The Treaty has always been questioned by both participants and non-participants. The Australian Government, until now, has always been able to maintain its own presence.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue that we are considering at the moment is the meetings on minerals negotiations. I have copies of the press releases for the eighth, ninth and tenth sessions. One should take into account exactly what the meetings have been about. Mr Chris Beeby of New Zealand was the chairman of the meetings. After the eighth session he put out a press release which said, in part:

. . . the discussions in Hobart had been marked by the constructive and dynamic spirit that characterised the Antarctic Treaty system and had so successfully fostered international co-operation in the Antarctica for more than twenty-five years.

``The purpose of the negotiations'', Mr Beeby said, ``is to strengthen the Antarctic Treaty by ensuring that if mineral activities in Antarctic ever take place they do not threaten either the peace and stability that the Treaty has maintained or the Antarctic environment.''

He explained that the regime under discussion would cover all phases of mineral resource activities and would provide detailed principles, procedures and mechanisms, including in every phase the requirement that any activity be subject to an environmental impact assessment.
The ninth session took place in Tokyo, from 27 October to 12 November 1986, the following year. The press release read:

The reason for this negotiation is therefore to ensure that if mineral activities in the Antarctic ever do take place, they are regulated in an acceptable manner and do not threaten either peace and stability that the Antarctic Treaty has maintained or present unacceptable risks to the Antarctic environment. ``The important point to note about this agreement,'' said Mr. Beeby ``is that it will prohibit mining in Antarctica unless a judgment is made in the future by the institutions to be established that the environment will be adequately protected.''
After the tenth session-again, Mr Beeby was chairman-the press release, in part, read:

It is to ensure that if mining activities do ever take place in Antarctica they are carried out in a manner that ensures the continued peace and stability of the continent-as guaranteed by the Antarctic Treaty-and does not present unacceptable risks to the Antarctic environment.

In this tenth session the chairman raised the question of the liability for damage and the elaboration of procedures for settlement of disputes, but did not reach any conclusion. The reasons for the presentation of the treaty are quite clear. The fact that we have not gone quite far enough along the track is also quite obvious at this stage. I believe that there is a need for a treaty. Whether we have reached that stage remains to be seen. I believe that if we wish to safeguard the future, we need to pursue the treaty and subtreaty basis on which we have been operating.

We have to consider that the countries that came in as original members-the United Kingdom, Norway, France, New Zealand, Argentina, Australia and Chile-are now being joined by a considerable number of other countries. The other 30-odd which have now joined all wish to have their own say too. Their views and ours on many issues are not the same. The basis on which we completed the original negotiations has been varied somewhat by the interests of other parties over time.

Our territorial claims are not recognised by many other countries. We hope and expect that the demonstration of our own involvement in the Antarctic will be regarded as evidence of possession and sovereignty, and so on. We have to concede that, whatever happens, man is part of the environment and cannot be separated from it. We have to do everything possible to ensure that man's presence and involvement are in harmony with the environment. We will never stop people going to Antarctica. It covers an area of over 14 million square kilometres-almost twice the size of Australia. By virtue of its unique climatic features, it offers an immediate challenge to the inquisitive nature of man-and rightly so.

The treaty development of the Antarctic and the subsequent Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources (CCAMLR) have been steps in the direction of producing by cooperative means agreements to introduce man but to do so more carefully and more thoughtfully than has happened in other places and at other times. As has been said, the first formal discussions on minerals began in 1982, and a considerable amount of thought and discussion has taken place since then. It now becomes necessary for Australia to make a decision by 25 November-six months away-if we are to sign this treaty. I hope that the promoters of the most extreme views on both edges of the spectrum, that is total availability, and total exclusion, will not be considered too seriously. I believe that some careful, in-between, acceptable proposal can be made. The decision is not easy. We know that the Government has been divided and that strong views from both sides have been put. We know what Senator Richardson and Senator Gareth Evans believe and we know what Mr Keating and Senator Cook believe. I do not see it just as a means of taxation, as one of those four gentlemen may, but I do see that there is a sovereignty question which needs to be resolved.

As a Tasmanian and as one who had two extremely useful and interesting years bearing the Opposition's responsibility in the area of science, which included the Antarctic area, I had the opportunity to avail myself of much information and of discussions with many interesting and knowledgeable people. I was pleased to form a good relationship with the Antarctic base at Kingston, south of Hobart, and to meet many of the scientists, practitioners and researchers that were involved. The extremely valuable research that they have carried out to date has been of great value and will continue. I refer not only to the work done on the animals, birds, sea life, the climate, and so on, but also to the research on a wide range of other pursuits such as psychology, food processing, insulation practices, extreme cold engineering, clothing, and so on. This research will spread to other areas worldwide. Clearly, now that the base has become recognised for the quality of its research, we are seeing more and more international scientists and visitors there. The future offers great potential in our servicing of research visits from other countries and of providing them with food, housing, clothes, medical services, transport and engineering, on a basis that offers many advantages over bringing everything half way round the world.

The Tasmanian Government is fully behind doing everything possible to encourage items with Antarctic connections and to provide Tasmanian connections. I commend the Tasmanian Government on taking such forthright steps, in difficult times, to change some of its activities into activities that will provide a different future. One of the real successes has been the development of the igloo satellite cabin by Malcolm Wallhead for a quick erection prefabricated shelter. That is just one that comes to mind. The Tasmanian Government assists industries with specific Antarctic applications to get into business in Tasmania so they may add to the resources available to expeditioners generally. Another excellent move has been the establishment of the Institute of Antarctic and Southern Ocean Studies at the University in Hobart. The work done by the Vice-Chancellor, Professor Lazenby, and by Professor David Green, in particular, has produced an excellent balanced program. The aims of the institute are worth stating:
to foster within the Tasmanian community a better understanding of Antarctica and its marine environment, the resources of the region and their significance to Australia;
to foster, encourage and support the conduct of research into all aspects of the Antarctic continent and the adjacent islands, seas and oceans;
in the longer term, to widen the opportunities for teaching within the University in the disciplines relevant to this research;
to enhance liaison and collaboration with individuals, and other national and international institutes and agencies having an interest in the region, by providing a focus for activity;
to encourage the development of local industries supportive of national and international endeavour in the region.

That has proved to be very successful and very satisfactory. The project fits in well with the CCAMLR, the Maritime College, the Antarctic Base and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation maritime divisions. The location and proposal are excellent. The institute is to be a fully multi-disciplinary operation covering science, law, medical aspects and engineering generally, and at post-graduate and under-graduate levels. The whole project is excellent. Then, of course, there is the International Antarctic Centre, which is another tremendous project and is an integral part of the overall picture. The design competition for the entrance to the building was held recently and was won by Philip Cox of Sydney, and the Director, Dr Louise Crossley, has been appointed and has taken up her duties.

Many people will never be able to visit the Antarctic and the Centre is designed to provide them with information, with history, and experience of what goes with Antarctic conditions. No-one can deny the real fascination that people have for what they normally cannot experience. This project will greatly assist with that. Tasmania is the logical place to be regarded as the Antarctic stepping off place for the world. We have to remember that Amundsen came into Hobart to give the world the news of his reaching the Pole. His modern day equivalent, Dick Smith, left from Tasmania in his Twin Otter for his most recent scientific expedition only a few months ago. It is worth mentioning that Dick Smith supports the whole Tasmanian Antarctic project. Hopefully, the Centre will help to educate people, who would go down as tourists and learn of the general fragility and the need to respect the environment in every way.

Visits to Antarctica will increase. Adequate protection is what we are talking about. The education of people before they go is very important, whatever their reasons for going. Scientific research will be the main reason for them going. There is still much to find out. Information on early life on earth, on climatic changes and likely climatic changes in the future, is probably all there. We need that information and we need researchers to go and get it.

We know there are many minerals in Antarctica, but at this stage there is no contemplation of recovering these in an economical manner. This means that our position needs to be determined before someone says that it is economical. Our position in Antarctica is one relating primarily to foreign affairs and strategic issues. I presume that these will need to be given priority in making our decision. From the mineral exploration aspect, however, the matter cannot be left in permanent indecision. While ever the convention remains unsigned and inconclusive, those countries with greater desires to seek mineral exploration will be advancing their views and, at the same time, those who want it to be an out of bounds area will be pursuing their views too. I believe that we cannot leave it that way. Senator Puplick referred to the progress that is being made in tidying up these issues. I hope that we can work towards making a decision soon on the basis of the best information available and that, when we do, the Government and the Opposition will be able to find common ground.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government supports the words used by Senator Puplick in the debate-that is, the need to promote adequate public discussion. It is important to note that by tabling for discussion some five or six months ago the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities and by keeping it on the table for a very long time, the Government has enabled the debate to progress on this issue all around the country. In fact, I think it has received enormous coverage in recent times. I am glad that we handled this matter in this way so that no decision was rushed.

SPEECH.PARA: The signing of this Convention is not a simple black and white matter. It is true, as Senator Archer and other speakers have said during the debate, that there are different views within the Government. I note that Senator Puplick has stated that the Opposition has yet to come to its conclusion on the issue. There are reasons for having different views and I want to go through some of them in the time that is available to me.

This minerals convention did not come out of thin air. It was the result of six years of tortuous negotiations involving representatives from 33 countries. I, for one, would not like to be the person who started it all again. It is not an easy matter to come to agreement or consensus on an issue such as this. The final meeting was held in Wellington in June of last year and the text of the convention was tabled in the Senate on 22 November of last year.

I think one misunderstanding that exists in the minds of some senators and, I might say, some people in the community, ought to be laid to rest. The Convention is not, and cannot be interpreted to be, an encouragement to mining. Rather, it seeks to put in place a series of stringent regulations should mining ever occur. In this respect, I would like to mention the reference in the debate to tourism because I think it has relevance to when mining might occur. I am constantly asked about tourism in the Antarctic, as I am about mining. I am personally opposed to mining taking place in the Antarctic and I will maintain that position. It will be a long, long time before tourism can even be considered.

The Australian Antarctic Territory has within its boundaries places which experience some of the world's worst weather. A couple of weeks ago we almost lost somebody at Casey Station. If anyone is wondering why mining or tourism will not take place for some time, it is worth noting the circumstances of a tragedy that almost occurred. The person whom we almost lost set out to walk one kilometre from the old Casey station to the new to bed down for the night. A blizzard set in as he walked out of the door of the old station and he literally could not see his shoes. He wandered off the track past the guide lights. In fact, his safety was in severe jeopardy. He was saved because he literally walked into a huge bulldozer. He was able to climb into the cockpit of that vehicle and survive. I think that incident illustrates just how difficult mining and/or tourism are in the Antarctic. This is certainly the case in so far as the Australian Antarctic Territory is concerned.

My concern in the short term is not so much about mining in the Australian Antarctic Territory; it is for those areas that Argentina and Chile in particular have an interest in. Being further north than the Australian Antarctic Territory, the climate in those areas is not as extreme. Those countries pursue their claims in the Antarctic with considerable passion. One can actually buy in Argentina maps of Argentina which show Antarctica as well. As I said, these countries take these matters very seriously indeed. I am concerned that mining might first begin in these areas. I, for one, want to make sure that, if mining is ever to take place, some regime is established that might at least, to use the phrase that Don Chipp made famous, keep the bastards honest. Senator Archer quoted what was said by Mr Beeby of New Zealand, who had the very difficult task of chairing negotiations. I would like to quote the following statement by Mr Beeby:

The convention does not incorporate a judgment that mining in Antarctica is acceptable, but instead, gives a high priority to environmental protection. It constitutes a mechanism for assessing possible impact on environment of Antarctic mineral resource activities, determining whether they are acceptable and, if so, regulating them in detail . . . The protection of the Antarctic environment is in fact the overriding theme running right through the text. The safeguards are substantial.

I think that is a pretty important statement from Mr Beeby. Under this Convention, mineral resource activities are prohibited unless it is judged, based upon the assessment of adequate information, that they would not cause significant adverse impact on the environment, on living resources or on global or regional weather patterns. We need to be sure that there is the technology to ensure safe operations; that the capacity exists to monitor the environmental and ecosystem parameters; and that the capacity exists to respond effectively to accidents with potential environmental effects.

I would like to say something about Australia actually signing the Convention and what that would actually mean. For the Convention to come into force, the following nations must sign: 16 consultative parties who participated in the final session of the fourth special Antarctic Treaty meeting in Wellington in June 1988; five developing countries; 11 developed countries; and all claimant states such as Argentina, Chile and Australia. To date, 15 countries have signed, and that includes Great Britain in the last couple of days.

For the Convention to come into force, for all of the conditions that I have just mentioned to be met, the signatures of Australia and France, as claimant states, are required, as are the signatures of either China or India. I might say that indications are that China will sign fairly shortly. So it will boil down to Australia or France signing the treaty.

On the question of environmental safeguards, Australia's objectives throughout these negotiations were to ensure that we focused on the achievement of very stringent environmental safeguards. Article 4 of the Convention sets out the general environmental principles concerning judgments on mineral activities which include the following:

Decisions about Antarctic mineral resource activities shall be based upon information adequate to enable informed judgments to be made about their possible impacts and no such activities shall take place unless this information is available for decisions relevant to those activities.

No Antarctic mineral resource activities shall take place unless it is judged, based upon assessment of its possible impacts on the Antarctic environment and on dependent and associated ecosystems, that the activity in question would not cause--

The article then goes on to list a number of adverse effects, be they water quality, flora, changes in distribution and the abundance or productivity of different species of fauna. Of course, the jeopardy of endangered species is also mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very similar to the conditions applying in respect of Alaskan oil exploration.

—That is very true. I will come to some misconceptions about what the convention can do which, obviously, are not very far away from what Senator Coulter is suggesting. But I am not sure that he and I would necessarily agree on the next step of what to do about it. I certainly agree with the honourable senator's interjection.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of liability has created a fair bit of discussion. The Convention applies strict liability on operators for damage to the environment and dependent ecosystems, the established use of the environment arising directly out of damage to the environment, and property-that is life or injury, et cetera-arising directly out of damage to the environment. Australia was successful in minimising the defences to liability contained within the convention. Our negotiators made a particular point of that. The only two defences to operate will be the natural disaster and act of violence defences. I do not think we could have been expected to have done much better than that. The natural disaster defence covers an event constituting in the circumstances of Antarctica a natural disaster of an exceptional character which could not have been reasonably foreseen. It is worth noting, and I think this has been too often missed in the debate, that that is in the context of those words `in the circumstances of Antarctica'. That in itself sets a fairly rigid test when one looks at what might be foreseen. I think it is therefore a very narrow defence.

To come to the point that I think Senator Coulter was implicitly raising, if one looks at the views on the Convention, two principal positions are being taken by the community on this question. The first is the view that if there were no convention there would be no mining. The second is that the Convention is the only way of ensuring proper regulation and environmental protection. I hasten to add that I do not subscribe to either view. I certainly do not believe that if there is no convention, there will be no mining. That is simply not the case. I believe, as I said, that mining will take place in some of the more northern parts of the Antarctic Territory, and I do not believe that is all that far off. That is why I would like to see something in place.

In so far as this Convention ensures anything, I would be reluctant to make the claim, as we have seen in the case of the Arctic, that the Convention would do any such thing. I hope a convention, be it this or a renegotiated one, might be able at least to place some pressure on those countries and companies involved in a mining exercise to do so responsibly. I repeat: that is in the context of my view that there should not be mining in Antarctica. When the Government comes to examine this question, and obviously I cannot pre-empt what its decision might be, there are concerns from a range of views that are worth taking into account. That is why I said it is not black and white.

Certainly Senator Cook has argued, I think forcefully, that we have to be concerned about the question of the subsidisation of mining. He is quite right to be concerned about it. In general terms, we sought a provision proscribing substantial types of incentives for the development and disposal of mineral resources which might give some sort of unfair advantage to mining in Antarctica compared with elsewhere in the world. We received support, through negotiations, from Chile and Argentina on that question. Unfortunately, at the end of the day we finished up practically alone on that point. It is worth noting that both Chile and Argentina have signed the Convention.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been concerned about revenue sharing and the issue of claimant states. There is no doubt that the non-claimant states are not terribly happy with the suggestion that that might take place, and I can understand why. While that is a matter of concern to us, I am not sure what we can do.

Senator Puplick raised a number of concerns which he said needed to be addressed, and I wholeheartedly concur. He raised the question of oil pollution. Obviously that is a critical problem, particularly in cold climates. That is one of the reasons why I am personally opposed to mining in Antarctica, and will remain so, at least until the Cabinet decides otherwise. Then I dare say I might rather hastily change my mind, although I do not believe the Cabinet would even be contemplating that at this point in time. All I hope is that we do promote debate. I hope the debate is rational and I hope it is understood that this is not a clear cut question. There are good arguments for signing the convention and there are good arguments for not signing it. It is a matter of the Government and the community going through the debate and weighing up those considerations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note, curiously, that only two people in this chamber at the present time have been to the Antarctic. You, Madam Acting Deputy President, were the distinguished Chairman of the former Committee on National Resources that inquired into the resource potential of the Antarctic and matters touching upon the Australian Antarctic Territory. The urgency motion that has been moved by Senator Vallentine is symptomatic of her attitude towards the world. She is very much the Alice in Wonderland of the Senate. She wishes the world to be as she wishes the world to be, and the world shall be as she wishes it to be. She does not live in the real world; the rest of us unfortunately have to live in the real world with Senator Vallentine on the outside looking in, making these bizarre--
—Progressively destroying it.

—Nobody is making a greater contribution to screwing this country than the Australian Democrats, through their interference, their mucking around, their meddling and their general incompetence in respect of legislation that comes into the Parliament. Whether or not the regime is signed by Australia will in no way affect whether or not there is mining in Antarctica.
—We were sitting here having a rational debate until you started.

—The honourable senator is welcome to make a contribution to this debate any time he likes and when I sit down I will listen to it. The truth of the matter is that Australia will be able to make no contribution if it is not a signatory of the treaty. The facts of the matter are that, whether or not this treaty succeeds, ultimately it will not influence whether mineral exploration and exploitation take place in Antarctica. The objects of the exercise, the intention, the inexorable reason why nations have come together, negotiated and sought to sign a regime, is to ensure that in the unlikely event that there is mineral exploration of a significant nature or, less likely, exploitation, there will be some sensible control and management of it. Otherwise, those countries less responsible than ourselves, perhaps through economic necessity more more than anything else, and their demand for resources, will proceed-that is, if the exploration itself does not destroy the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: So it ought to be understood from the outset by Senator Vallentine and the Democrats, in their headlong attempt to get a few grubby votes by putting up this bizarre proposition, the desperate leftovers--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a grubby attempt to get votes. They are not necessarily grubby votes.

—Senator Richardson is absolutely right. But my judgment is that, if Senator Richardson thought there were any greenie votes to be got out of not signing this thing, he certainly would not be signing it. I find it a unique curiosity that Senator Richardson and Senator Vallentine have a different view about this issue. Ultimately, bankrupt of policy, bankrupt of ideas and bankrupt of ideals, the Democrats and Senator Vallentine have drawn themselves together in pursuit of whatever irresponsible leftover greenie vote there is.

SPEECH.PARA: This proposal will do more to damage the Antarctic than anything I can imagine. I can think of nothing more irresponsible than the proposal put forward by Senator Vallentine that we ought not to be even a party to agreements of this nature. To propose the concept of an Antarctic World Park is absolutely absurd. The first thing that would happen if we had a world park is that the present Antarctic Treaty would collapse. It could not function if the Antarctic was a world park. I am glad to see the Democrats have gone across to rescue their soul mate and bring her back to the chamber to defend herself. The truth is that because we have an Antarctic Treaty, because we do not have a world park concept, there is an environmental regime in place and certain disciplines and responsibilities are cast upon the various members of the Treaty and those who have agreed to it. For the benefit of Senator Vallentine I will read out the general principles of the Antarctic mineral resources convention. It says:
No Antarctic mineral resource activity shall take place if it is judged to cause:
significant adverse effects on air and water quality;
significant changes in atmospheric, terrestrial or marine environments;
further jeopardy to endangered species;
risk to areas of special biological, scientific, historic, aesthetic or wilderness significance;
significant adverse effects on global or regional climate and weather patterns.
No Antarctic mineral resource activity shall take place unless it is judged that:
technology and procedures are available to provide for safe operations and compliance with the above;
there is the capacity to monitor key environmental parameters;
there is the capacity to respond effectively to accidents.

Area of Application: Includes the continent of all Antarctica, all Antarctic islands, including all ice shelves, south or 60 degrees south latitude and in the sea bed and subsoil of adjacent offshore areas up to the deep sea bed.
That is saying, in effect, that there shall not possibly be any mining in that area in my lifetime, and I suspect in the foreseeable future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or even in my life.

—Or even in Senator Richardson's lifetime. That is simply because it will not be possible to fulfil the obligations of the regime with those conditions. Let us remind ourselves of what prospecting is allowed, for those honourable senators steeped in knowledge of exploration. The entry level to mineral resource activity is limited to activities meant to identify areas of mineral resource potential for possible exploration and development. Geological, geochemical and geophysical investigations and field observations, remote sensing and collecting surface sea floor and sub-ice samples are all permissible. Drilling beyond a depth of 25 metres and dredging and exploration other than for small scale samples are not permitted. By any measure it simply allows for very superficial exploration under the most strict regime imaginable and under circumstances that prohibit and proscribe any form of exploration in the Antarctic.

SPEECH.PARA: If Third World countries are able to go to the Antarctic because they are not signatories to the minerals regime, and they have no obligations or commitments and are not parties to a treaty, there are no parameters or responsibilities cast upon them as to how they will conduct their exploration and what concern they shall have for the environment and the effects of their exploration upon the environment. If Australia does not sign the convention then it cannot seek amendments. Under the proposed treaty no amendments can take place for 10 years-for very good and sensible reasons. Following that decade, with the hindsight of experience, knowledge and better understanding, amendments can be moved. In the event Senator Vallentine would have her way it would be quite impossible for Australia to participate in those discussions, negotiations and agreements and ultimately move amendments which would rectify any part of the agreement which experience has taught ought to be so moved.

The minerals regime will put in place measures to regulate future mineral activity which the Antarctic Treaty does not. When the Treaty was first signed in 1961, and in its early stages, it was never imagined that exploration or mining was likely to take place. It was almost incomprehensible to those nations that they would ultimately have the capacity to do so. In many respects it still is. That is why it really contains no mention of mineral rights. There are a number of companies in the United States and Japan who I suspect are conducting prospecting and mineral exploration in the area. I suspect some other nations, under the guise of other activities, are probably doing exploration work and seeking to identify what minerals, precious metals and other resources are in the Antarctic. This regime is intended, after six years of endeavour, to lay down some guidelines ahead of activity by mining companies or nations. It is an opportunity for Australia to contribute. But at the end of the day it is fundamental that there be a proper public discussion and an airing of all points of view in respect of the Antarctic.

In the last few years we have seen-I am sure Senator Richardson will agree-very inadequate government funding of Antarctic research. Frankly, the reason we have become a joke on the international stage of those nations who have an interest in the Antarctic is that we claim sovereign rights over 42 per cent of the Antarctic-an enormous area-and we spend a paltry sum to justify our claim. If we had to justify our claim in the Antarctic based on the amount we spend on it or our representation down there, or by scientific research, we would have to forfeit the claim, hand it back and apologise for our conduct. We now have an opportunity to make a contribution towards the debate. Senator Puplick's motion reads:

The need for the Australian Government to promote adequate public discussion of all of the issues arising in relation to whether or not Australia should become a signatory to the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities (CRAMRA).

It is a thoroughly proper and responsible attitude, not a blinkered, obsessed, myopic, subjective attitude driven by political expediency by a group of senators destined for failure and defeat at the next election. They are making a last dying gasp for a breath of fresh air, looking for a constituency which by and large is deserting them because of their irresponsibility and conduct in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my summary I shall deal with the speakers-probably with the exception of the last, who did not have very much that was worth refuting-in the order in which they spoke. In regard to the speech made by Senator Puplick in putting forward an amendment to my urgency motion, obviously he is trying to avoid voting on the issue of the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities (CRAMRA). The urgency motion was intended to elicit a view from the Government and the Opposition about whether they would be supporting CRAMRA-and that is exactly what Senator Puplick is avoiding. He does not want to have to vote on this because the Opposition has not made up its mind, and it also seems that the Government has not made up its mind. The community certainly has made up its mind, but we are not privileged to hear what the Opposition has decided as it is still confused. I am not confused. I am not confusing the two issues about CRAMRA and a world park. They are mutually exclusive. There is no confusion about the issues in my mind or in my urgency motion. Mining is not compatible with wilderness objectives. Some tourism is possibly compatible and that aspect needs to be looked at in more detail.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick also mentioned the involvement of the United Nations and one possible plan for the management of a mining-free Antarctica, but it is not a foregone conclusion that it would be under United Nations jurisdiction. That is only one possible plan among many which has been put forward, as Senator Coulter said. We need to look very creatively at what kind of jurisdiction there would be over a world park. It is not necessarily even a popular proposition. A world park would indeed involve a great deal more consultation about the primary objective, which is the conservation of the Antarctic natural environment as far as that is possible, considering what has already happened there in terms of scientific development and the consequent degradation of the environment that has already occurred, mainly due to pollution. (Quorum formed) There is no reason why the international cooperation that we have seen in Antarctica should not continue if the main aim of the scientific community there is to continue with scientific research and to conserve the fragile environment. There is no reason why there should be further politicisation of the area there, which would happen if this mineral Convention were signed. Then there would be a good reason for politics and questions of sovereignty to come to the fore. There would then be a great deal of debate about the rights of various countries and various companies to have adequate access to Antarctica. But if we prevent mining happening, there is no reason why international cooperation should not continue.

I commend Senator Coulter's statements. He reflected the more sane position-one that is shared by most people in the community-that as far as possible we should not interfere further with the natural state of Antarctica as it is known to us now.

Senator Archer's sentiments, which were very laudable, were to the effect that whatever we do should be in harmony with nature. I could not agree more. Mining cannot be in harmony with nature; it is exploitative. We cannot have it both ways. I agree with Senator Archer that we need a decision soon so that the international community can get on with the business of conservation rather than exploitation in Antarctica. It would be preferable, as Senator Archer said, that this should be a bipartisan policy.

The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) reaffirmed his opposition to mining in Antarctica, but right at the end of his comment he said `until Cabinet decides otherwise or may decide otherwise'. I wonder whether he was flagging the intention of Cabinet in that somewhat unguarded remark.

TALK.START.PARA: —No; I really was not.

—Then I hope that Senator Richardson's opposition to mining is absolute and will not be swayed in any way. I hope that he will be going in to bat for the environment in Antarctica as he has done in other places. We cannot imagine, as Senator Richardson said, that this Convention will in some way monitor mining to ensure that it does not interfere with the environment. It will be a licence to go ahead and mine. We cannot attempt to stop mining by having a mining convention. It is a contradiction in terms.

SPEECH.PARA: There needs to be a lot more discussion about tourism, as Senator Puplick said, and it needs more discussion in the community. I do not care what other countries have already signed the Convention. I think that is irrelevant to the debate. Australia is in a very good position to take a lead in this matter and we have an opportunity to veto CRAMRA. We should take the strong position and not be guided by what other countries have signed so far. In some cases their reasons for doing so are dubious, particularly in respect of Chile and Argentina, which hope to get their share of whatever mining spoils there might be.

Questions of sovereignty, subsidisation and incentives for the exploitation of mineral resources in Antarctica have been raised. On that score the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, has some doubts, as does the Treasurer, Mr Keating, as I mentioned earlier. Maybe it is strange for the environment movement to have support from the Treasurer, but it makes a nice change, and we welcome that.

Still, at the end of this debate, we have not a position from the major parties. We have not a clear position from either the Opposition or the Government about whether they would support the signing of CRAMRA. The Australian Democrats and at least two Independents will vote against this watered down amendment put forward by Senator Puplick-not because we are opposed to further discussion on this issue, which we think is very important, but because we wanted a stronger statement. We wanted to find out the clear positions of the Government and the Opposition on CRAMRA. Obviously they are not prepared to give us this sort of statement. No wonder there is disillusionment in the community with the two major parties, which are so wishy-washy and so similar to each other that it is difficult to distinguish between them. We have not heard very much variation in the views of the Government and Opposition, and that is typical of so many debates in this place.

There are lots of green votes in this issue and the Government and the Opposition should be aware that the public will not be duped by their doublespeak that a mining convention will prevent mining in Antarctica. It is a contradiction in terms. If the Government decides to sign CRAMRA, it needs to be well aware of the fact that there will be a huge fuss in the Australian community. Today it is being given due notice of that fact. Australia has the power of veto. I hope that the Government will heed the wisdom of the people on the issue of protecting Antarctica, not just for our sakes but for future generations. Collectively we have managed to stuff up the environment of earth's atmosphere and of the five developed continents. Let us not stuff up the remaining sixth continent, which is still unique and which it is still possible to save.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Puplick's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question, as amended, agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Government in the Senate nominating Senator Faulkner to be a member of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs.

INTERJECT.PARA: That Senator Faulkner, having been duly nominated in accordance with Standing Order 36aa, be appointed a member of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) Report on Food Processing and Beverages Industries is an interim report on Government regulation of packaging and labelling. In recent months the Australian Democrats have been concerned about a move that seems to be under way towards considerable deregulation in the area of packaging and labelling, particularly of food products. Certain elements of this report give us concern in that area. I recall the earlier report of the Business Regulations Review Unit last November when this issue was raised by us and when we expressed the concern that we express here today. The Democrats believe that labels on food should give more information rather than less.

I point to some of the issues addressed in this report. For instance, we express concern that the Industries Assistance Commission is putting before us the prospect of allowing industry to use misleading terms such as `giant kilogram', `jumbo' and `bonus pack'. We believe that is not in the interest of consumers. The proposal is to remove the code of practice for deceptive packaging as well. While there are some arguments advanced in the report, we believe that the current code covers the requirements of consumers and should not be removed.

We recognise that industry may find it inconvenient to give full and accurate information to consumers but we do not believe this is any excuse for lowering standards. It is difficult enough for consumers to do battle in the supermarkets, to sift out fact from fiction in the heavy promotional advertising that is so much a part of our daily lives and to ensure, particularly in the supermarket situation, against price rise rip-offs without expecting them also to cope with misleading labelling, misleading packaging and reduced information.
SENATE 12 April 1989...Food Processing and Beverage Industries

One of the other recommendations in this report is the requirement to specify that a product is artificially sweetened by whatever the artificial sweetener is. We believe that that should not occur either. It is of great concern to many consumers that they have full information about the ingredients in products. The IAC claims that currently there is a double requirement because, of course, there is a requirement for the identification of ingredients. It believes that the fact that the artificial sweetener will be included in the list of ingredients is sufficient for the consumer. We say it is not. Because there are grave concerns about some artificial sweeteners, we believe that the consumer's attention should be drawn to the fact that such products are artificially sweetened.

In general terms, I express concern about the general approach of this report. In the first instance, I am not sure that it really is the role of the IAC to be involved in dealing with these sorts of issues beyond that aspect that we would agree with; that is, that we need a national system of uniformity in requirements for labelling and packaging of consumer products. We certainly agree with that. It is the IAC's role to promote that. But many of the aspects in this report relate to issues that are not genuine costs on industry; they are conventions and, in many cases, conventions that have developed into codes of practice in the interests of consumers and are not genuine costs on industry.

The claim by industry and by the IAC in this report that to reduce information to the consuming public will save the public money is a claim without any actual backing. Certainly, in the experience of average consumers, there is nothing to suggest that it would reduce the cost to the community. Once again, we want to go on the record as resisting the push towards deregulation in the area of packaging and labelling of foodstuffs in the interests of the Australian consumer.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY COMMISSION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is another of those annual reports for the year ended last June being presented to this chamber in April this year. It is more evidence of appallingly bad reporting standards. It is about time the Government smartened itself up. It is not good enough to blame the organisations involved for this late reporting. For example, the financial section of the report is dated 23 November 1988. The Auditor's report is dated 24 November 1988. Surely the Government can get its act in order and present these to the Parliament at a time not contemptuous both of the Parliament and of the people of Australia to whom it is supposed to be reporting.

There is a little additional problem with this annual report that I would like to deal with. It is a problem not revealed in the printed part of the report on page 76, which deals with financial statements and which simply makes the bald statement that financial statements for the year ended June 1988 have been prepared on an accrual accounting basis and that the statements conform to the guidelines of the form and standard of financial statements et cetera. But, as is always the way in these matters, when one looks to the fine print of the accounts defined at the end of the annual report on page 95 one discovers that, yet again, there is more evidence-this time involving the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission-of simple administrative incompetence in the spending of taxpayers' money. Note 18 to the accounts states:
MINISTERIAL APPROVAL OF ESTIMATES

The Commission is required under sub-section 57 (1) of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act 1985 to submit estimates of expenditure for approval in a form directed by the Minister. Further, under sub-section 57 (2) of the Act, the Commission is required to expend moneys in accordance with the approval given by the Minister.

In accordance with the requirements of sub-section 57 (1) of the Act, Ministerial approval was sought on 26 June and 16 September 1987 for estimates of expenditure for the quarters ending 30 September and 31 December 1987 respectively. Ministerial approval was not obtained until 28 July and 26 October 1987 respectively resulting in first and second quarter expenditures of approximately $1.2 million and $1.5 million in advance of the Minister's approval.

The simple reality of that is that a Government body has been spending money in an unauthorised way simply because it is the only way for it to operate. Ministers involved have taken so long to get around to acceding to the requests. It may have been unreasonable to give the Minister four days before the commencement of a new quarter, as was the case with one of those applications, but the fact is that this organisation has blatantly broken the Act under which it operates. There is no sanction, no penalty and, even worse, no mention in the printed report of the fact that it has broken the requirements of the Act under which it operates. In the notes to the accounts it says this:
Procedures subsequently approved by the Minister will facilitate provision of Ministerial approval prior to any expenditure of Commission funds.

In other words, it appears that at last they are getting around to smartening up the procedure so that this illegality does not continue. We have seen repeated examples in annual reports of organisations breaking the rules, the laws under which they are operating, and in fact not operating in an effective and proper way in the regulation of taxpayers' funds.

I hope that at last someone in the Government is going to respond to these continual complaints I make about these annual reports, particularly as to their lateness. Until they do, I shall keep up this attack, if you like, on what is clear governmental incompetence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take up the cudgels on behalf of Senator Michael Baume as well on the reception of the annual report of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. I picked up the auditor's report and on reading the item on page 75 to do with the financial statement I thought everything was all right. I then turned to the fine print and saw exactly what Senator Michael Baume saw: millions of dollars are being spent in an unapproved way.
—Unauthorised.

—An unauthorised and, indeed, illegal way. Eventually they caught up with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) and got him belatedly to authorise it. They have now taken precautions against a similar thing happening in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to this sloppiness, appendix 8 on page 121, dealing with the legislation administered by the Commission, states that the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act was proclaimed in December 1985 and that the regulations came into effect on 20 February 1985. I presume that is a misprint for February 1986, but it is certainly a sloppy little error.

The report was unavailable until it was tabled, and I have only had a chance to glance through it superficially. It looks as though we are running the biggest $17m talkfest Australia has ever had. That is all they seem to have done. I notice a whole series of resignations. The Queensland member of the Commission retired in June last year and, as far as I can tell from this, he has not been replaced. During 1987-88 the following people served but had resigned prior to certain dates: Mr Kevin Power, the nominee of the Commonwealth Minister for Industrial Relations, resigned in August 1987; Mr Ron Reid, the nominee of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, resigned in August 1987; Dr Brian McGuirk, the nominee of the Premier of Western Australia, resigned on 7 December 1987; Mr Jim Brassil, Chairman of the National Commission, resigned on 14 March 1988; Mr Graham Swan, the nominee of the Premier of Queensland, resigned on 18 March 1988. A lot of people seem to have got sick and tired of this talkfest. I notice in the schematic representation on page 5, describing the Department, that the Occupational Medicine Unit position had not been filled as at 30 June 1988. I can only hope it has been filled by now or the place will not be operating effectively at all.

I join my voice with that of Senator Michael Baume. I deplore the lateness of the report and the sloppy administration, and I wonder about the series of resignations that have taken place in the Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested to note the comments of my colleagues opposite and what might be a priority of emphasis when somebody gets up to speak on a report. The honourable senators seem to have turned to the back of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission to find out just how much money it has spent. I would like to return to the front of the report and find out what it spent it on. The figures listed on page 10-they are now a year behind; as I understand it, those figures have been updated-remind us that over 500 Australians are killed each year as a result of traumatic occupational injuries alone, and the number of deaths from occupational disease each year is thought by many to be considerably higher than 500. In fact, more recent figures provided to me say that the figure is now 550 deaths in work each year, although 20 per cent of those deaths are said to be in journeys to and from work. More than 300,000 Australians suffer work injuries each year. They are the figures of the greatest pertinence in this report and they are the ones that should be in the forefront of the minds of senators.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point in that very same paragraph, a point that the Opposition never remembers, is that in 1986 Australians lost 10 times as much time from work as a result of occupational injury and disease as from industrial action. The Opposition would have us understand that days lost at work are due to industrial disputes. It never reminds us that at least 10 times as many days are lost as a result of occupational injury and disease. The preliminary cost of workers compensation claims for 1987-88, calculated by the Australian Bureau of Statistics from the Australian National Accounts unpublished data, was $4.79 billion. This direct cost alone was 1.6 per cent of the gross national product. Those figures do not include the occupational injury and illness loss; nor do they put any figure on human misery and suffering or the pain, anxiety and chaos caused in families when a worker is lost to the work force and the income from the worker is lost to that family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you need a $17m commission to tell you that?

—It is interesting that Senator Sheil says that. That is precisely what we need. If he read the front of this report he would know that until this Government came into office and actually focused on a national view of occupational health and safety those figures could not be stated. The figures that were given to me in 1983, 1984 and 1985 were still citing 300 deaths. They were very wrong and had been underestimated because there were no national statistics, no national data and no national perspective on occupational health and safety. That is what this Commission has been established to try to find out, to try to collate and provide. In fact, if Senator Sheil read the early pages he would have a better idea of just why the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission justifies the expenditure made on it. If Senator Sheil actually wants to worry about $1m out of $17m, then I remind him of the cost that is put on occupational health and safety in this country-now up to $6 billion. I think that $1m here and there, while we cannot ever disregard it, is not really of such pertinence against the cost of accident and injury and disease in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The early chapters explaining the work of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, of its emphasis of comparison between Australian and overseas data, other countries and the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, put Australia very low down and certainly give us no cause for comfort in looking at the occupational health and safety performance in this country. But with the formation of the Commission, with the national perspective, with the changed legislation introduced by most States in this country in the last couple of years, we are now getting a much better handle on the numbers, a much better idea of the costs, and a much better understanding of the steps necessary to prevent illness, disease and accident and promote safe practices. The formation of the national perspective, the Commission and the tripartite nature of the committees involved have led to a considerable improvement in understanding the issue, its significance, size and importance. I would hope to see in the next annual report some considerable movement, particularly in the collection of statistics, and data which are promised in this report for the first time ever to be comprehensive national statistics.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION: EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

It is with considerable satisfaction that I commend the equal employment opportunity annual report of the Australian Industry Development Corporation, which provides us with an accessible, brief, concise, well produced means of identifying exactly what has been achieved in the AIDC in relation to its responsibilities under the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Act, which was proclaimed on 1 July 1987. I believe this report provides a model for how such reports should be produced and, apparently, for how such an exercise should be conducted.

The report describes the relevant history of the AIDC. It describes how it is a small organisation which needs complex financial and technical skills among its staff. Consequently, 80 per cent of its staff have post-secondary training and 60 per cent have tertiary qualifications. I imagine that that makes it unique among many organisations, but perhaps there are quite a few statutory authorities of similar size in that category. The report states that this requirement for a complex skills base can act as a barrier to entry to and promotion within operator streams for members of designated groups. However, since this organisation has been implementing its equal opportunity policy, of the 180 current staff 17 have been promoted from support positions to professional ranks. I emphasise that this is extremely significant. The individuals employed in support positions might never have had such opportunities to move out of those streams into professional ranks without the strategies that have been adopted and encouraged by this Government. Nine of those promoted officers are women and five of those women have been moved from support departments to business divisions. Once again, it is a very commendable record on the part of the Corporation.

The Corporation has clearly allocated responsibility for the development of the equal employment opportunity policy to the Chief Manager, Human Resource Management. The report takes us through the steps that have been followed and that are required in order to ensure that, initially, employees are informed of the exercise; that wide consultation is held with employees and trade unions; that statistics are provided; and that the whole plan is monitored and evaluated. Most important of all, perhaps, is the fact that, as a result of this process, the Corporation has a plan for the next two years. I repeat: I believe the Corporation should be congratulated for having competently, wholeheartedly and without any fuss set itself the task of implementing equal employment opportunity. I wish it every good fortune.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
