SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fifteenth report of the Committee of Privileges dated March 1989 deals with the Committee's findings in relation to evidence presented during Senate Estimates committee hearings in relation to Project Parakeet. On 6 December 1988 the Senate resolved, on the findings of the President, that there were grounds for reference to the Privileges Committee of this motion:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether false or misleading evidence was given to a Senate Estimates Committee in relation to the Department of Defence project known as Project Parakeet, and whether a contempt of the Senate was committed in the giving of that evidence.
Paragraph 10 of the findings of the Committee reads as follows:

The Committee has concluded that there was no intention to give any false or misleading evidence to a Senate Estimates Committee in relation to the Department of Defence project known as Project Parakeet. It follows, therefore, that no contempt of the Senate was committed in the giving of that evidence.

I accept the findings of the Committee. They fully vindicate my reference of the matter to it-a reference which was not taken without a great deal of thought and deliberation because the charges laid were of the utmost gravity. There are few more serious charges than that of misleading the Parliament, for which severe penalties are exacted. The Committee found:
There was no intention to give false or misleading information.

The Committee did not find that the Senate had not been misled by the evidence tendered to it. Indeed, it tacitly accepts that the Senate was misled, as a careful reading of the section preceding the Committee's findings, entitled `Conclusion', would lead anyone to see. The operative word, of course, in the findings of the Privileges Committee is `intention'. The Committee could not prove beyond reasonable doubt that the intention to give false or misleading evidence existed. In the circumstances, no other finding was possible. My central concern, however, was not with `intention', but with `false or misleading evidence'. I recommend that honourable senators read the `Conclusion' section of the report.

I will now deal in a little more detail with the background of this matter. The matter being inquired into by the Senate Estimates Committee was the development and acquisition of part of a communication system for the Defence Force-Project Parakeet. The project has five phases, and the first three have been completed. When the contract was let to the prime contractor, a company called Racal Electronics Pty Ltd, the expectation was that if the performance of the contractor was satisfactory throughout the first three phases, the final two phases would be awarded to the contractor. It goes without saying that the expectation was that the contractor would perform satisfactorily throughout all phases or he would not have been awarded the contract in the first place.

Preceding the Estimates Committee meeting in April 1988, it was known to all of those who took an interest in the matter that there were serious problems with Parakeet. It was known, for example, that the Scandinavian subcontractor responsible for the switch gear, which was crucial to the system, was experiencing major problems in meeting the specifications. It was known that Racal had technical problems and significant management problems. It was known that the decision had been taken to recommend that the automatic follow-on of contracts be voided and the subsequent phases go to open tender. There were articles in the press. I knew of these problems before I attended the Estimates Committee hearing. It may seem strange to public servants that questions should be asked when the answer is known, but it is an old truism of politics that one does not ask a question until one knows the answer. While that statement is obviously not literally true, public servants would be surprised at the number of times that the answer is known to the questioner at a parliamentary committee hearing.

Project Parakeet was an important and expensive program about which there had been much public discussion. Dr McIntosh, the Chief of Capital Procurement, was the major witness for the Department of Defence. He knew at the time that he was recommending to the Minister that the project be cancelled. It is against this background of knowledge that the evidence given to the Senate Estimates Committee on 11 April by Dr McIntosh must be judged. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the relevant passages from the Senate Estimates Committee Hansard, which are printed in the Committee report.
Leave granted.
The passages read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —What will happen about Project Parakeet? Will that be affected by any of these financial decision in this subdivision?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-There are not proposals in the additional estimates that are affected by Project Parakeet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the contract going ahead?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-At this stage there are no decisions that would affect additional estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what I asked. Does the major equipment project items of a saving of $157.5m, affect Project Parakeet? Do you mean that it is not included in there? There is no reduction, slippage, rescheduling or whatever we might like to call it?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-No, Senator, not in these additional estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —So the news report in the Sunday Telegraph of 27 March that Parakeet was in doubt was not accurate?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-I think that speculation of that kind is premature.

TALK.START.PARA: —You make me more suspicious than ever by your answers. Do you realise that?
—Is it not true that there are considerable technical problems with Parakeet?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-I think that is an overstatement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not true that one of the major subcontractors is in difficulty?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-I think that, too, is an overstatement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the project way over budget?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-At this stage, no. At this stage the completion of the most recent phase has occurred and it has not been way over budget. We are now examining proposals for the next phases. We have in front of us a set of proposals from the contractor for the next phases. Data is being considered within the Department for a recommendation to Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are those proposals over budget?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-At this stage that is not yet clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it behind schedule?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-Not significantly, no. We are actually considering what this last phase means to us and where we proceed from here. Until we have made a recommendation to Government on what those costs are, it is difficult to say anything else.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to go back to Parakeet and to Dr McIntosh's assertions that things are going well there. Do you categorically deny that there have been problems with the Scandinavian or Danish sub-contractor for the switch gear for that program?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-I am sorry, that is not what I said. I said that we had completed a phase and we were now examining the proposals for the next phase and those proposals will be put to the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the questions put to you earlier was to the effect as to whether there were any problems with Parakeet and the answer you gave implied that there were no problems with Parakeet.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-I said that those assertions that you had made had been exaggerated. I did not say there had been no problems. In a development program of this kind, of course there have been. But at this stage we have proposals in front of us for continuing the project which are being considered.

TALK.START.PARA: —I put it to you that there are serious technical problems with Parakeet. Is that true or false?

—Dr McIntosh has now answered the question three times. I wonder how many times he is expected to answer it? He has said that there are no significant problems. He has said it a couple of times now. I think that that is probably enough.
—So long as Dr McIntosh realises that that is the position on the record.
—I am sure that he recognises that it is on the record. He has had to repeat it several times. He seems happy to live with it.
—What is the timetable for project Parakeet?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-We would expect to be putting a proposition to the Government shortly for the next phases. Shortly might mean within the next week or two.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the next phase?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the next phase?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-We are going through a development program. We have just completed the third phase. We are looking at completing phase 4 which is a continuation of the development before we enter phase 5, which is the production equipment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have in mind the equipment being in operation by a particular date? Are you, hopefully, working to a particular timetable?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-Yes, of course.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of date?

SPEECH.PARA: Brig. Farry-The mid-1990s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has that date been set back as a result of technical difficulties?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-At this time, no.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it always intended to be in operation in the mid-1990s?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-Yes, and as you would appreciate from that answer, in a development program of this kind where there was no equipment readily available off the shelf that met our requirements, it required us to undertake a staggered-staged, if you like-phase of development. The precise timing is then as vague as the mid-1990s.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has not been any slippage from your point of view in the development program in that you intended to be in operation in the mid-1990s from the beginning of the project and that is still, you believe, the likely date.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-That is the date on which we are still planning, yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are reports in the Press that the project is likely to be reopened for tender untrue?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-I am afraid I should not comment on that until propositions of whatever kind for the continuation of the program have been taken by Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not quite understand that answer.
—It implies only that the Government has not made a decision on the next phase, I assume.
—Is that what you mean?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-Yes, exactly.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the Press report which talks about a phase being likely to be reopened for tender suggests that tenders had been sought and perhaps awarded. Was that for a particular phase?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-We have completed phases 1, 2 and 3. At the end of phase 3 the contractor is obliged to put forward proposals for phases 4 and 5 and those proposals are now being considered. When they have been considered recommendations will be put to Government and the Government will make decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have tenders been sought for phases 4 or 5?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-`Tenders' implies that we sought open tenders. What we sought were contractual commitments from the contractor as to how he would see continuing phases 4 and 5. There was a contractor who completed phase 3 and he has been asked to give us prices for phases 4 and 5.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, if you have not submitted it to Government contracts have not been entered for either of those two phases.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-Phases 4 and 5 we have yet to commit, of course.

TALK.START.PARA: —So, therefore, reference to having to reopen a tender would appear to be incorrect?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-I am sorry, I have not said that at all. All I have said is that we have sought propositions from the current contractor, and the options that relate to those propositions will be put to government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us move to Parakeet. What is the timetable on that?

SPEECH.PARA: Major-Gen Francis-I expect that there will be overall about a year's delay on Parakeet. We expect to be seeking approval for parts of Parakeet in the next Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are we precisely with it from a contractual point of view?

SPEECH.PARA: Major-Gen Francis-At this point, the contract for phase 3 is complete and we will be seeking endorsement of phase 4. Exactly in what form we are still debating. We are not absolutely certain of the acquisition strategy that we will use in the near future for approval in next year's Budget. So there is no contract running at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, but will it go to tender?

SPEECH.PARA: Major-Gen Francis-Yes, it will, to open tender.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not a fact that the Department is completely disenchanted with Racal and has no confidence in it, and that is why it is going to tender?

SPEECH.PARA: Major-Gen Francis-It is a fact that we are not continuing with Racal as the sole supplier, which was our original intention. There are a number of reasons for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the performance of the equipment?

SPEECH.PARA: Major-Gen Francis-Partly performance. The principal reason was that the cost it came in with as a tender for the next phase did not relate back to what the company predicted, and the price that it predicted was one of the significant factors upon which it was chosen in the first place. It would not be fair to other possible suppliers to continue with Racal under those circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —What were the other reasons? You said it was the principal reason.

SPEECH.PARA: Major-Gen. Francis-We had some management problems with the company. It was in the process of sorting those out and we really had not got to the point of proving the point one way or the other when it put in its estimate of the next phase. At that point, we decided that there was no point in continuing with Racal for the next phase. So the company just continued and completed its work on phase 3.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Committee went into this in some detail last year. We were assured by Dr McIntosh that there were no problems with the performance of the contractor at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-That is not what you were assured. With respect, Mr Chairman, I too have brought my transcript and that was not what you were assured, with respect, Senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —I put it to you, Dr McIntosh, that you misled the Committee there.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-I do not believe so.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were asked a question by Senator Newman and you said, `At this stage there are no decisions that would affect additional estimates', implying that things were going well. Later on I asked you if it were true that there were considerable technical problems with Parakeet and I later on went on to the switching gear. You told me that was a wild exaggeration. The general tenor of your replies to this Committee was that there were no difficulties which hazarded in anyway the future development of project Parakeet.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-With respect, Senator, that is not at all what I said and I do not believe the transcript shows that. What I said was that there were no technical problems, and as you have heard from General Francis--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not a fact that there were problems with the subcontractor with the switch gear?

SPEECH.PARA: Dr McIntosh-I can turn to Major-General Francis for the detail if you wish, but that was not a major concern at this stage, remembering that phase 3 as I outlined to you was paper studies and we were not into the building of technical equipment at that stage. But--

TALK.START.PARA: —I put it to you that it was a major concern of the Army. It might not have been of the civilian component, but it was certainly was of the Army.

SPEECH.PARA: Major-Gen. Francis-The concern of the Army at the time was that Racal would not guarantee the performance of that particular equipment in certain areas. They were in the process of sorting that out when we decided not to proceed because of the cost issue. I am pretty confident actually it would have been sorted out. It was not that the equipment necessarily would not perform, it was that they were not giving us a guarantee that it would.

TALK.START.PARA: —The position at the moment is that we are at least a year behind schedule.

SPEECH.PARA: Major-Gen. Francis-We will lose about a year, yes, which is preferable to proceeding down an unsatisfactory path.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite. Parakeet also happens to be an essential part of the communications net.

SPEECH.PARA: Major-Gen. Francis-I certainly support that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.

SPEECH.PARA: CHAIRMAN-Dr McIntosh, you were in the process of giving an answer there and you were interrupted. Are you finished to your satisfaction?
Dr McIntosh-I think the issue has been well and truly covered.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a narrow and legalistic sense, Dr McIntosh's answers about the project being on-time and on-budget are correct. The contractor was finishing the third phase within the nominated time and budget. But Dr McIntosh knew that he had taken the decision to recommend to his Minister that the contract be voided-a major step-because the performance of the prime contractor was not good enough. He knew that this was in the papers. He knew that the Senate wanted information to judge how successfully the program was progressing. He knew that the reason for Estimates committees is essentially prospective, not retrospective; in other words, that Estimates committees are looking at expenditure ahead. He knew that the Senate wanted information on the future of this major program. By answering the questions from Senator Newman, from Senator Hill and from me, by sole reference to phase 3, he clearly implied to the Senate that all was well, as a reading of Hansard shows. The implications were clear that the future of the contract was in good standing. That was not a truthful answer. Dr McIntosh stands condemned also by his own written submission to the Privileges Committee. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: At the time of the hearing, phase 3 was concluding and the proposals for phases 4 and 5 were being considered. Discussions were being held with Racal who were being advised that the Department intended recommending to the Minister that they not continue as sole supplier for later phases.

Furthermore, Major-General Francis, the Assistant Chief of General Staff, Materiel, in his submission to the Privileges Committee, after confirming the problems with EB/STK -the subcontractor for the switchgear-went on to say that in discussions with Racal he had found its tender prices for the next phases so high that he could not accept them and he could not recommend that it continue exercising its contractual obligations. I should at this point comment on and commend Major-General Francis for the directness of his answers and the readiness with which they were given.

The submissions from Dr McIntosh and Major-General Francis to the Privileges Committee quite clearly state that they were aware of major problems ahead for Parakeet at the time of the Estimates hearings. By their own admissions to the Privileges Committee, they confirmed that they knew serious problems were ahead. The Parliament was asked to approve money for this project but was given no inkling of these problems. Dr McIntosh chose to withhold this information from the Parliament. He chose instead to fence with the meaning of words. Indeed, Major-General Francis, in his first submission to the Privileges Committee, said:
It's my perception that the issue will be decided on opinions on the meaning of the words used by Dr McIntosh in April . . .

Major-General Francis was clearly uncomfortable with the stratagem used by his superior to conceal the facts from the Committee. Furthermore, in Dr McIntosh's submission we can see ambivalence where he is arguing that, on the one hand, he knew that the price was too high but, on the other hand, he did not know whether he could proceed with the contract, while at the same time he was recommending to his Minister that the contract be cancelled. Nor is it competent for Dr McIntosh to hide behind the construction that to have frankly answered the senators' questions would have pre-empted a ministerial decision. There was no question of that arising. There is always a Minister at the table ready and alert to intercede when questions beyond the legitimate bounds are asked. Senator Durack, in his speech on this report, drew attention to the fact that Dr McIntosh was not only a very senior public servant but a very experienced one in appearing before parliamentary committees. He could have answered clearly the questions that the senators were asking without pre-empting ministerial prerogatives or breaching commercial-in-confidence information.
The Parliament is not only entitled to be informed, but officials have an obligation to inform. I share Senator Durack's fears when he said:
I am rather concerned to read the views of a senior public servant that public servants do not have to volunteer information to a Parliamentary Committee or an Estimates Committee.
The whole purpose of Estimates Committees is to reveal the workings of government. It is not a game-least of all an adversarial contest over concealment.

I took no pleasure in referring this matter to the Privileges Committee. It is the first time in 11 years in the Senate that I have felt the need to do so. I am pleased that the Privileges Committee report vindicated my action and essentially found in my favour. I regret that Dr McIntosh's career has been blemished. A neutral Minister in the future will be influenced by this report. It is my earnest hope that witnesses before future parliamentary committees read this report of the Privileges Committee and understand clearly what the Committee is saying.

In conclusion, I can only re-echo the words of the Privileges Committee when it said that if Dr McIntosh had been as forthcoming with the Estimates Committee as he had been with the Privileges Committee, this sorry incident would not have occurred.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to continue some remarks I started to make last week on the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs. It was tabled in this place late last year. Before I comment on the matters within the report I would like to acknowledge the person who had carriage of this report in large part and that is my one-time South Australian colleague former Senator Ron Elstob. It was a massive task and it is a massive report. It was conducted by Senator Elstob in a very thorough and proper way. In some ways it is a very fine testimony to Senator Elstob's commitment to and on behalf of people who are not so well placed in this society to speak for themselves. Senator Elstob had a way of reducing complex ideas to pretty simple principles.
—He was a good senator.

—I thank Senator Hill. Senator Elstob was minded to say quite often that what he thought people should have was a right to education, a right to work, a right to health and health care and, as stated in this report, a right to adequate provision for them in their old age. I do not suppose there can be a better way of providing some kind of testimonial to Senator Elstob now that he is no longer in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to make a statement of appreciation of two consultants who contributed so much to the work of the report, David Ingles and Daryl Dixon. This is a massive document. It covers a huge body of information in both the retirement pension area and the superannuation area. It is a tremendous resource document. It also has been a great challenge to those of us who struggled to get across it as it was being formulated. I am particularly appreciative of the assistance the consultants gave us in the task of trying to finalise that report. I would also like to thank all those other people who contributed and assisted the Senate Committee in producing this report.

I do not mind reminding the Senate that the reason we have this report was that the Opposition senators and the Australian Democrats were very annoyed at the time of the introduction of the assets test. They wanted a royal commission. They settled for terms of reference to be sent to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. That is why we tackled this mammoth task. I suppose it could be said that it is a very useful report, contributing as it does to the body of information in this very complex, complicated area and, in particular, very expensive area.
When tabling the report, my colleague Senator Zakharov, who has just joined us in the chamber, said:

In 1987-88, the cost of providing age and service pensions amounted to $8.9 billion. The estimated cost to the Commonwealth of superannuation tax concessions exceeded $3.5 billion for the same period.

In view of the generally low level of benefits received by most superannuants, together with the fact that only 8 per cent of the population aged 65 years and over receive any income from superannuation, and less than 5 per cent rely on such benefits as their principal or main source of income in retirement, it is not surprising that a large number of those who contributed to the inquiry questioned the effectiveness of the Government's role in providing financial assistance for the occupational superannuation system.

That highlights in a very brief way some of the vital comparisons that need to be made when we are looking at the challenges facing governments if they want to address the proper financing of income support for people beyond working age, that is, in their retirement and old age.

The figures in this report give one considerable pause. The costs are huge and, as any demographic study will show, the numbers of people coming into this category of `beyond retirement' will increase over the next 20 to 50 years, and it is a matter of serious consideration for governments. How will that be afforded by our society? This report gives some very interesting and provocative ways of thinking about the mix between superannuation and pensions in the future.

I briefly want to allude to the points that I raised in a dissent from the majority report. First of all, I wanted to disagree with recommendation No. 6 to extend the availability of Commonwealth pensioner fringe benefits to all age and service pensioners. In an ideal world, it would be fine to provide pensioner fringe benefits to everybody in receipt of pension or part pension. But, as I have just said, the cost of the age pension income support, let alone the fringe benefits that go with it, is very high and will only get higher.

Over recent years the Government has been very effective in targeting its pension and benefits payments to those people most in need. I could not see why we should move away from the practice of continuing to target to those most in need provisions under pensioner benefits services, including the fringe benefits that go with the pensions. While I appreciate that some people at the margin-that is, those people on part pension in receipt of a small extra income-are denied pensioner fringe benefits, I do not believe that a universal adoptive of pensioner fringe benefits is the preferred way to go. I believe that this area is well worthy of further consideration by government so that the more significant pensioner fringe benefits might be made available in an increased or more targeted way. But I could not come down on the side of the universal provision of those benefits.

I objected to recommendation No. 12 that provided for the payment of the age pension at a standard single rate. Again, my principal concern was the clear cost implications which would have been quite massive. This recommendation tries to tackle the inequities that sometimes exist now. For instance, there is an income difference between two single rate pensioners and pensioners in receipt of the married rate pension-that is, two people in receipt of a single rate pension as against a married couple in receipt of a married rate pension. That does create some discrepancy. In fact, by adopting a single pension rate for everybody we would simply reverse the discrepancy and reverse the inequity. I am not sure that we should actually try to solve problems by creating inequities. Sometimes this happens, but certainly in this case my principal reservation is based again on the enormous cost implications.

I was also concerned about the provision of fringe benefits to all age and service pensioners because of the implications of costs to the States. A large number of the States provide a variety of extra pensioner fringe benefits which are usually allocated to those pensioners who are entitled to the pensioner fringe benefit card at the Commonwealth level. That makes good sense in terms of coherent administration and planning. But if we were to extend the pensioner fringe benefits concession to all pensioners or part pensioners, the State cost implications would be absolutely massive. Ultimately, the responsibility for meeting these costs would come back onto the Commonwealth Government which is the principal collector of income around this country. Again, it seemed to me that we are not even absolutely clear about what those State benefits are. The benefits vary from State to State and include such things as electricity, transport, rate and rent concessions. I believe we should perhaps again suggest that this is an area for further more comprehensive investigation. Again, we need to target decisions in that area. But again, cost implications were the principal reason that constrained me from supporting those recommendations.

I would like to say that I think the report contains a very imaginative proposal. I refer to the two-tier provision of pension-a 20 per cent universal pension for aged people and then a much more targeted extra 10 per cent to those most in need. We did not actually vote on this recommendation, so it is not a question of whether I disagreed with the majority report. But, again, as we move towards targeting, I found that it would be running against the principles that are currently in place to move towards universality. While it could be argued, from a fuller reading of the report, that tax benefits could be given, I did not find the arguments persuasive.

Finally, all of the implications in this report depend on good will and a bipartisan acceptance of the recommendations. But I see very little evidence of the bipartisan support that is necessary to implement such long term proposals as are contained in the report. In fact, I think it is not forthcoming. At this stage it would be foolhardy in the extreme to make recommendations on the basis of that kind of bipartisan support. I recommend the report to anyone with an interest in the provision of income support for aged and retired people. It is a thoroughly comprehensive and quite splendid resource document which is full of excellent up to date data and recommendations.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration entitled Review of the Efficiency Scrutiny Program, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

In December 1987 the Committee sought and obtained a reference entitled `the central administration of the Australian Government'. This report is the first from the Committee under that reference. The efficiency scrutiny program had been widely publicised as a departure from the traditional approach to public administration and was expected to lead to a major change in public service culture and the general attitudes of public administration. The Committee believed that there would be value in evaluating the early experience of the program in the light of these claims.

Although the program ended earlier than expected, the Committee saw value in completing its inquiry. There has been little official reporting on the scrutinies to Parliament or the public. This report is, in fact, the first comprehensive public review of the efficiency scrutiny program. The Committee believes that its conclusions will be useful to those responsible for efficiency improvement in the public service, especially if any attempt is made to revive the scrutiny technique.

On behalf of the Committee, I would like to thank Committee staff, witnesses to the inquiry and others who helped the Committee in its deliberations. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the remainder of my tabling statement.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Good work but could do better

The majority of the Committee concluded that there was considerable merit in the program but found fault with several aspects of its administration. Every teacher or sporting coach knows that the hardest assessment to communicate is `good work but could do better'. The difficulty in striking this balance is reflected in the majority and minority reports which agree on the facts but disagree significantly on their meaning.

The majority view was that the monetary savings achieved by the program were significant and far outweighed its cost. The scrutiny program will have produced savings to the Commonwealth budget of about $193 by the end of June next year with ongoing savings after that of about $87 million every year. The direct costs of the program itself were in the $1 to $2 million range-a handsome return on a small investment.

The Committee was sceptical as to the effects of the program on public service culture and attitudes. Many departments and agencies had little or no direct experience of the scrutiny process and this must have reduced its impact on culture and attitudes. Although ministers and departments expressed moderate support for the program in their submissions to the Committee, few have chosen to use the scrutiny technique themselves since the operations of the program were devolved to them in July 1987.
Centralisation versus devolution

The most important criticism of the program relates to inadequate central monitoring. There was clearly a tension from the beginning between competing philosophies described by the Department of Finance as `letting the managers manage' and `making the managers manage'. Mr Block and his Efficiency Scrutiny Unit were strong advocates of devolution-`letting the managers manage'. They seem to have applied the concept too enthusiastically to their own operations.

The Committee concluded, while there were and are opportunities for decentralisation in the public sector, the scrutiny program struck the wrong balance between central control and autonomy. There are advantages as well as disadvantages in centralisation, especially in the use of a small central unit in efficiency review. The ESU could usefully have been:
a source of motivation for critical review of targeted aspects of public service operations;
a catalyst in that review by providing reviewers with specialist advice and an external mentor;
a clearing house for ideas so that innovations in one agency could be readily passed on to others;
a monitor of performance in implementation of reforms, and
a training ground for an important part of the future top management of the public service.

The ESU did all of these things, some of them less effectively than it could have. The Committee concluded that the decision to devolve responsibility for scrutinies to departments was a decision not to improve the Unit's performance in these tasks but to stop seeking the benefits of centralisation altogether. We have recommended that:
a mechanism be developed to allow for central monitoring of efficiency improvement initiatives by Australian Government departments and agencies; and
in conjunction with this, the formal requirements for departments and agencies to report on their efforts to improve efficiency should be strengthened.
Accountability to Parliament

It is disturbing that there was no provision in the program for reporting to Parliament. The reporting system may have been sufficient to inform the Government of the performance of departments and agencies in particular scrutinies. It was certainly not sufficient to allow the Parliament to hold the Government accountable.

We have recommended that all future efficiency improvement programs should include a provision for annual reporting of results to Parliament. This would be of advantage to the executive as much as to the Parliament. It would force efficiency reviewers to rigorously evaluate their own performance and would allow their claims to be publicly tested.
The alternative method of accountability-detailed scrutiny after the event by committees like this-is slower, less consistent and, possibly more painful to the Government in the long run.
Risk management

A major theme of the scrutiny program was risk management. The Committee found, however, that a only few, albeit important, scrutinies directly sought to improve risk management in the public service. It is also clear that the concept was already widely applied in the public service.

We noted some concern on the part of the acting Auditor-General that the rhetoric on risk management might have led to some element of substitution of licence for intelligent operation. The current Auditor-General expressed similar concerns at a Committee hearing last week.
We have recommended that the Department of Finance should report to Parliament by the end of this year on the effectiveness of risk management approaches flowing from the scrutiny program.
Other criticisms

There appeared to be a wide-spread perception in the public service that consultation between scrutineers and those working in the areas they examined had been inadequate and that the Department of Finance was excessively zealous in harvesting the savings from scrutinies.

The Committee accepted that both these factors were problems and would have been caused difficulties if further cross-departmental scrutinies had been undertaken. We were sympathetic, however, to the Finance argument that quick action needed to maximise the benefits of the program, especially given the scale of the potential savings from the larger scrutinies.
Success or failure?

We concluded that the long-term effect of the scrutinies in increasing the concern for efficiency in the general public service was probably beneficial but small. The short-term savings, however, were large enough to justify a revival of the program when the pace of other change permits it.

The monetary savings achieved by Mr Block were very large in comparison to the costs of his Unit. It is likely that the scrutiny program also had a beneficial effect in increasing the concern for efficiency in the general public service culture.

The Australian Public Service has been extensively reviewed and reformed in recent years. Mr Block reached the conclusion that, although improvements are possible, the Australian people have grounds for pride in their public service. He went so far as to describe the Ministry and senior public servants collectively as national treasures.

The majority of the Committee agrees with the Prime Minister that Mr Block has made a significant contribution to the welfare of the citizens of Australia. We were pleased to agree with Mr Block that those citizens have reason for some pride in the standard of their public service. We emphasise that our criticisms of the scrutiny program and of the public service are intended to build on, not reflect on, the achievements of those involved in public administration at all levels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration because it deals with a matter of considerable significance. As Senator Coates rightly said, it is true that there was a great deal of expectation about the achievements that might have derived from such an exercise as efficiency scrutiny. I regard it, however, as somewhat revisionist to suggest that from the outset it was contemplated that there would be a change in public sector culture. Indeed, I think that has been put forward after the event somehow to provide a basis for suggesting that there has been such change. Indeed, as I will demonstrate a little later on, I think that is also a vastly overblown claim.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is fair to say that the genesis of the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit (ESU) was the report of the Rayner unit in United Kingdom which had been operating since 1979 and which, over a seven-year period, had accounted for aggregate savings of #900m and reduced the annual running costs of the Civil Service by about #300m or 2.3 per cent. True to his utterly opportunistic and pragmatic approach to politics, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) seized on the achievements of the Rayner unit and put them forward as the principal justification for the establishment of a similar unit in this country. That unit was quite explicitly based on the Rayner unit. The Prime Minister said, in recognition of that fact:

. . . the present economic climate requires the public sector to review systematically and in a quite fundamental way its management and administrative procedures, having regard to best private sector practice.

I think it is significant that the Prime Minister was prepared to acknowledge that the public sector had a lot to learn from the private sector. Indeed, in his statement to Parliament in late 1986 he was at pains to say that the public sector had to shape up; that if it did not learn from the best techniques of the private sector it would be in big trouble; and that in the past in many ways it had reflected the easygoing, `she'll be right, mate,' management and work style of the lucky Australia of the 1960s and 1970s. There it was-purple rhetoric, pandering to those whom I regard as being substantially in the majority in this country amongst people who think about the issues-the statement that small government was a virtue, something to be striven for, something on which governments were increasingly expected to deliver. The Prime Minister, true to form, saw an opportunity there to capture part of that market and, as a result, headed off down the path of efficiency scrutiny units. I think there was at the time general approbation of that initiative. The tragedy of the matter, I think, is that what was a very good idea ultimately became no more than a cynical political gimmick. It did not last for any length of time and it was in fact closed down within a matter of days after the 1987 Federal election. I think that is a tragic outcome, because so much could have been achieved by a proper handling of the issue.

Mr David Block, a prominent businessman with extensive private financial sector experience, was appointed to head the unit. In many ways much was expected of Mr Block. I think he was a victim of his own rhetoric and that ultimately he did not perform an adequate public service in this regard. When the Prime Minister did what he did in chopping the unit off at the knees after the 1987 election, Mr Block simply went quietly. He allowed himself to be used. He took the opportunity merely to say that he believed changes had been achieved in public sector culture and he was in no way critical of the fact that all of the principal objectives of the unit had simply been ignored.

In fact, when the Prime Minister announced the establishment of the scrutiny unit, it was to operate for a period of three years, it was to oversee an extensive program of scrutinies of selected areas of public sector administration, and it was to carry that out in a series of phased programs. Mr Block launched the initial program in October 1986 by asking all departmental heads to consult with their Ministers and nominate areas for possible scrutiny. He then proceeded to nominate departmental heads to provide scrutiny topics to the unit in November 1986. He selected the 37 topics that were subsequently designated for examination in the first round of scrutinies. The selection of topics was endorsed by the Expenditure Review Committee. Clearly, Cabinet regarded this as of priority, unless it was as cynical as the Prime Minister and was let in on the secret that this was mere window dressing to carry the Government up to the mid-1987 election.

The scrutinies began shortly after that, the scrutineers having been chosen in early 1987, mostly from middle management ranks of departments. I think there was within the Public Service a deal of anticipation that some progress could be achieved. The first round scrutinies were conducted over a 90-day period from January to March 1987. As they progressed, Mr Block, and I think through him the Australian public, came to accept that what was happening was a long term program to achieve significant change within the public sector, that principles of efficiency were to be regarded very highly, and that all managers in senior positions in the Public Service were expected to address these issues and to confront the unit in such a way that it would be clear that they were able to achieve significant savings in their own areas of responsibility.

By May 1987, 37 first round scrutinies had been conducted and Mr Block was telling the Australian community that he expected a further 40 to be completed by the end of that calendar year. In fact, as I have indicated, virtually nothing happened between that time and the date of the July 1987 election. Three days after that, the Prime Minister effectively announced the demise of the unit. Of course, in the best traditions of salesmanship and public relations at government level, that was not a concession. There was simply an announcement that the Government had decided to devolve the program of efficiency scrutinies to individual departments and Ministers. The then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, was designated as the chair of a committee of Ministers with overall responsibility. Mr Block would be retained with his supporting unit, renamed the Administrative Reform Unit. It was then given an expanded charter to advise on broader issues of public sector management.

The fact is that from 14 July 1987 the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit was, for all practical purposes, dead and buried, and it remained dormant until it was officially pronounced extinct on 8 July 1988, when even the renamed Administrative Reform Unit was wound up. Mr Hawke then stated, in his usual euphemistic terms, that Mr Block had achieved marvellous results, that he had given his full concurrence to the disbandment of the unit, and that public sector cultures had been changed. To quote the Prime Minister:
Mr Block has managed to promote an environment of reform and questioning of established practices within the Commonwealth administration which will have ongoing benefit for many years.

Not only is that high blown rhetoric, but I also regard it as verging on the dishonest. Nothing positive can be said about the achievements of Mr Block other than in a very modest manner. Later I will come to some of the limp testimonials provided by leading departments of the Commonwealth to indicate to what extent they regarded the unit as having achieved anything of significance or success in changing their attitudes to public sector culture. The fact is that the unit achieved very little. Worse than that, not simply was there window dressing; it made claims which were later demonstrated to be quite inadequate and its own processes were demonstrated to be quite inefficient and ineffective.

When we have regard to the political timetable, we are left wondering why the Prime Minister did not see any virtue in endeavouring to deliver the goods in this area. Presumably that will have to remain one of life's great mysteries. One of the most disappointing aspects of the whole exercise was the attempt by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration to ascertain the details of the estimated and actual staff and financial savings. When it was discovered that a question from Senator Archer to the Prime Minister was already on notice, it was thought wise to abide by the results of that question. In fact, it took more than eight months before the Prime Minister condescended to respond to Senator Archer's question. The figures that were ultimately provided were later revised downwards quite substantially and were couched in such terms that it was very difficult to comprehend precisely what was being alleged by way of savings. I think the view ultimately taken by the Committee, which we would endorse, was that those savings were exceedingly modest, probably about $36m a year.

The actual cost of conducting the unit is not disclosed, and certainly not the amount that was paid to Mr Block by way of consultancy fees. I would not suggest for a moment that they exceeded the alleged $36m of savings. Nonetheless, when we look at what could have been achieved as a percentage of running costs of the Public Service-when it was about 2.3 per cent in the United Kingdom, we find it was less than half of one per cent in Australia-then it is quite clear that nothing of substance was achieved. Not only are we disappointed at the dollar outcome, we are even more disappointed to find that the revised figures were misleading, inaccurate and unreliable. I think this highlights the travesty of claims to efficiency and belies the suggestion that somehow we now have a modern and efficient public sector that is using the latest performance indicators and targets and all the most modern management techniques. The reality is that the savings estimates provided, ultimately in the answer to Senator Archer's questions, were expressed variously in dollar terms over different years. Some of those estimates did not specify any price base at all. The overheads were variously costed at rates ranging from zero to 100 per cent of direct salary costs. Not all the figures allowed for the 25 per cent rebate, which was supposed to be available to departments that actually achieved significant savings. Neither the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit nor its successor reviewed the scrutineer's estimates or monitored implementation in any systematic or purposeful way. That is a disgrace.

If ever one is entitled to expect that proper accounting techniques and efficiency approaches are going to be adopted, it is when we have a specifically designated efficiency scrutiny unit headed by someone the community regards as an expert in the field, someone with presumably good credentials for delivering. Yet what we find are the sorts of approaches that would make a suburban firm of accountants blush. It is therefore perhaps merely consistent with the very low estimate ultimately provided by the various departments of the work of the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit. Perhaps they go some way to explain why the Prime Minister was persuaded that there were not any more votes left after the election. Maybe that is the answer to the conundrum-that even the Prime Minister was embarrassed at the lack of substantive achievement. It did not stop him going on to make the usual claims about achievements but in reality they were virtually nil.

I will give some of those testimonials from the Government departments and hope that I do not ever find a collection such as these put forward to justify my achievements, or those of any of us on this side of the chamber. The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs described the program as having provided `a modest impetus to public service reform'. Defence saw the process as forming `a small part of the way ahead'. Social Security regarded the process as merely a supplement to other activities; Foreign Affairs and Trade assessed the exercise as having been of limited value; and Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories felt that it was still too early for a full evaluation. Perhaps we could say they were damning the program with faint praise. It does not take much to comprehend what was really being said, stripping away the attempt at politeness and the endeavours to use jargon that might have been construed as fairly neutral. The fact is that they were kicking it to death. They were obviously not interested in cooperation. They did not regard themselves as having anything to learn or as having learned anything from the process in the short time that it operated.

It is clear that the Prime Minister's claims were inadequate in the extreme. To suggest Mr Block's major contribution had been to make Public Service managers think in different ways is totally dishonest. To suggest, as it is now put forward, that somehow there has been a change in public sector culture is again quite wrong. I think the whole poverty of these claims can be seen from the actual achievements; in dollar terms they are very modest and in qualitative terms they are even less impressive. Therefore, I think the real tragedy of the exercise is that there was a lot that could have been achieved if there had been a serious commitment on the part of the Prime Minister, if there had been a genuine appreciation of the need to achieve savings and efficiency within the public sector.

True to the Prime Minister's incomparable ability to wax and wane, to blow with the wind, one only has to look at what he said in a speech last October to the national conference of the Royal Australian Institute of Public Administration. Having praised the ESU when it was first established, having said what a marvellous job Mr Block had done and having based the whole establishment of the unit on the notion that the public sector had much to learn from the private sector, by October 1988 Mr Hawke was talking much more about the public sector being able to teach the private sector. He made virtually no reference to the application of private sector ideas. His attitude was, if anything, the reverse-talking of streamlining measures and setting an example to the private sector by accelerating the drive for greater efficiency in the public sector. In our dissenting report we regard that as a complete capitulation to traditional public service orthodoxy, as setting back the cause of reform, indicating beyond doubt that this Government is not interested in pursuing these matters, and that Mr Block and the ESU had merely a transient and ultimately negligible impact on Public Service attitudes. In fact, they may have set back the cause for genuine public sector reform.

One can understand the cynicism of the Australian community that has a bill of goods sold to it in this way. If at the outset the Prime Minister had put forward more modest goals and had been honest with the community in the final assessment and the justification for winding the unit up so prematurely, then one might have been able to say that at least some modest progress had been made. In the light of all that obfuscation and the very unimpressive outcome one can only wait until there is a change of government before we can get back to the process of embracing genuine public sector reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks supporting my colleague Senator Alston and make a couple of comments regarding the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. I too agree with the thrust of the report. The aims first announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) were laudable. We heard all of this huffing and puffing and we had the appointment of Mr David Block. We were looking at something that I believed was long overdue in this country. After the debacle that has occurred we are faced with a situation where the likelihood of any Public Service reform or scrutiny has virtually gone out the window. It would be a very brave person or government that attempted to do something again in the wake of what has happened.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that when the Prime Minister first started on this exercise and announced what he saw as the main objectives he was basing it on a scrutiny by Sir Derek Rayner in the United Kingdom that had lasted seven years and had reduced public service running costs by 2.3 per cent. How the powers that be could compare this particular effort with that one is beyond imagination. The upshot of it is that after such a short time we ended up with the dubious savings of 0.5 of one per cent. I suppose if we take into account even the cost of the Committee looking at the efficiency scrutiny program, that would have been quite significant. It seems a shame that something that offered so much gave us so little. If one could believe the aims of the original exercise, it was something that we could look forward to with a great deal of enthusiasm. But here we are less than three years later looking at something that I do not think anybody can be all that proud of. As we have said in our minority report, we have ended up with a short, shallow political exercise. I do not believe that even David Block expected that to happen when he set off on this rather daunting task. As my colleague Senator Alston has said, within three days of the Government returning to office in 1987 the whole thing was virtually scrapped. Even though it was revamped, it was finally put to bed in 1988.

A few people who gave evidence were concerned about the inadequate and superficial consultation that took place. Obviously it was a sloppy exercise from start to finish and it was not thought through in the way that it should have been. As an exercise that was set up to improve standards of management and accounting, as Senator Alston said a moment ago, it did not set much of an example for anybody, particularly as to the tardiness in replying to Senator Archer. I doubt whether anybody would be brave enough to try to attempt a similar exercise. It seems that the public sector will continue on its merry way without too many cost savings. I noticed a while ago the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) standing at the table testing himself out. I thought that we might be getting a sneak preview of what Australia is to expect over the next few months.

If this exercise is an indication of the way in which this Government performs, I feel that we have not much to look forward to. The position can be summed up by quoting the penultimate paragraph of the minority report of which Senator Durack, Senator Alston and I were the authors:

It is clear that Mr Block and the ESU had a transient and ultimately negligible impact on public service attitudes and practices save for the considerable time, energy and resources which the public sector was required to devote to what was essentially a public relations program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I would like to take this opportunity to respond to the debate on the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration which has been tabled this evening. It is important that I should answer the comments made by Senator Alston and Senator Calvert and their minority report, and to provide some defence for the majority report. I found it sad to see the minority report from Opposition members of the Committee. I do not think that its language and tone was in the nature of a committee report; it was more like a political speech. It was full of exaggerated rhetoric, a good use of the Thesaurus on Senator Alston's part, since the minority report described the operation as feeble, shallow, shabby and so forth. He spread those words very nicely through the minority report.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to point out that the majority report was not a whitewash of the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit (ESU). It was a fair and reasonable commentary to which the Opposition members of the Committee could have been party. They could then have made the sorts of speeches they have made tonight, without the need for a minority report. If we are to have that sort of purely political minority report on an issue such as this, where there could have been the hope of some consensus, I think there is not much point in referring anything to Senate committees in the hope of achieving that sort of consensus. Much of what was said in the minority report could have been said in debate and not in what purports to be a report dissenting from the majority. When the Opposition members of the Committee made a number of comments about the draft report, modifications were made in an attempt to meet those comments. But those Opposition members went ahead anyway with what I think were excessively destructive comments about the Efficiency Scrutiny Review that were unfair in the strength of this criticisms.

I shall deal with a few particular matters. I shall not attempt to go over all the ground again, but a few things need to be said to answer and put in perspective the political criticisms which have been made. In regard to timing, the minority report talks of the review having been a shallow political exercise which was little more than a pre-election gimmick. Something announced in September 1986 for an election that might have been expected at the end of 1987 hardly falls within the definition of a pre-election gimmick. It was part of what has to be acknowledged as a continuing program of the Government's reform of the Public Service and its administration generally. It was welcomed at the time and should not have been damned in retrospect as much as it has been this evening by the Opposition.

Opposition members make great play of the fact that an announcement was made three days after the July 1987 election in changing the nature of the unit headed by Mr Block. Senator Alston tonight talked of the ESU having been closed down and that it was chopped off at the knees immediately after the 1987 election. But that operation continued for a further year in a different form, the so-called devolved form. I am not saying that I agree with this concept of devolution, but at least the Opposition, which is more supportive of that sort of concept, should acknowledge that that did happen and that the operation continued. It is hardly fair to say that the whole thing was closed down immediately after the 1987 election. The comment was made that the judgment had been made that there were no votes left in this issue after the election. I hardly think that some of these issues of administrative reform are a great central political issue for the public generally anyway. Attempts to make these reforms should be recognised much more as genuine attempts than the Opposition managed to do tonight.

Another issue raised in the minority report and also in Opposition comments in this debate is that the equivalent British operation saved 2.3 per cent of running costs, whereas the Australian exercise saved only 0.5 per cent. First of all, it very much depends on the definition of civil service running costs. Certainly the reference was to 2.3 per cent in Britain after seven years of the Rayner unit's operation, whereas the 0.5 per cent that was referred to was achieved in something over one year. One should at least be fair and make comparisons over a similar period. In any case, I did some fairly rough calculations on the equivalent amounts of money. Obviously it depends very much on one's definition of what constitutes civil service running costs. Clearly there is a major difference in definition of running costs between the two governments, so it is very simplistic to make that comparison. We reject that simplistic comparison.

In any case, the numbers are only one thing. There is also the question of the overall impact on attitudes as an indicator of performance. There are other issues around that one could surmise were involved at that point in 1979 when the British unit began for example, and there was more scope for review and for cost cutting compared to the equivalent position that the Australian Government was in at the time. Making these sorts of international comparisons in such a firm way as saying one was 2.3 per cent and the other was 0.5 per cent is pretty unreasonable and does not take into account the different range of other measures which were being undertaken in different countries at the time and at different times.

I also thought it was a bit unreasonable of the Opposition members to put in the minority report paragraphs 15 and 17 as if they were comments of their own. They used comments that were made by the Committee in the majority report as if that were part of their disagreement. The commentary made by the minority in paragraphs 15 and 17 were contained in the majority report and therefore was not a matter of disagreement. There was also some suggestion by the minority that the Committee report attempted to down play the achievements of Rayner in the United Kingdom and Grace in the United States. The only point of our making those comparisons was that they were more or less equivalent attempts to show that there had been this sort of review tried elsewhere and that there had been similar situations of falling short of the initial promise. I do not think there was any attempt to say that this operation was much better than that in the UK or US equivalents, but merely to say that here were the comparisons and that there was less achieved than might have been in all cases.

What I am disagreeing with is the suggestion that, because Rayner and Grace were done by conservative governments overseas, they were wonderful and the Australian one was not. I do not think that suggestion ought to be made any more than the opposite suggestion because all three did have trouble with implementation. What those two overseas examples found was that there was a lot more scope for cuts in policy areas than in administration. That is where those overseas studies strayed into the area of policy rather than straight administrative savings. The British auditor found that five of the 32 scrutinies examined over there accounted for more than 70 per cent of the savings. There is a similar parallel with the Block scrutinies here. It is not so much that any of the three was good or bad but that all three indicate that the scope for squeezing savings out of the bureaucracy can be overestimated, especially by those who do not have to do it.

The other thing I should comment on is the size of the savings. I think Senator Alston in his comments tonight said that all that had been achieved was a measly $36m a year. In fact, $36m was the amount we quoted for the first year. It was expected that by the 1989-90 financial year it would go to $87m for a total over the three years of $193m of savings. I think we ought to get the facts right as to what the report says has been saved in this operation. The minority report refers to the savings-whether they want to stick to $87m or use the $36m figure-as modest. I would like to suggest that savings of that order per year-$87m-are not at all modest, and certainly not at all modest compared to the $1m or $2m-an amount of that order-that was the cost of the operation.

The suggestion is also made that this whole thing of changing the culture was something thought up after the event, that it was parenthetic. Paragraph 30 says that it was a canard perpetrated by the myth makers. But, as is generally agreed, the whole of the Block program was inspired by the Rayner operation in the United Kingdom and there are plenty of records of the fact that that report was about cultural change. It therefore has to be accepted that changing attitudes within departments was, to a large degree but not solely, what Block was all about. I do not think you can claim that because the success was not as great as had been promised therefore it means that the whole thing was a failure. You cannot say that. Nor can you say that there was not reference to cultural change at the time of the formation of the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit.

There are many other comments I could make on the political rhetoric, which saddened me, in the minority report but I will not take any more time now to do that. All I would say in conclusion, while carrying no particular brief for Mr Block, but in order to answer the criticisms made of him and of the unit in the operation by the Opposition, is that David Block is the same person whom the conservative colleagues of the Opposition parties are using in New South Wales in the form of the Greiner Government to do what I understand is something of a similar operation. If members of the Opposition are going to be critical of the operation here, they ought to be similarly critical of the operation in New South Wales.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fourth report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on Proposals for Variation to the Plan of Layout of the City of Canberra and its Environs, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Cooney, I present the fourth report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills concerning Audit Amendment Bill 1989; Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill 1988; Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) of 1989; Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1989; Taxation Laws Amendment (Employee Share Acquisition) Bill 1988; and Trade Practices (International Liner Cargo Shipping) Amendment Bill 1989. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 3 dated 12 April 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Clerk-Pursuant to the order of the Senate of 29 November 1988, a return is tabled containing details of all provisions of Acts which have come into effect on proclamation and which have not been proclaimed, together with a statement of reasons for their non-proclamation and the timetable for their operations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is the second of such information coming from executive departments to the Senate with regard to unproclaimed legislation. If one compares the return that has just been tabled with the previous one, one finds that we have not progressed much in the five months since last November when this exercise was last gone through. Indeed, on a rough calculation that I did in somewhat of a hurry, it seems that there were 61 pieces of legislation, parts or all of which were unproclaimed as of 24 November 1988. There are now 67. In the meantime, some action has taken place. Indeed, twelve items on the previous list have been discharged. Certainly, action has started to occur. We must be thankful for that. Unfortunately, another 18 were added to the list in the meantime. So we went somewhat backwards.

New admissions to this area of unproclaimed legislation are the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The worst, by far, is the Department of Transport and Communications, which had seven on the old list and has 12 on the new list. Indeed, of the 18 new additions, five came from one department-the Department of Transport and Communications. We have not progressed a great deal. However, I am heartened by the action that the Government has taken in this matter. I refer to the legislation circular No. 1 of this year, which is headed `New Procedures for Unproclaimed Legislation, Macklin Motion, Commencement Provisions and Explanatory Memorandum', which, amongst other things, points out what the Senate debated last year on my motion, what is now in place and some of the comments that various honourable senators made in this matter. Following from that, drafting instruction No. 2 of 1989 was issued from the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel. It makes very interesting reading. It is a short drafting instruction and it would be well worth while, I think, to incorporate this document in Hansard for the benefit of honourable senators in scrutinising the commencement date of legislation that they are dealing with in this chamber. I seek leave to have that drafting instruction incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
OFFICE OF PARLIAMENTARY COUNSEL
DRAFTING INSTRUCTION NO. 2 OF 1989
Commencement of Legislation by Proclamation
Last year, Senators expressed strong disapproval of the fact that many pieces of legislation had been unproclaimed, in some cases for many years (eg Hansard 24 November 2772ff.).

2. In response to this criticism, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (PM&C) has instructed that a new policy should be adopted when providing for commencement of Acts by Proclamation. PM&C has issued a Legislation Circular and new paragraphs to be inserted in the Legislation Handbook, copies of which are attached. I have discussed the matter with PM&C, and what follows is my understanding of the new policy.

3. As a general rule, a restriction should be placed on the time within which an Act should be proclaimed (for simplicity I refer only to an Act, but this includes a provision or provisions of an Act). The commencement clause should fix either a period, or a date, after Royal Assent, (I call the end of this period, or this date, as the case may be, the ``fixed time''). This is to be accompanied by either:
(a) a provision that the Act commences at the fixed time if it has not already commenced by Proclamation; or
(b) a provision that the Act shall be taken to be repealed at the fixed time if the Proclamation has not been made by that time.

4. Preferably, if a period after Royal Assent is chose, it should not be longer than 6 months. If it is longer, Departments should explain the reason for this in the Explanatory Memorandum. On the other hand, if the date option is chosen, PM&C do not wish at this stage to restrict the discretion of the instructing Department to choose the date.
5. It is to be noted that if the ``repeal'' option is followed, there is no limit on the time from Royal Assent to commencement, as long as the Proclamation is made by the fixed time.

6. Clauses providing for commencement by Proclamation, but without the restrictions mentioned above, should be used only in unusual circumstances, where the commencement depends on an event whose timing is uncertain (eg enactment of complementary State legislation).
7. In future therefore, commencement clauses providing for restricted Proclamation dates should be along the following lines, depending which options are chosen.
1. ``FORCED COMMENCEMENT''
A. Where only one day may be proclaimed
(X) Subject to subsection (Y), this Act commences on a day to be fixed by Proclamation.
AND EITHER
(Y) If this Act does not commence under subsection (X) before [specified day], it commences on that day.
OR

(Y) If this Act does not commence under subsection (X) within the period of [6 months] beginning on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent, it commences on the first day after the end of that period.
[Note: This form can be adapted for the commencement of a single provision, 2 or more provisions or `the remaining provisions'].
B. Where different days may be proclaimed
(X) Subject to subsection (Y), sections x, y, and z/the remaining provisions of this Act/commence on a day or days to be fixed by Proclamation.
AND EITHER
(Y) If a provision referred to in subsection (X) does not commence under that subsection before [specified day], it commences on that day.
OR

(Y) If a provision referred to in subsection (X) does not commence under that subsection within the period of [6 months] beginning on the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent, it commences on the first day after the end of that period.
2. ``FORCED REPEAL''
A. Where only one day may be proclaimed
(X) Subject to subsection (Y), this Act commences on a day to be fixed by Proclamation.
AND EITHER
(Y) If the commencement of this Act is not fixed by a Proclamation published in the Gazette before [specified day], this Act is repealed on that day.
OR

(Y) If the commencement of this Act is not fixed by a Proclamation published in the Gazette within the period of [6 months] beginning on the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent, this Act is repealed on the first day after the end of that period.
[Note: This form can be adapted for the commencement of a single provision, 2 or more provisions or `the remaining provisions'.]
B. Where different days may be proclaimed
(X) Subject to subsection (Y), sections x, y and z/the remaining provisions of this Act/commence on a day or days to be fixed by Proclamation.
AND EITHER
(Y) If the commencement of a provision referred to in subsection (X) is not fixed by a Proclamation published in the Gazette before [specified day], the provision is repealed on that day.
OR

(Y) If the commencement of a provision referred to in subsection (X) is not fixed by a Proclamation published in the Gazette within the period of [6 months] beginning on the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent, the provision is repealed on the first day after the end of that period.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The exercise that we are dealing with today, hopefully, over time, will become a very small rather than a large affair. I note for example the age of a very large number of the pieces of legislation on the return. The one that has probably the most outstanding pieces-that is, the Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Act 1980-is nine years old. I think we will get three more bits proclaimed on 1 May 1989. Unfortunately, there are still pieces not proclaimed. In fact, in the comments on section 45 (2), the Department that provided the reason says that it has absolutely no idea when these will be proclaimed. That should not be allowed to occur. If this is likely to go on, it will be well worthwhile for the Government simply to bring in a Bill to repeal all of these unproclaimed pieces and to start again. It is extraordinary that we managed to flush out of the relevant department the fact that one particular piece was non-proclaimed due to an oversight. It was nice of the Department to tell us.

SPEECH.PARA: But there are more important concerns thrown up by some of the explanations. Some of them are quite legitimate. But I do not want my comments to be taken as meaning that all of the delays are necessarily legitimate. For example, the ones in the Australian Capital Territory obviously will be proclaimed when-perhaps I should add `if'-the House of Assembly ever manages to get itself meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gets itself declared, first.

—Yes, gets itself declared and then manages to meet. Upon that day, of course, the relevant sections of those various Acts relating to the Australian Capital Territory will come into operation. That is a perfectly legitimate exercise and I think that everybody can see the reason for doing it in that particular way. However, I am certainly not happy with others.
