The Aboriginal Land Rights Legislation Amendment Act appeared on the old list as well as this one. It was debated quite extensively in this place. In fact, the reasons that are pointed out here for not proclaiming those pieces of legislation are the matter of contention in the debate, which I find absolutely extraordinary. The Government set about refuting it so that it could get the Bill passed and now presumably believes that it was correct in hindsight. I also have some worries with the crimes legislation. Since the last report, sections 11, 14, 16, 17, 18, 69b, and 70 to 75 have been proclaimed. That is very good. Section 47 is still outstanding. One hopes that the relationship between that and the Proceeds of Crime Act and the Cash Transaction Reports Act will be satisfactorily resolved.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for most of the new items appearing in the return is that regulations have not been drafted. We might be reasonable on this matter because we are dealing with the period from November to the present. For a significant portion of that time, departments were understaffed due to the taking of annual holidays and the statutory holidays that occur in that period. It is a legitimate point that can be raised-but only so far. It is being pressed beyond that limit with regard to a number of matters. One that I draw attention to is the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. If people remember the ones that we used to have, they will know that almost all of those were items either putting in commas or dots or non-controversial and small amendments.

Since any department had a small bit in those miscellaneous Bills, it is quite extraordinary that we should still have pieces lying around outstanding, particularly as, as I understand it, there is a lot of competition to get into those Bills. Finally, of course, they had to be killed off for the very reason that everybody thought it was a great place to pop something so that the Senate would not look at it. Of course, we have now moved to the new notion of having portfolio Bills. If they managed to get in, I would have thought that there would be a reason for it and that they may wish to proclaim those. I am still very much concerned that we have absolutely no idea when these Bills are likely to be proclaimed. I am not quite sure that one could describe the fact that we have no idea when they will be proclaimed as a reason for their non-proclamation. The Senate actually asked for reasons why they will not be proclaimed. It is not that we do not have any idea why or when they will not be proclaimed. Perhaps in future we may get some more adequate explanation.

I am also worried that the argument that we do not have regulations drafted has become the accepted reason why nothing has been done. Looking at the departments, I notice that there seems to have been an inter-departmental committee meeting on this matter to make sure that they all got their acts together and gave the same excuse. Quite frankly, I do not think that is going to wash. I would now expect the Senate, as I certainly intend to do with some of the Bills currently on the Notice Paper and which we will get to shortly, to seek to amend quite specifically the Bills with regard to their commencement dates, particularly two pieces of legislation which have completely ignored the drafting instruction from the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel. This was not meant as a frivolous exercise on my part and I am sure it was not on the part of other senators who have taken a long term interest in this matter, particularly Senator Puplick. This is an important exercise. It is one where the Parliament needs to be assured of what is going on. As we have said in a previous debate, it is one which allows certainty, particularly for the legal profession. I for one have absolutely no idea how even judges find out that some of these clauses have not been proclaimed. I can imagine all sorts of extremely odd things going on in courts all over Australia simply out of sheer ignorance with regard to some obscure part of one of these Acts having been forgotten by the relevant clerk and its not managing to be proclaimed.

I think the new drafting instruction is an excellent one. If followed, it will resolve most of the problems that have occurred to date. As I say, we intend to enforce that drafting instruction, and then at a later date it can be reviewed. If followed, it will certainly overcome almost all the problems we are currently facing in this little list and will not be adding, as this one did, another whole swag from time to time.

It is nice to know that some of the departments have got off the list. It is disappointing that a couple have actually managed to get themselves on. I hope the departments who are the worst offenders in this regard, particularly the Department of Transport and Communications-presumably because the Minister for Transport and Communications is no longer in this place-do not feel that they do not have to worry terribly much. I indicate to the people who have the responsibility in that Department that the Bills coming from the Department will be well and truly scrutinised and that there will be considerable problems with pieces of legislation if they cannot manage to get their act together and follow very simple, straightforward and, I think, excellent drafting instructions from the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of very brief comments on this paper on unproclaimed legislation. I do not want to detain the Senate for very long because I know that there is overwhelming public clamour for us to get back to the copyright legislation and, in particular, for us to pass the sections on imposing royalties on blank tapes, for which some people have been waiting for an extraordinary length of time. My first brief comment is that I share Senator Macklin's concerns about a number of these matters which have not been progressed since the last time we had a list. However, I am absolutely intrigued to look under the heading of the Naval Properties Transfer Act, which was passed in 1925, to see that it has not been proclaimed, and we are now told that the Act will be repealed as soon as possible. This is an absolutely extraordinary method of dealing with these things; that is to say, pass an Act, wait 64 years, and then repeal it prior to its proclamation. Whoever is responsible for having dreamed up this particular technique needs to be congratulated. It will undoubtedly set many a precedent.

SPEECH.PARA: Much the same can be said about the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act, which was passed in 1972 and is now not to be proclaimed because there will be self-government in the Australian Capital Territory in 1989. As to the question of establishing how many Acts have been passed and will not be proclaimed because some part of Australia is about to be hived off and turned into a separate State or given some new judicial status is a matter of real interest. Section 3 of the Koongarra Project Area Act 1981 still remains unproclaimed because, as the Government says, there is no advantage in proclaiming section 3 until the Government decides that mining can in fact proceed at Koongarra. In the light of the review which the Government is currently undertaking of its uranium policy, one waits with great interest to see a quiet midnight proclamation of part of the Koongarra Project Area Act so that the Government can get on with changing the policy, which it is undoubtedly about to do.

The only other one I would mention is subsection 14 (2) of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1985. If one reads carefully what the paper says, it in fact tells one that the reason this has not been proclaimed is that the industry does not like it. It says:

The area inquiry concept has been strongly opposed by the commercial broadcasting industry, which has sought clarification of the intended relationship between area inquiries and licence renewal inquiries which the ABT is already required to conduct.

It then goes on to say that the concept is now being considered in the context of a review of the powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure and a review of the structure of the Broadcasting Act 1942 by the Department. It is fascinating to know that the Department is in the process of reviewing the structure of the Broadcasting Act 1942 which, as I was told by a real expert today, along with the Income Tax Act and the Copyright Act, is about the most incoherent legislation that the Commonwealth has on its books. It does not say that the Department is actually considering any substantive amendments to the Broadcasting Act, simply the structure of the Act, whatever that may mean. We are told that all these reviews are expected to be completed in mid-1989. Whether that is actually a promise or a threat or simply a vain hope, one will wait to see.

We have been told that a subsection of an important Act, the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1985, has not been proclaimed. The Parliament decided that it wished to enact legislation dealing with the area inquiry concept because it thought, presumably, that it was a good thing at the time. The commercial industry does not like the concept which the Parliament has passed. As a result, the commercial industry has the capacity to lean on the Government to ensure that the section it does not like is not proclaimed. We were told the last time we had one of these reports before us that the reason that one Act had not been proclaimed was that the bureaucracy did not like it. Now we have established the principle that if the industry does not like it and has the capacity to muscle the Government, it also has a veto power. One expects to see in the next one that some piece of industrial legislation has not been proclaimed because the Australian Council of Trade Unions did not like it.

It is not up to those organisations to decide what pieces of legislation will be proclaimed once the Parliament has passed them. It is appalling to read that particular comment in relation to the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act. Nevertheless, I do congratulate whichever genius in the Attorney-General's Department has decided to repeal the Naval Properties Transfer Act 1925 prior to it actually being proclaimed 64 years later. There is a great deal more that could be said in relation to this particular paper, which repays some degree of study by other honourable senators. Therefore, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted: debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was dealing with this matter before lunch I had got up to clauses 9 and 10 of the Copyright Amendment Bill with regard to the relationship between the artistic and industrial design problems. I indicated at that point that we previously had some intention, in terms of our ongoing discussions, to look at what might be able to be done with those. At the end of the day, we decided not to push ahead in that area, for a number of reasons that I will go into in the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I foreshadow the following second reading amendment in respect of the Copyright Amendment Bill:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that, as a matter of urgency, the Attorney-General's Department should examine and report upon:
(a) the implications for industrial designs of the provisions of the Copyright Amendment Bill 1988;
(b) the desirability of protection for industrial designs and the form such protection should take under either the Designs Act or the Patents Act;
(c) the adequacy and appropriateness of the present design registration system and the need for changes under that system to complement changes made to the copyright law; and
(d) the need for, and form of, any transitional provisions in the designs system following changes to copyright law which affect industrial designs''.

I now turn to another topic-that is, performers' protection. Performers have been granted rights over the recording of live performances, either directly or off-air, and over certain uses of such recordings made without their consent. Before now, with one limited exception, performers have had no rights over recordings to which they have consented. Performances are defined as live performances given in Australia by one or more `qualified persons'-meaning Australian citizens and residents. These include dramatic works, musical works, literary works given by way of reading, recitation or delivery, circus or variety acts, and dances. Reading the news and performing a sporting activity are included among the exemptions. I am not quite sure whether unsporting activity is able to be covered.

Unauthorised uses give rise to a claim by the performer, who can bring an action in relation to them. The performer's consent is not required to make an exempt recording, although the recording ceases to be exempt if it is used for purposes other than those which are defined. There is also an ephemeral reproduction exemption in favour of broadcasters, whereby a recording or copy may be made if it is solely for the purpose of making a broadcast where the broadcast itself is authorised by the performer. Copies must be destroyed within 12 months.

These provisions reflect very clearly the recommendations of the majority of the Copyright Law Review Committee in its 1987 report and will certainly enable Australia to meet the minimum requirements of the Rome Convention for the protection of Performers, Producers of Phonograms and Broadcasting organisations. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has stated that it is the Government's intention to take steps towards accession to the Rome Convention in the near future. Various concerns have been raised with regard to this clause, probably the most significant of which is the retrospective effect of the clause. It goes back 20 years. The Government, by way of an amendment that it has circulated, will remove that effect.

Article 15 (b) of the Rome convention refers to `current events' rather than to the narrow term `news'. The Government argues that the change will create other inconsistencies in the legislation. Its backstop is that it is unnecessary because there is no evidence that `news' would be interpreted narrowly. I doubt very much whether there is an accepted definition that could be interpreted so narrowly, particularly because, in the industry itself, there is a very well-defined context for `news' and an equally well-defined context for `current affairs'. I indicate that we will support the Opposition's amendment in this regard.

The ephemeral recordings issue is interesting. I will raise some questions about it during the committee stage. There could be certain problems with regard to exemptions for public events. I hope the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) will be able to respond to my comments at the end of the second reading debate. I refer, for example, to application of authorisation requirements to parades or events which require audience participation-events such as the Gay Mardi Gras or, to use a more mainstream event, Carols by Candlelight. In any event, one can imagine that a very broad range of activities may be covered by this aspect. Many of the performances during, for example, Carols by Candlelight, if not during the other example that I gave, are often by notable artists. I think that this aspect should not be put aside. We should be clear about what is covered and how the broadcasting legislation is expected to deal with it.

I turn to the area of educational copying-one which is particularly difficult to deal with. Copying will be permitted provided that the institutions comply with a number of requirements, including payment of equitable remuneration to copyright owners. Alternatives are available as to how this is to be assessed. The provisions largely reflect the recommendations of the former Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, which were made about three years ago. There has been a significant amount of lobbying on this matter. In particular, the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee has raised a number of concerns. It would like to see the provisions extended to cover radio programs-which the Bill permits only by domestic users-and the copying of published audiovisual materials other than off-air. The off-air ones, of course, are catered for. It is also concerned about the need for fair dealing provisions in relation to audiovisual material, copying by libraries for users and for other libraries and copying for preservation.

The Opposition will move a number of amendments in this regard. Having regard to the spirit in which Senator Hill made his comments it may be better not to deliberate on this matter at this point, but I would certainly be interested in having discussions.

The external students problem is a difficult one. It probably ought to be resolved by the position adopted in the legislation rather than by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee's position. Essentially, the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee has raised the problem that external students are disadvantaged by way of distance in terms of getting hold of materials. I, for one, have always fought strong and hard on their behalf. However, they must be compensated for the disadvantage that they suffer. I think that can be accepted. We are interested in who is to compensate them. It does not seem to me to be fair to say that they should be compensated by the author. The author is in the business of trying to earn a living. Our poor writers have a bad enough time as it is, without their having to compensate external students. Many of them have great difficulty in compensating themselves, just in order to feed themselves.

I think the community has a reponsibility for external students and it ought to exercise that responsibility by way of government funding. In other words, the onus would have to lie with the Government to fund the institutions. The alternative argument, of course, relates to the fair dealings question. When we debate that aspect I wish to see whether it is possible to cover it within the scope of the legislation. There may need to be an amendment to the clause. I will seek to question Senator Hill about whether a `fair dealing' by external students may allow them to appoint a librarian to undertake a copy on their behalf. I think this is another avenue to pursue.

The legislation as it currently stands was the result of some fairly tortuous and protracted negotiations between a number of parties. It is useful that we have got rid of the extremely cumbersome reporting mechanisms that are in the current Act and which will not be contained in the new Act. The external students problem still needs to be addressed. I will be interested to hear how the Government views the problem of disadvantage faced by external students vis-a-vis internal students, and how it intends to deal with that matter before I make a final deliberation on that part of the legislation and the removal of the exemption clause.

The next aspect to which I refer relates to media monitors. The people who have been monitoring the electronic media have recognised that they have been operating in a no-man's land. No-one is quite certain whether he is permitted to do what he is doing. Then again, no-one is quite certain that he is not permitted to do it, either. It is an area which, one has to admit, is legitimate. I admit its legitimacy, particularly as the clipping services with regard to newspapers are accepted. Citizens have a right to know what has been said about them by way of radio or television broadcasts. If they were not listening to or watching the particular program they still have that right. This could be dealt with in a number of ways. For example, we could require an individual radio or television station to provide any member of the public who comes through the door with the ability to peruse the programs. That would be a massively expensive mechanism.

There is, in terms of the media monitors, a very easy and simple way of handling this problem. Media monitors already cover radio and television stations for clients. We propose to move an amendment in regard to this to enable that particular area to be clearly dealt with in such a way that the media monitors are able to provide to an individual a copy of the particular part of the tape or topic that that person is dealing with.

I will give a couple of examples to honourable senators who may not be familiar with the services that are currently provided. One example involves a teachers union in Queensland which is seeking to cover an interesting debate over class sizes. That is legitimate. No way in the world could the teachers union cover that. But since teachers invariably are included in the debates-they were the ones who were leading it and trying to get a reduction in class sizes-they feel the need to be able to respond to comments made by Ministers or other people on talk-back programs. They are attempting to engage in a debate in the society. This material has been broadcast to all and sundry. I find it very difficult to understand why a commercial operation cannot exist so that people can pick that up.

We should not operate on a wait and see mechanism, which I understand is what the Government is suggesting. That seems to me to be a silly exercise now that we are here, because our proposed amendments include a simple mechanism to deal with this matter. It can be reviewed at a later stage, but it should be put on a firm footing now. Some of the opposition to this comes from people who have made statements on radio or television which they do not want to fall into the hands of other people, having libelled or defamed them. That is an area which the two companies that currently operate do not wish to deal with. Very sensibly they do not want to draw on the wrath of the law. They just want to go about a legitimate business exercise, hence they try to stay away from defamation cases. I still believe that if those statements had been made on radio or television, it is the same as if they were printed in the newspaper. One has a legal right to take action if one feels one is defamed. I do not think this right should be obstructed by it being so difficult to get hold of the tape. On a number of occasions I have heard of, the tape has inadvertently been destroyed. I do not think that is a reasonable exercise for public broadcasters. If they are willing to broadcast material, they should be willing to re-broadcast it through that very simple mechanism.

With regard to the blank tape levy-and I understand all honourable senators managed to get themselves a tape today as a result of some lobbying on this matter-under the present law, home taping of published records and cassettes, either directly or off-air, is an infringement of copyright. That infringement is completely unenforceable. There is no way in the world that anybody in their right mind would try to enforce this law because the cost would be astronomical. Under the new proposals, copyright owners-that is composers, authors, publishers and record companies-will be compensated for this use by the payment of a royalty on blank tapes. This was a lateral thinking way of dealing with the problem. Unfortunately, we are still only dealing with radio cassettes and not other tapes. Considering the penetration of videos in the Australian community, which is the highest in the world-in fact, most homes would not do very much audio cassette taping, but almost every home would be recording television programs-it is interesting why we are going down one avenue and not down the other. Perhaps the Government can explain this. Perhaps we have not got around to admitting the level of penetration of video machines in this community. I would like to know why we are not dealing with that matter.

I also laud the Government for the exemptions it has made, for example, for schools and institutes for the blind, and so on. At long last the people who are drafting these pieces of legislation are taking notice of the interminable debates that we have in this place, that when legislation is drawn up somebody should always look over it to see whether these provisions can apply across the board to all Australians, particularly those Australians who suffer some disadvantage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on several aspects of the Copyright Amendment Bill 1988. As I said during an earlier debate today, this is one of the most complex pieces of legislation on the Commonwealth statute books. For example, page 36 of this Bill contains an amendment to insert a new clause which will glorify in the number of 135zzzb. The extent to which anybody can actually be expected to understand the complexity of legislation when it gets to that level is almost beyond me. There is some degree of confusion admitted by the lack of precision which we have seen in the drafting of this Bill. In the House of Representatives on the night of 24-25 November 1988 the Government, without debate, rammed through further amendments, including an amendment to insert a new section 248g (2) (c), which itself has become the object of considerable representations and on which the Government has started to back down. We propose further amendments which have been circulated today on this piece of legislation. It is an extraordinarily complicated and difficult piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague Senator Hill has already foreshadowed a large number of amendments which will be moved by the Opposition at the committee stage. I will draw attention to just one other and that will be to clauses 9 and 10 in terms of the interaction between the design and copyright initiatives. The long awaited reforms proposed by various craftspeople will be advanced by the Opposition. We will ensure that an amendment is moved so that questions of industrial design do not end up slipping between the provisions of the two Acts.

The Opposition supports the general thrust of this legislation. I draw attention to three items which were clearly spelled out in the coalition arts policy, for which I had responsibility. The policy was issued on 17 September 1988. The first is a commitment which the policy gave to supporting the levy on blank tapes. Our policy states:

The Coalition Parties support a number of recent initiatives taken in this area, including the introduction of royalty payments on blank tapes used for sound recording, and increased penalties for piracy.

Reference to that will be found in proposed clause 135zzj of the legislation. Secondly, in our policy we indicated that we would move to ensure that Australia became a signatory to the Rome convention. Our policy states:

Copyright protection will be extended to choreographic works recorded in the form of film. Steps will be taken to accede to the 1961 Rome Convention for the Protection of Performers, Producers of Phonograms and Broadcasting Organisations.

That will be found to have been picked up in part in proposed new section 248 of the legislation. Finally, we made reference to support for copyright registration and protection of dance works on video. We said in the policy:
Protection under copyright will be given for works of choreography recorded on film.

That is dealt with in the schedule of this Bill which amends the definition of the term `dramatic work' in section 10 (1) of the Act. That will be a great boon to choreographers. It will relieve them of the necessity to employ choreologists who are trained to record dance notation in the proper form in this very complicated area. This is something which is sadly lacking in terms of choreo- logical training in this country.

Copyright is an important economic area. For instance, the 1987 report of the Australian Copyright Council entitled Copyright: An Economic Perspective, draws attention to these matters. The Council draws the following conclusions from its study:

That copyright-based industries in Australia have grown at about twice the rate of the economy over the five years to 1985-86 (an annual rate of 6.1% . . .). The copyright-based industries represented almost $13 billion worth of production in 1985-86, of which over $7 billion, or 3.1% of the gross domestic product, represented value-added in the industries themselves. The industries provided employment for over 200,000 persons, which is 3% of the workforce.

One could go on at considerable length about the economic value of copyright-based industries in Australia. If one looks at a report entitled Economic Effects of Intellectual Property Right Infringement, produced in February 1988 by the United States International Trade Commission which was reprinted in the Journal of World Trade in 1988, one will find, for example, that losses through piracy and through theft of intellectual property in the United States of America was reported as follows: for the scientific and photographic industry, $5 billion; computers and computer software, $4.1 billion; electronics, $2.3 billion; motor vehicles and parts, $2.2 billion; entertainment, $2.1 billion; pharmaceuticals, $1.9 billion; chemicals, $1.3 billion; and petroleum refining and related products, including plastics, $1.3 billion. They happen to be real dollars, not the sort of Mickey Mouse dollars that this Government is inflicting on us at the moment. Losses in the entertainment industry in the vicinity of $2.1 billion are one of the areas which are picked up later in this report.

In making an analysis of the issues in this legislation, I want to start by referring to the levy on blank tapes. I am aware that the debate has to be adjourned shortly so that we can hear the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) make a formal apology on the part of the Government for its economic mismanagement. Part of the genesis of the royalty payments on blank tapes question was a speech given by Senator Evans, when he was still Attorney-General, to the Australian Communications Law Association in Sydney on 11 November 1983. On that occasion Senator Evans said:

While I have not yet made a final decision, I do see considerable attractions in the proposal for a royalty on blank audio tape as a trade-off for removing existing legal restrictions on non-commercial home taping.

I pay a great tribute to a large number of people who were involved at the time, particularly in the Australian Record Industry Association Ltd, whose then Executive Director, Victoria Rubensohn, was one of the principal proponents of this piece of legislation. She, of course, has gone on to do distinguished work on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Undoubtedly, both in her former capacity and in her present capacity, she has great interest in the way in which this matter has developed. In May 1988 the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, announced that the Government would proceed along the lines which are now enshrined in the Bill. He indicated in a press release:

The industry has agreed to set aside 15 per cent of revenue from the new royalty as partial funding for a non-profit Australian contemporary music development company which is being established by the Government to foster Australian music and young Australian musicians.

I will have something more to say about the Contemporary Music Development Centre, which is located at the Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education in Lismore, New South Wales, and the excellent work that has been undertaken there by Dr Clive Pasco and a number of others. Indeed, I will say something about the expansion of the Australian rock music industry, in terms of the Contemporary Music Development Centre, the Victorian Rock Foundation and the initiatives taken under the heading of export music Australia. It is often not realised what a significant economic contribution to our country is made by the popular recording industry in Australia. I want to deal with that at some length. I also want to deal with a number of other questions.

Perhaps I should simply foreshadow that in the remainder of my speech when the debate is resumed I will be dealing with the question of performers' rights and, in particular, the consequences of Australia's accession to the various parts of the Rome convention. I will also be dealing with the question of retrospectivity, the way in which representations from the Australian Record Industry Association, the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, the Advertising Federation of Australia Ltd and various others have impacted upon the Opposition, causing us to bring forward certain amendments which the Government has now picked up to ensure that there is not a retrospective application of these performers' rights in a way which would have been simply an administrative nightmare for the industry to put into place.

I will be dealing with a number of matters which go to questions of cultural policy and arts policy. It is very often not realised that a great underpinning of arts and cultural policy in Australia depends upon the legal regime which exists in order to secure copyright protection and intellectual property protection for performers. It is often not realised that the entertainment industry is precisely that-an industry. People who work in the industry, whether they work as performers or recording artists or whether they work in the various companies and associations which deal with arts and cultural matters, do in fact have an enormous economic stake in ensuring that the legislation under which they operate provides for security of their economic rights. In very large part, copyright is not just a matter of the protection of intellectual property but very much a matter of the protection of the economic rights of people who are affected.

As I said, the areas that I have already identified in relation to blank tape royalties, the provisions of the Rome convention and the protection of dance works on video tape are very welcome. I have indicated the extent to which the Opposition will be moving a number of amendments. Senator Hill has already dealt with those earlier this evening. I simply indicate, therefore, that at the committee stage we will be expecting a quite detailed reply from the Government on a number of matters. During the course of the next two weeks, we expect to undertake some negotiation with the Government to secure its agreement on as many of our amendments as possible. We will be seeking the active cooperation of the Australian Democrats in that regard.

This is an important piece of legislation and I hope that we will be able to sort out the differences which exist in a number of areas, primarily those concerned with the education area and the rights of people who are blind and handicapped. We look forward to progress being made over the course of the next two weeks. Mr President, in order to facilitate the Minister for Finance making a statement this evening, I now seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following Question Time today Senator Walters asked for clarification concerning the supply to senators of copies of the Treasurer's economic statement and related papers this evening. I asked my officers to pursue the matter with Treasury officers. I am now able to inform the Senate that the Treasury has been able to supply one additional copy of the economic statement and one additional copy of the related papers to each senator. A set of the documents will still be distributed to each senator in the chamber as advised earlier today. The additional copy will be delivered to senators' offices in the usual manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President,
Tonight the Treasurer is delivering in the House of Representatives the Government's Economic Statement for 1989.
It is my privilege to outline to the Senate the proposals of the Government.
Tonight the Australian Labor Party will fulfil the commitment it made in May last year to deliver substantial tax relief in 1989.
At that time the Treasurer said the country would be able to afford these tax cuts only if wage increases over the ensuing year were held in check.
The Australian workforce has kept to its side of that bargain.
Tonight we will keep to ours.
From 1 July all taxpayers will pay significantly less tax, particularly low and middle income earners.
This will be achieved while preserving the Budget surplus at this year's record level.
But tonight's Statement is about much more than just personal income tax cuts.
It also includes a wide range of measures to increase substantially assistance to families and pensioners.
There are all measures of great substance, carefully directed by the Government to those who deserve them most.
But even more than that, this package cements into place the central element of the Government's economic strategy for 1989-90 and beyond.
It secures the maintenance of sensible wage outcomes in the national interest.
We have sought and won agreement from the Australian Council of Trade Unions that the tax cuts will be accepted as part of next year's wages system.
This means that the tax cuts will take the place of what would otherwise have been very much higher wage cost increases, which would have threatened employment and thrown the economy into recession.
Instead, the tax cuts will play a central role in lowering inflation, enhancing competitiveness and supporting economic growth.
They will also underpin a far-reaching modernisation of the existing system of industrial awards, upgrading productivity and the quality of the working lives of all Australians.
Compare this situation with that of our predecessors.
In 1982 the then Treasurer-the now Leader of the Opposition-made irresponsible tax cuts which were not part of any sensible arrangement to moderate wage rises.
To the contrary, they were paid on top of a wage explosion which ushered in Australia's deepest recession since the 1930s.
He rejected the notion of an orderly and agreed basis for wages growth, preferring industrial confrontation to cooperation.
The dismal result was strikes and wages chaos which destroyed the economy, killing jobs and shutting down businesses all over the country.
Tonight's wage/tax package stands in stark contrast to that mayhem.
It is the very essence of reason and order.
Reason, in that the Government and the workforce can work out and cooperate in an arrangement that is vastly superior to the alternative of a wage explosion followed by a recession.
Order, in that only an orderly arrangement can secure improved living standards while maintaining business investment, growth and progress.
Mr President, this package could only be delivered by a Labor Government.
This Labor Government, through its Accord with the Australian workforce, is the only party which can deliver economic growth without crippling strikes, confrontation and unemployment.
In the last six years the Accord has delivered 1.3 million jobs, a phenomenal 20 per cent increase in employment.
And it did this with a sharp reduction in strikes.
By contrast, in the last six years of the Fraser Government job growth was a miserable 4 per cent, with three times as many strikes.
Indeed, in the last two years in which the present Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, served as Treasurer, unemployment doubled to 700,000.
That is why, Mr President, Labor not only claims a superior economic strategy and performance-it has proved it.
If we leave you with one single thought tonight it is this: If a Government cannot run wages in Australia it cannot run the Australian economy.
We have shown over six years that we can run a successful wages system.
In complete contrast, the Leader of the Opposition Mr Howard, as Treasurer in 1981 and 1982, comprehensively demonstrated that he could not manage wages policy.
He failed and his failure cost the nation dearly.
The tragedy with the Liberals is that in the seven years since, nothing has changed-they are no further advanced.
If they were in office today, they would have the same wages policy that destroyed the place seven years ago.
THE MEASURES
Mr President, I now turn to the details of the Government's tax and social justice statement, its wage/tax strategy.
At a total cost of $5.7 billion, it consists of tax cuts costing $4.9 billion and, at $710 million, the largest social security package in our history.

Overall, it provides big personal income tax cuts, significant increases in family allowances and pensioner benefits, increases in the Dependent Spouse and Sole Parent Rebates, and a radical restructuring of the Australian award wage system.
These combine to deliver a substantial rise in the disposable income of all Australians.
Families particularly will receive the extra support they deserve, and the least well paid members of the community will benefit from an historic lift in incomes.
Before detailing the changes, I will illustrate how the measures combine to apply in some representative examples.
The key here is to understand that a dollar in tax cuts is a dollar in the hand, whereas a dollar of wages is worth considerably less after tax.
In other words, the tax cuts are equivalent to larger wage rises.
The four examples I will provide are expressed in terms of their equivalent value as wages.

Take first a low income earner on about $290 a week or $15,000 a year, with a dependent spouse and two children, and qualifying for a $20 supplementary payment adjustment to his or her minimum award rate of pay.
On 1 July such a taxpayer will get the equivalent of a $24 a week pay rise from the tax cut and family assistance increases.
Subsequent award restructuring and supplementary wage payments will deliver an additional $40 a week, giving a total wage equivalent increase of $64 a week.
It is as though they received a $64 wage rise.
Second, in the case of a wage earner on $500 a week or $26,000 a year, with a dependent spouse and two children, the comparable wage increase is $71 a week.

Such a taxpayer will receive the equivalent of $41 a week from the tax cut and family assistance changes and $30 a week from award restructuring, giving a total wage equivalent increase of $71 a week.
Third, for a two income family with two children on a combined income of $860 per week or $45,000 a year, the increase is equivalent to a wage rise of $121 a week.

Such taxpayers will together receive the equivalent of $51 a week from the tax cut and family assistance changes and $70 a week from award restructuring-with one earner qualifying for a supplementary pay adjustment-giving a total combined wage equivalent increase of $121 a week.
And finally, for a single income earner with no dependants on $500 per week, or $26,000 a year, the total wage equivalent increase would be $56 a week.
Such a taxpayer will receive the equivalent of $26 a week from the tax cuts and $30 a week from award restructuring, giving a total wage equivalent increase of $56 a week.
Mr President, these increases fulfil the Government's commitment to lift real disposable incomes in 1989-90.
Had they all been paid in wages, such rises would have implied a 12 per cent increase in the national wage bill next financial year.
In fact, however, the actual cost of the overall package will be 6 1/2 per cent.
This reflects the efficiency of a `paid for' tax cut in providing a non-inflationary wage increase in place of a straight wage rise.
Putting it more starkly, the workforce will receive increases equivalent to 12 per cent roughly half the cost to employers and to inflation.
This result could only be delivered by a Labor Government through the processes of the Accord.
TAX SCALE AND FAMILY ASSISTANCE
Mr President, I will not detail the new tax scale and family assistance measures.
I have already illustrated the real benefit of these tax cuts to wage earners.

The tax cuts and family allowance increases are large in their own right-ranging from around $15 a week for a single taxpayer on average weekly earnings to $30 a week for a family taxpayer with the same income.

When this Government came to office in 1983, the lowest tax rate of all was 30 cents in the dollar; after that there was a hefty jump to 46 cents in the dollar; then another steep climb to 60 cents in the dollar.
Labor's new scale has a bottom rate of only 21 cents in the dollar, middle rates of 29 and 39 cents and, up to a $50,000 threshold, a new 47 cent rate.
Above income levels of $50,000 the rate will remain at 49 cents in the dollar until 1 January 1990, when it will come down to the new 47 cent rate.
Given the enormous progress we have already made in cutting the Liberal's punitive 60 cent rate, it is only fair that people earning more than $50,000 a year wait a little longer this time.
Mr President, we have also acted to reduce tax burdens significantly by increasing a range of tax rebates.
For single income couples with children, the Dependent Spouse Rebate is to be increased from $1,030 to $1,200.
For single income couples without children it will be increased from $830 to $1,000, while the sole parent rebate will be raised from $780 to $940.

To assist families we are raising family allowances to $9 a week for each of the first three children, and to $12 a week for the fourth and any additional children, while the family allowance supplement will be lifted by $3.10 a week for children aged between 13 and 15 years.
As a result we will achieve this year the child poverty benchmarks promised by the Prime Minister-well ahead of the 1990 target.

Moreover, in an historic step, all these rebates and family allowances will be indexed in future to annual movements in the CPI, to preserve their real value permanently-something which has never been done before.
Mr President, two further key points need to be made about this new tax structure.
The first is that it more than offsets what is known as fiscal drag or bracket creep.
In other words, personal income taxpayers will now be paying less tax than if we had indexed the tax scales for inflation since 1983.
Senator Chaney interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If you want figures, Senator Chaney, I suggest you get someone other than the person who prepared your last notional budget before the 1987 election which contained a $1.5 billion error in it.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point is that because of our past decisions, Commonwealth spending relative to the size of the economy will continue to fall in future years.
It has already fallen to its lowest level in 15 years.
In other words, we have provided real scope for further affordable tax cuts in the years ahead because the public sector will be so much smaller.
AGE PENSIONS
Mr President, I now outline the major reforms the Government is making in assistance to age pensioners.

First, the relationship between the age pension and tax systems is to be made more rational and less confusing. Many pensioners have said to us that it was unfair that they are allowed to earn up to an extra $40 a week without affecting their pension, but must pay tax if they earn more than $10 a week.
The Government has examined this and will remedy it.
Pensioner tax rebates are to be increased so that age pensioners with earnings within the income test free area of $40 for single pensioner, and $70 for married couples, will pay no tax at all.
When fully phased in by July 1990, this major reform will mean that 80 per cent of Australia's 1.8 million age and service pensioners will be exempt from tax.

For single pensioners, as a first step in 1989-90, the rebate will relieve $25 a week of non-pension income from tax, while in 1990-91 the rebate will be increased to a level which exempts $40 a week.
For married pensioners, the cost of achieving the same objective is smaller and the rebates will be raised in one step in 1989-90.
The second improvement concerns the timing of pension adjustments.
In 1986 pensioners were asked to share the burden of adjustment to the collapse in Australia's export prices by waiting six weeks for pension adjustments.
They have done their fair share.
The Government has decided not only to remove the six week delay, but also to bring forward the indexation of pensions by a further six weeks; a total bring-forward of 12 weeks.
This bring-forward will be implemented in equal instalments over three indexation adjustments beginning in 1989-90.
In other words, after June this year pensions will be indexed at five monthly intervals until the full 12 week bring-forward is in place in September 1990.
These new payment arrangements will apply to all pensioners and beneficiaries and will compensate for price rises much more rapidly.
In addition, Mr President, the 2 per cent discount imposed in 1986-87 for public service and defence force pensioners will be restored from November 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —At last. Caught you.
—You could not catch anything. You caught Ollie but that hardly counts.

SPEECH.PARA: WAGES POLICY
Mr President, I now describe in more detail how the changes fit into wages policy.

I can announce tonight that, on the basis of the tax cuts and assistance measures the Government will deliver from 1 July, the Australian Council of Trade Unions has agreed and accepts that average earnings growth in 1989-90 will be held to around 6 1/2 per cent.
In doing so, the ACTU also has agreed that there will be no claim for a CPI-based across-the-board wage increase in 1989-90.
Mr President, the new wages system will be determined by Justice Maddern and his colleagues on the Industrial Relations Commission in the current proceedings and the Wage Case scheduled for May.

We are envisaging the most far-reaching overhaul of industrial awards since Federation, and the Industrial Relations Commission has a vital role to play in establishing the new wage system and presiding over the orderly change to award structures.

Award restructuring will bring substantial benefits for all parties-for employers, a more flexible, productive and highly trained workforce; and for employees, more interesting, varied and better-paid jobs.
For very low-paid workers, the Commonwealth will support moderate supplementary payment adjustments, phased over two years, to lift their incomes to a reasonable living wage.
Only members of unions prepared to implement genuine award restructuring will be eligible for pay rises.
The tax cuts, by raising take-home pay from 1 July, will establish an environment in which comprehensive award restructuring negotiations can proceed.
We anticipate that wage increases from this process will be paid progressively in two stages, beginning later in 1989.
This new pay system brings about historic changes, including reforms called for by the business community over many years and now able to be implemented under the Accord.
It will make Australian industry much more productive, competitive and better placed to overcome our balance of payments problem.
The Commonwealth will back up the award restructuring process by allocating $12 million to fund its Workplace Reform Program.
The Minister for Employment, Education and Training is announcing tonight new programs to assist training in industry.
FISCAL POLICY
Mr President, like policy, budget policy will continue to be deployed fully to bear down on Australia's trade deficit.
Already I have said the 1989-90 Budget will retain a surplus at least equal to this year's forecast of $5.5 billion.
Furthermore, we will budget for an unprecedented fourth consecutive year of real declines in spending.
And we will again ensure the public sector borrowing requirement in Australia is no greater than zero.
Fiscal policy will therefore be kept as tight as a drum.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, observe the derisory cackles from the people who never, in all their years, brought in a Budget surplus.

SPEECH.PARA: To this end tonight's Statement includes a first instalment of savings measures for incorporation in the August Budget. These savings will more than offset the $71 million overall cost of the new policy measures I have announced to assist families and pensioners.
Savings on direct Commonwealth payments totalling about $360 million will be achieved principally from four areas.

There will be a further tightening of procedures to avoid social security abuse; the pharmaceutical benefits scheme will be restructured-I stress without affecting pensioners; a new pathology fee schedule will apply; and Defence spending will be maintained but without a real increase.
Payments to the States will be determined at the Premiers' Conference next month.
But savings against the forward estimates at least equal to the cuts in direct Commonwealth spending will be realised.
The States too must contribute to the national economic and wage strategy from which they materially benefit.
STRUCTURAL REFORMS
Mr President, I turn now to on-going reforms in key areas of the economy designed to remove supply bottlenecks and raise efficiency.
The new wages system opens the way for a dramatic lift in the productivity of Australian industry, as does the continuing boom in business investment.
But further progress in other areas is essential if we are to sustain rising living standards in the future.
Our determination to pursue changes was demonstrated by the structural adjustment measures the Treasurer announced last May.

It was demonstrated again earlier this week when the Government declared its intention to override restrictive State provisions in order to accelerate the essential deregulation of wheat transport and marketing.
This followed our decision to press ahead with the development of additional capacity at Sydney Airport.
In their own ways both these decisions will lift our competitiveness and improve our trading performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the waterfront?
—What about the wheat industry? You will get your chance to vote for efficiency but I will take an even money bet that you will cave in to the National Party of Australia, as you have always done.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister has already announced that Ministers will be outlining additional reform measures during May.
Important amongst these will be a statement by the Minister for Transport and Communications detailing fundamental changes to the operations of our ports and coastal shipping.
These are key areas where inefficiencies and bottlenecks have held back our trade effort for decades.
But the Commonwealth alone cannot do all that is needed.
Ports and railways are a State responsibility and we will be seeking from them a meaningful commitment to reform in these areas.
Mr President, this Government already has implemented many fundamental reforms to the tax system.
Tonight the Treasurer is releasing a comprehensive document which outlines how we will crack down on the use of overseas tax havens by Australian companies.
We have no intention of allowing unscrupulous operators to exploit ordinary taxpayers through sham companies established for the sole purpose of avoiding tax.
ECONOMIC CONTEXT
Mr President, I will conclude with some observations on the economic context of tonight's Statement.
The single most significant development in our economy in the past 12 months has been the huge surge in business investment.
This holds out the prospect of major benefits to Australia through increasing our capacity to produce exports and replace imports.
But the Government has not sought to disguise the fact that this investment phase has also led to substantial tensions in key areas of the economy.
With so much of the new equipment needed by business having to be imported, the balance of payments deficit has not narrowed as we expected.
And with demand running too strongly inflation has not fallen as we had hoped.
We have therefore seen interest rates in Australia rise to higher levels than any of us would like.
However, recent indicators have provided welcome signs that demand is returning to more sustainable rates of growth.
We are confident that this trend will continue as the past tightening of fiscal and monetary policy takes increasing effect.
This should be sufficient to slow demand and cut back the recent lift in imports and lower our current account deficit.
This Government is unequivocally committed to pursuing the strategy necessary to achieve a lasting turnaround in our current account and external debt imbalances.
As a nation we must never lose sight of the fact that both are unsustainably high.
For this reason I reaffirm that monetary policy will continue to play its vital balancing role in our overall economic strategy.
In all of this, tonight's wage/tax package is central.
It imposes a discipline on the key cost area of wages.
Without it Australia would simply return to the high cost recessionary days of the early 1980s.
We have acted decisively to prevent that dismal outcome.

We shall continue to pursue our economic strategy because it is the only strategy-I repeat the only strategy-capable of delivering lower inflation and a lower current account deficit in combination with sustained business activity and higher employment.

I table papers entitled as follows: Taxation of Foreign Source Income-An Information Paper-April 1989; Improving Australia's Training System; Towards a Fairer Australia-Social Justice Measures-Economic Statement, April 1989; and Award Restructuring-The Task Head.

That the Senate take note of the statement.
