PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Walsh) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address a few remarks on an issue on which I have been making adjournment speeches over the last few weeks. This evening I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate a death which occurred in custody in Western Australia in 1983. Peter Allan, who is also known as Peter Allan Jacobs, died on 25 February 1983, aged 26. He was a son of Allan Jacobs, a much respected elder of the Roebourne Aborigines. Peter Allan was imprisoned in Karratha in the north of Western Australia on 21 October 1982. He was sent to Fremantle gaol in mid-November and he was given a routine X-ray which suggested a lung disease. There appears to have been no appropriate diagnosis made at the time and Peter was imprisoned in close contact with others whom he could have infected.

SPEECH.PARA: In January 1983 Peter Allan was transferred to Canning Vale prison where another X-ray was taken which showed some residual lung thickening. Nonetheless, the prison authorities are reported as having said that he appeared well. On 4 February Peter Allan reported himself ill and he did not improve, but it was not until 12 days later that he was sent to the Fremantle Prison infirmary. During the next three or four days his sickness escalated at an alarming rate, and on 20 February the prison authorities at last noticed his deterioration. Peter Allan was found unconscious on 22 February and an X-ray taken the same day showed the possibility of broncho-pneumonia and tuberculosis. Even then, despite being unconscious all of this time, he was only transferred from the gaol to Fremantle Hospital on 23 February, by which time he was dying. Later the same day he was transferred to the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital in Perth.

From the research which has been carried out by staff in my office on these matters, I would say that despite the fact that Peter was unconscious and completely incapable of making any attempt to escape, he, like other prisoners that I have mentioned, was taken to hospital in chains and was kept chained to the hospital bed while he was dying. I find it hard to understand how the prison doctors responsible, when they have taken the Hippocratic oath, can come to terms with this sort of treatment of dying prisoners. Peter Allan Jacobs died that same day.

I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate some relevant points in this account. Peter Allan Jacobs was already suffering from a severe but almost certainly curable illness when he was admitted to the Fremantle Gaol just some three months earlier. X-rays had indicated a lung disease but nonetheless there was no appropriate diagnosis at that stage and he was imprisoned in close contact with others whom he could have infected. It appears that diagnosis and treatment of prisoners in the Western Australian prison system is inadequate and slipshod. Whatever crime the prisoners have committed they are nonetheless human beings and, as a matter of human rights, are entitled to a level of medical care not inferior to that available to members of the general community. And indeed, I would suggest that since much crime has health related causes, or at least has significant contributory factors, it is in the interests of the general community that prisoners' health be fully investigated and for treatment to be given to reduce the possibility of further offences after their release. With adequate early treatment of his tuberculosis, Peter Allan would have been unlikely to develop the deadly disease tubercular meningitis. This is another case of proper medical aid being given later rather than sooner and we have yet another young man who is dead.

When the Inquiry into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody comes to examine the circumstances of the death of Peter Allan Jacobs, it is to be hoped that the medical procedures at Fremantle Gaol will be closely scrutinised. This will be of assistance in the examination of the tragic circumstances of all the deaths which are occurring to both Aboriginal people and non-Aboriginal people in custody.

Likewise, I wish to place on the public record my bewilderment over a medical decision made concerning Malcolm Hatch, about whom I have spoken previously. Malcolm Hatch, as I said before, when he was very ill, had been provisionally diagnosed as having encephalitis. He was picked up from Cessnock Prison in an emergency vehicle which then proceeded to Cessnock Hospital to pick up another patient who was then taken to the Royal North Shore Hospital. It was only then that Malcolm Hatch was taken to the Long Bay Gaol infirmary. Questions need to be asked as to why, if it was an emergency case and an ambulance was required to move Malcolm Hatch, he was not taken directly to the Prince Henry Hospital, the best hospital in Sydney for neurological disorders. Instead, he was taken from one place to another before finally being taken to hospital.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee to Defend Black Rights has drawn my attention to several incidents which occurred in Murray Bridge in South Australia earlier this year. The incidents give me great cause for concern and indicate that the recommendations of the Muirhead Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody are not having the desired effect. In his report, Mr Justice Muirhead stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The material I have considered to date satisfies me that police lock-ups, and to a lesser extent our prisons, are being utilised too freely to cope with persons who can in no way be termed `criminals,' who are, to put it simply, grossly disadvantaged by reasons of fundamental underlying social causes and that in many cases custodial deaths arise from the same causes.

In 1987, the figure of 91 Aboriginal deaths in custody was twice the average annual number of deaths in custody between 1980 and 1986. The number of Aboriginal deaths by hanging increased from the 1980-86 average of 1.7 per annum to 15 in 1987-a nine-fold increase. The number of deaths reported as being due to natural causes doubled in 1987. In all, 92 Aboriginal people died in custody between 1980 and 1988, compared to 329 non-Aboriginal deaths in the same period. The figure has now climbed to over 100. While Aboriginals constitute only just over one-100th of the total Australian population they are, of course, as we all know, vastly over-represented in the number of people in prison and represent just over one-fifth of the total number of deaths in custody. Interestingly, the majority of Aboriginal deaths, or 60 per cent, occurred in police custody, while 68 per cent of non-Aboriginal deaths occurred in prison custody. Why is this? I believe it is incidents such as those which occurred at Murray Bridge in South Australia earlier this year that have given rise to and continue to give rise to black deaths in custody.

I want to read into the record some of the accounts of the appalling incidents which have occurred. The people who live in Murray Bridge belong to the Ngarinyeri people. They are a close-knit community and they are making serious attempts to overcome problems in the community. However, the attitude and the behaviour of some of the local police make this impossible. The first account is from Chirpy Campbell and is about an incident that occurred on about 7 February this year. It says:
2 Aboriginals were picked up this afternoon. One's name was Tooman Sumner, the other one was Michael Rigney.
Tooman was in the shop, i.e. the pub, in Murray Bridge and he was dragged out of the shop by police. Sydney Rankin was in the shop. They pushed Tooman to the ground and kicked him twice.

Les Sumner saw it and took the police officer's number. Johnny (Campbell) was standing on the street and saw what was happening. He rushed up and pushed the police officer to the side and said, `Hey, he's an old man'.

Tooman and Michael were taken to the police cells and locked up. I phoned there and asked Sgt King could I talk to them. See if they're all right and talk to them. Tooman takes fits and he needs his tablets. The police shouldn't have been put him in the cells. They should have handed over to the Nunga Farm. Tooman didn't have his tablets with him. They were back at the Nunga farm.

When I rang up and asked if I could talk to them, Sgt King said `out of all the Black people in Murray Bridge, you'd be the last one (I'd let see them). Not only would you sit down and talk to the prisoner, you'd also put in a formal complaint. Tooman was charged with `assault police' (and possibly other minor charges). He hasn't all his senses about him. He's a sick man. The charges should be dropped and the police should be dealt with for bashing Tooman and their treatment of Michael.

That was incident number one, on about 7 February. The second incident-it was quite a large incident-occurred on 21 February when a number of Aboriginal people were drinking at the pub and all hell broke loose. These are the words of a man called Allan Raja Sing:
There was about 15 of us all in 1 group, straight across the road from the police station. We'd just finished having a couple of charges there at the side of the pub.

About 6 police officers come across to where we was. 6 police officers come across the road and went straight for this bloke, Tony Rankin. They said-`Oh, you're under arrest', and they started harassing him . . .
They was grabbing him around. And about 6 of them jumped on him.

They handcuffed him and they was dragging him across the street. His trousers were falling down. And, ah, I think a couple of us mob, were trying to pull his trousers up. And, ah, got as far as, right in front of the police station.
His brother tried to keep on pulling up his trousers, tried to help his brother. And they got him! They put him down on the ground. Tried to stop him and that.
Both of them were still on the ground and I was just standing there.
Another copper come up and hit me in the chest with a baton. I just gave him 3 quick hits.
Just to break the quote: that is obviously not a proper thing to do but it does seem to be, at least, an immediate reaction to being hit in the chest. I continue with the quote:
And I just walked away and I don't know what happened from there.
And I was going around the corner. And I met up with these other people. Then everybody started to go their own way.
And me and this other bloke was walking home. And I think about 3 or 4 (coppers) grabbed him. And about 5 grabbed me.
They walked me back to the police station and they charged me with grievous bodily harm.
When they grabbed me was about half an hour after.
The bloke I was with, they locked him up and let him out a couple of hours after, I think.
Then they did not let me out till the next morning because I had a 1 day warrant out. So they let me out 9 a.m. the next morning.
That was one account of that particular incident, the arrest of Tony Rankin. Here is Tiny Rankin talking about the same incident:

Me and Raja and a couple of boys and my brother Tony (were) sitting at the Bridgeport . . . and then we started walking up towards the social security building in Murray Bridge. Straight across from the police station.

Then about 7 uniformed cops and 2 detectives from Murray Bridge here-Detective Jenkins and Detective King . . . The detectives was in front of the uniformed cops and they was approaching a group of Aboriginals . . .
They went up to my brother Tony and said to him that he was under arrest.
And he said `What am I arrested for' and he gave his name and address.
And the cops didn't say nothing and Tony walked away. See they gotta charge you with something, otherwise you got a right to walk away. And the cops grabbed him and they threw him to the ground.
Tony, by the way, is 18 years old. To continue:
Then they started kicking and punching into him. And then they started dragging him across the road. And this was about 7 o'clock during the afternoon and going towards the night.
They dragged him towards the police station across the road, from where we was sitting.
And I said, `What's my brother arrested for?' I said that to Detective Jenkins and he told me to go and get-
and the word is used. I continue:

And, ah, his other mate, Detective King . . . started kicking into Tony and dragging him along the ground. They was treating him like a dog, just kicking into him and dragging him by the handcuffs across the road.
And, ah, my brothers, Raja and Charlie, they said to Det. King, cause he was kicking into Tony, they said: `What's my brother getting arrested for?'

And as the cops was dragging Tony, I went to 1 of the uniformed cops that was dragging him and I said: `What's my brother arrested for' and I pushed the police aside, and, now, one of the other uniform police hit me across the side of the face with a baton. I got a black eye over it. Everyone can see it red and all that.
The next minute I know, I got handcuffs shoved on me and I was in the cells.
They chucked me in and then that same night, when they was going to give me police bail, they laid the charges on me. They were-hindering police, resist arrest and assault police.
Yesterday I went to court . . . and it got remanded till April some time. I've got witnesses that said I never assaulted police. Some white people from the shops saw it too.
The baton knocked me right out. Blackened me out for a minute or so and when I woke up they was dragging me across the road.
When I was in the cells, Detective King, he said: `You're a dead nigger or boong'. Can't remember if he said nigger or if it was boong. He pointed his finger like a gun at me and then he walked off.
I just laughed at them for talking shit. They gave me a dirty look and went away. I went to sleep after that and I got police bail at about 10 or 11 o'clock.
That was the second incident. Then there is this statement of Tony Rankin himself on his own arrest:

They came across the road, some detectives and uniformed police and they sang out to me, Ah, and I answered my name-Anthony Rankin and looked at them and they said, `Ah, Come with us'. And I said `What for? Am I under arrest?'. And they came straight across and just started to grab me. I put up a fight with them and ah, they grabbed me then, and ah, handcuffed me.

And while they was handcuffed me ah my pants fell down and that, and I was, ah, naked. And they did my hands behind my back handcuffed, picked me up off the ground and then dragged me along the ground in front of the police station. And then they carried me through the stairs and then they dragged me out the back. And whilst they was dragging me through the back, they was dropping me on my face, 'cause they had my arms up behind my back I couldn't protect my face. They dropped me on my face and that, kicked me down the stairs out the back towards the police, ah, cells and dropped me on my face and that, took me into a padded cell then.
And one police-Detective Jenkins, he then jumped and put his knee into the back of my neck, and they took the handcuffs off, before kicking me and that, a few times.
He said that they were threatening him and saying, `You're dead now', and that they had him naked. He continued:
They dragged me straight from across the road and took me into the police station . . .
My wrists were cut, I had cuts on my wrist, my left wrist was pretty deep and swollen. From the handcuffs.
That was the incident on 21 February. In another incident that happened exactly one week later, Johnny Campbell was concerned about his brother Wayne's arrest. This is what he says:

`Detective Jenkins' used to be stationed in Elizabeth (Adelaide area). He used to raid my younger brother's house all the time. When he was living in the Elizabeth area a few years ago. Used to raid his house all the time and do `drug searches'. One night the coppers planted gear in his house, videos, those sort of things. Set him up. Wayne beat most of the charges from this. On 28 February I heard my brother was arrested for no reason. Just after 11 at night I went to Murray Bridge police station. I confronted at least a dozen police officers that was stationed that night. Usually they'd only have about 3 or 4. That was a lot to be stationed that night.

I walked in there and I said: `Look, why was my brother arrested for?'. They just ignored me. They didn't even answer me. At the time I was really (angry) when I heard that he was arrested for no reason, but I just asked them in an ordinary way. But I was feeling really bad tempered, you might say. When they didn't answer my question, I sort of acted then a little bit more aggressive towards them. You know, when someone ignores you.

I raised my voice. I was asking why my brother was arrested, could I see him. Well then, they got a front counter sort of thing, and there's a side door where they take you to if you've been arrested. The side entrance at the front of the police station.

I was grabbed. My arm was placed at the back. I can't recall if the police officer said I was arrested. Then I was taken through, roughly. They rough handled me. They didn't give me any options. They took me to the back of the police cells where I was in a lot of pain on account of my back.

I walked in there (to the police station) with my crutches. The one that grabbed me sort of grabbed my crutches and threw them aside. I didn't resist. Cause if I had of resisted, I would of been in that much pain from my back. I knew it would hurt, that's why I didn't resist. I was screaming out in agony. The pain sort of got that worse, you know. Irritated my back through the way he arrested me . . .

I was taken to the back of the police station where the police cells are, and it's a fair distance, say about 20 yards from where I was arrested, to the back of the police cells. And at that time I was in a lot of pain.
I could of been pushed or I could of fell to the ground on the result of my back pains. Then I was assaulted. The copper that grabbed me was a sergeant. Sergeant King.

Well, I was kicked in the ribs. I don't know who `cause it happened that quick and there was that many police around me. About half a dozen. They was all around me. They kicked me at least about twice, and I was kicked in the forehead at least once. I was still in pain. I could still feel the pain that was going through my back. I was in that much pain that it was unbearable . . . I was treated like this before by police a lot of times. I'm sort of used to it.
They kicked me in my righthand side ribs.

Then they stripped me down to my jocks. They said `Oh, just in case you might hand yourself we're going to strip you down'. I was really (angry) when they said that. I knew they just intimidating me. I just left it. Well, I didn't resist or anything.
I was laying on the ground. I was dragged to a padded cell. About a couple of metres or something. Then they locked me in there.
And, ah, half an hour later I was banging on the door and it took them about a half an hour to respond. Ah now, a uniformed officer said, `Ah, what do you want?'.
I said, `I want to see a doctor, you know. About my back'. And I said-`Look I've got a bad back. I'm in a lot of pain'. And he just slammed the door. He never said nothing. He just slammed the door.

That was the second incident. The Committee to Defend Black Rights sent an observer for a march that was held on 15 March over black deaths in custody, and a person called Warren Martens made this comment about the march and the extraordinary overreaction by the local police to this particular incident:

At least 30 police (most of whom were from out of town) were there amongst the crowd. They were laughing at us. They had guns and batons and appeared to be from some special squad, perhaps tactical response police. Some were high up coppers-inspectors or sergeants. They were using two-way radio handsets. There were at least another 50 police in and around the police station. We stopped at the police station and courthouse and saw a big mob of police. You could see them in there through the glass. The station appeared to be locked. A police was taking photos of everyone. We started chanting `Stop Black deaths in custody', `Drop the charges', `Stop the bashings on Blacks'. Then 6 inspectors came out of the station and 2 Aboriginal liaison police came out. Then a whole lot of police came out-a lot of police were laughing at us.

While I was giving my speech, 2 police officers came from across the road into our rally and took this young Ngarrindjeri man into the police station. We felt it was like a payback for us having a rally. The way they arrested Tony Rankin only weeks before was part of what the Ngarrindjeri were upset about. It seemed the police were trying to say, `You can protest, but we'll keep arresting you. We're in control'. It was direct provocation.

It is clear that the recommendations of the interim report of the Muirhead Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody have made little impact at Murray Bridge. In particular, I draw attention to the following recommendations:
1. Governments which have not already done so should legislate to enforce the principle that imprisonment should be utilised only as a sanction of the last resort.
3. In jurisdictions where drunkenness has not been decriminalised, Governments should legislate to abolish the offence of public drunkenness.
8. Police officers should receive emphasis in training that arrests for minor offences must be avoided when alternative steps are available.

11. Where practicable, the Aboriginal Legal Service should be notified in all instances of the detention of any Aboriginal person in custody. Where it is not possible to contact an officer of that Service, such notification should be given to a person designated by the local Aboriginal community to receive such advice.

14. Police officers whose duties may require them to perform watch-house duties should undergo basic training in the recognition of symptoms of head injuries, major illnesses, and in first aid and resuscitation techniques.
They should certainly not be the ones causing them. Other recommendations are:
20. An Aboriginal detainee should be assisted to communicate with the Aboriginal Legal Service and should be entitled to private visits by a lawyer or field officer from that Service.
22. In consultation with Aboriginal communities and their organisations, cell visitor schemes should be introduced to service police lockups and watch-houses wherever practicable.

27. Appropriate screening procedures should be implemented to ensure that potential officers who will have contact with Aboriginal people in their duties are not recruited or retained by police and prison departments whilst holding racist views which cannot be eliminated by training or re-training programs.

32. All personnel of police, prison, social welfare or other departments whose work will bring them into contact with Aboriginal people should receive appropriate training or retraining to ensure that they have an understanding and appreciation of Aboriginal history, culture and social behaviour and the abilities to effectively communicate and work with Aboriginal people.

Mr Justice Muirhead's recommendations are excellent, and I am sure that those in the final report will be just as useful. However, I think we must go further to prevent Aboriginal deaths in custody, by ameliorating the social conditions which lead Aboriginal people to be overrepresented in gaols throughout the country. I believe we have to take sterner measures against those who perpetrate racism in this country and use the law and their own privileged position to do so illegally.

Accordingly, I believe that police officers King and Jenkins should be immediately suspended from their duties at Murray Bridge, charged with assault and tried before a court. Officers who replace them should be given full training in, and appreciation of, Aboriginal history, culture and social behaviour as recommended by Mr Justice Muirhead and should show a proven ability to communicate effectively and work with Aboriginal people.

Until such steps are taken, in many places throughout the country we cannot expect to see a decline in the disproportionate number of Aboriginal deaths in custody. It was a great disappointment to me and many Australians that the Government did not effect a land rights treaty in the Bicentenary of European settlement of this country. However, we are able to do something practical immediately as a result of Mr Justice Muirhead's inquiries. Such pockets of police brutality as I have described tonight should be shown to be completely unacceptable to all Australians, and those who are responsible for it should be charged, as an example to others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter of major concern to a very large section of the Australian business community. Australian stock markets are right now being misled in a major way by totally incorrect, misleading, interim company profit reports that do not reflect the real earnings performance of these companies-many of them major ones, many of them reporting `profits' involving multi-millions of dollars. I use the word `profits' because they are so-called profits. But the disastrous thing is that this is happening solely because this Government has changed, through one of its agencies, the interpretation of the word `profit' in one very serious particular. That serious particular is in the matter of unrealised foreign exchange profits or losses.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been only from the beginning of this year that this change has taken place. What is required under these changed accounting standards-details of which are revealed in the Accounting Standards Review Board's annual report for 1987-88, which I will deal with in a minute-is that these new accounting standards require companies to reveal what the unrealised profit or loss has been, on any changes in the value of the foreign exchange borrowings on their books or any foreign exchange loans on their books. In the past, variations in the value of loans have been written off or credited over a period of several years. This was in order to smooth out the impact of such changes in the value of such loans in foreign exchange terms because obviously, when the currency is a free currency with a market place, the value of that currency fluctuates severely.

This new accounting standard is an absolute farce. There are some major Australian companies that have reported interim profits of multi-millions of dollars. I am aware that in some of those companies a large proportion of the multi-million dollars of interim profits has not in fact been taken; they are simply in the books and, because the Australian dollar has subsequently fallen in the current half of the year, that declared interim profit will be wiped out in the second half of the year. It will be shown to have been a totally phoney profit. Having spoken to some of the companies and accountants involved, they say they are required to report in this way because of the new accounting standards. They are required to take in this bit of paper profit, which they have quite frankly, in some cases, no capacity to take in simply because the loan might be outstanding and might not be coming up during this period at all. The fact is these profits have not been taken; they are simply paper profits and they are required to report that they are `profits'.

Surely there is a way that these companies could say, `However, a large proportion of our profit is made up of unrealised profits and we cannot be confident that they will be maintained for the rest of the year'. Companies can do that. But there are many companies which prefer not to, for a whole lot of market reasons. There are many companies which quite like to see their profits boosted and their share price boosted as a result by this profit which, as I said, in so many instances will be shown to be a phoney profit.

One company, Santos Ltd, decided to deal with this matter in a very conservative and, on the face of it, incredibly honourable way. It declared that it certainly had, because it is required to by the Accounting Standards Review Board, a book profit of this order, but then in fact it wrote that profit off into a reserve. This was a reserve for future currency falls. I might say that that is all very well and the company clearly was trying to give a proper indication to its shareholders. But had in fact there been a temporary loss, it would have been required to report a loss and it could not have offset that loss by creating some sort of future reserve for future profits on currency accounts.

The fact is that this nonsense has been perpetrated because, according to the Accounting Standards Review Board, it is an international standard. That is sort of right but not quite right. It is true that, if Australian corporations want to borrow, for example, from the United States, they have to re-write their accounts to fit into this interpretation of profit. But in Canada, for example, the former Australian system operates. That is sensible, because, let us face it, Australia and Canada have a business community in which a massive proportion of their borrowings is coming from overseas; unlike in the United States where the net amount would be a tiny fraction of the borrowings that Australian corporations have.

This is a matter of major principle and I believe the Accounting Standards Review Board is not only to blame for this ludicrous situation, but it must revise its view or else bring in new arrangements which would correct the situation. I believe it should allow companies to go back to the old evening-out system but to oblige them to say in their notes to the accounts, `However, if the international accounting standard were applied the profit would have been $X in this situation'. But the Board has not done that. I think in the past the Accounting Standards Review Board has been a mite too academic and not quite had the sort of hard-nosed practical approach that it should have had.

I am much cheered up by the change in composition of that Board and I believe it now is at last starting to deal with the things that really matter. Certainly there is a list on page 16 of the latest annual report which deals with priorities in considering accounting standards. There I am glad to see that it is going to examine the separation of realised and unrealised gains in the profit and loss account, requiring in fact a clear distinction rather than this ludicrous situation that the present system has now imposed on the stock markets, with, as I said, this massively phoney number of interim profits.

The ludicrous thing is that, if a director takes the view that to include that profit would be massively misleading and that, therefore, he should not follow the standard, he can find himself hauled up before the National Companies and Securities Commission. The professional bodies will frown on the matter and he will have great difficulty with his auditors anyway. It does seem to me that something immediate has got to be done. But the Board has also done something, it seems to me, which is absolutely ludicrous about goodwill.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should watch Peter Couchman.

—Thank you, Senator. I will improve my thespian style. It also has introduced a ludicrous situation about goodwill which, quite frankly, I think is the worst decision it has made. Under the old system a company could write off goodwill, particularly on acquisition, over a period of 20 years or so; it could write it off against the reserves it had built up. That system applies in the United Kingdom, for example, where goodwill can be written off either against the company's reserves or against profit. The system in the United States of America means that it has to be written off over 40 years out of profits. The difference between writing it off out of profits and out of reserves is of major significance to what a company's accounts will look like.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now finding some ludicrous arrangements being made in terms of takeover in order to doctor the accounts, to make them look good in the face of what seems to me to be a stupid goodwill requirement, which I trust will be fixed up. Why are we regarding the United States system as the world standard when, as I say, in the United Kingdom for example, there is a choice? This has to be fixed up. It seems to me that there is a fair risk that some companies may well be paying dividends out of unearned profits, because of the previous matter I raised about including in profit unrealised profits. I do not think that is a healthy standard.

I conclude by making a couple of points about the Accounting Standards Review Board annual report. I have a great concern about this because for some years I was heavily involved in the annual report award, which judged the merit of annual reports by Australian corporations. In fact, I was a former chairman of that. While I welcome the attempt to improve accounting standards that is now being shown by the current membership of the Review Board, I simply say that it is lousy accounting. It is a very poor reporting standard for the annual report for the year to June 1988 to be presented to the Senate in April 1989, 10 months late. I think that is most unfortunate, particularly as the report was completed and sent to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities by 26 October last year. What have the Government and the Council been doing with this report? Can the custodians of good reporting in Australia please smarten themselves up? I ask the Minister at the table, the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), to use whatever endeavours he can to improve the standards of reporting, at least in terms of time. I commend the Board for getting its accounts in by October, particularly in view of the problems it faced with the most unfortunate death of a director of the Board, Mr Morley, and the difficulties that other members of the staff had in carrying on afterwards. I commend them for it, but I certainly do not commend the Government for bringing in this report so late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be very brief because we all want to watch the television response to the statement made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I will take on board Senator Michael Baume's comments and ensure that the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities is informed of the Senate's distress at the fact that the annual report of the Accounting Standards Review Board has been tabled so late. Whether it is accurate to call the Board a government agency, I think, is questionable. In so far as the strictures are well directed, I think they should be directed simply to the Board. As it is now composed in a way which is perhaps different from when the standards were devised, to which the honourable senator referred, perhaps it could review its position.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jenkins raised a matter relating to the death in custody of an Aboriginal in Western Australia. I believe that is more properly a matter for the Muirhead Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.

Senator Dunn raised some matters relating to alleged brutality to Aboriginal persons by police officers at Murray Bridge. If she forwards the material to me, as the Minister on duty, I will undertake to forward it to Commissioner Hunt of the South Australian police.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 8.35 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 1 June 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were local councils consulted, when new aviation regulations were imposed in 1985, and were any environmental impact studies carried out.
(2) Were these regulations referred to the then Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment for study under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposal) Act; if not, why not.

(3) Are there any controls on noise levels of propeller aircraft, helicopters and airships over the Sydney metropolitan area; if so, what are the maximum levels, at what hours do they apply, and how do these levels compare with allowable jet aircraft levels.
(4) Are propeller aircraft frequently directed to fly over Cremorne and Neutral Bay in Sydney, even late at night and very early in the morning.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 20 December 1984 an Aeronautical Information Circular was issued notifying changes to the airspace in the Sydney Control Zone. The changes became effective on 4 July 1985. This change in airspace was introduced in order to allow for the non-controlled operation of helicopters and float planes over certain areas of Sydney. While local Councils have been and continue to be consulted on issues associated with the Civil Aviation Regulations, they were not consulted in the development of this particular proposal. The then Department of Aviation assessed the environmental aspects of the proposal. The Department's assessment included the change in noise level, pollution, safety and the hours of operation on the routes.

(2) The proposal was not required to be referred to the then Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, as the assessment by the then Department of Aviation concluded that the proposal was not environmentally significant.

(3) The Air Navigation (Aircraft Noise) Regulations require that all aircraft made in, or imported into, Australia satisfy the appropriate requirements of the International Civil Aviation Organisation's Annex 16, Volume I, ``Aircraft Noise''. Apart from this requirement there are no specific rules or regulations that restrict aircraft noise emissions over the Sydney metropolitan area.

Civil Aviation Regulation 157 requires that an aircraft shall not fly over a city, town or populous area at a lower height than 1500 feet, or over any other area at a lower height than 500 feet, except in specified circumstances.

Environmental assessments of noise levels have been undertaken by the Civil Aviation Authority in relation to helicopters and airships. The Authority has indicated that if operated in accordance with their directions the degree of noise from helicopters and airships would not be comparable with the much louder noise levels of jet aircraft and, in general, would not have a significant impact on the environment.

The noise reduction strategy recently introduced at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport has considerably reduced the use of flight paths to the north, east and west of the airport between 11 pm and 6 am by all aircraft types. After 1 January 1990 the only propeller driven aircraft permitted to use the airport during these curfew hours will be those meeting new international noise certification standards.

(4) Pilots of propeller-driven aircraft may ask permission to fly over Cremorne and Neutral Bay. These requests are normally granted. There are also occasions when Air Traffic Control may direct an aircraft to fly over these areas. During the late night and early morning, care is taken to ensure that aircraft do not unnecessarily overfly Cremorne or Neutral Bay.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 20 December 1988:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Department of Aviation authorize flights of airships over the Sydney metropolitan area only in January 1987; if so, why was any airship permitted to fly over the metropolitan area of Sydney after that date.

(2) Are the Australian regulations related to airstrips used by airships merely copies of British air regulations; if so, are these regulations appropriate to Australian conditions, and what research has been carried out to validate this.

(3) Is it the case that airships are allowed to operate at an altitude of 1500 feet west of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, and at an altitude of 1000 feet to the east of the Bridge; if so, why does this altitude discrepancy exist.

(4) In view of the number of light aircraft and helicopter crashes in Australia in recent years, is the Minister fully satisfied with the safety aspect of the large number of aircraft, including helicopters and airships, operating over high density residential areas.

(5) Is the Minister convinced that any possible benefits derived from allowing this large number of aircraft to operate over high density residential areas of Sydney justify exposing thousands of residents to the risks involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Charter operations by the Bond airship were approved in January 1987. The authorisation was issued for the duration of the Air Operators' Certificate, which is still current.

(2) Yes. The landing area dimensions are surveyed in accordance with the British Civil Aviation Regulation Section Q. The dimensions were assessed by Australian specialists employed by the then Department of Aviation and were deemed suitable.

(3) No. All flights by the airships are restricted to above 1500 feet over populous areas. Special approval has very occasionally been granted to come down to 1000 feet over the Harbour, for example for the start of the Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race. Operations over water are less dangerous to public safety.
(4) Safety standards are set and monitored having regard to all the relevant factors, including different population densities. I am satisfied that an acceptable level of safety is being maintained.

(5) Aviation is an integral part of the Australian economy and transportation system and is of immense benefit to the nation. Safety standards are in place to ensure that any risk involved is kept to an acceptable minimum.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 1 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What percentage of Australia's total overseas aid budget is spent on child survival or primary health care
(2) What is the total value in dollars of this spending
(3) Will the Government give a commitment to maintain or increase spending on overseas primary health care

(4) Is the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau or any other Government Organisation or agency currently undertaking an equity impact study to gauge the effectiveness of our overseas aid spending
(5) What are the terms of reference of this study and when will it be completed
(6) When will the findings of this report be made public
(7) Which social indicators (such as female literacy, infant mortality rates) will be used in this study

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is not possible to give a precise figure for expenditure on child survival and primary health care within Australia's overseas aid program because:
(a) many projects in the health sector have a broad impact on communities and are not targeted at specific age groups
(b) the definitions of `child survival' and `primary health care' can vary according to whether, for example, water supply projects are included in primary health care

(c) several substantial items of broader aid programs ultimately benefit child (and general) health activities. This is particularly the case with budget support to Papua New Guinea, emergency food aid, and assistance through non-government organisations.

Bearing these qualifications in mind, bilateral aid specifically directed to the health sector in 1987/88 formed 1.1 per cent of the total overseas aid budget of $1,019.5 million for that year. In addition, aid contributions to multilateral and international agencies active in the health field accounted for a further 1.0 per cent of the above total (see part 2 for details).

It is likely that this total of 2.1 per cent significantly understates the ultimate benefit to the health sector from the totality of our overseas aid because of the health benefits of other programs. A study of this issue in 1986 by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) indicated that, on the basis used by other national aid agencies, about 4 per cent of Australia's bilateral and multilateral aid was spent directly in the health sector. If all forms of aid were analysed to determine their ultimate uses, this figure would be approximately 12 per cent.

(2) Total bilateral Official Development Assistance (ODA) expenditure on health in 1987/88 was approximately $11.3 million. In addition, ODA contributions to multilateral and international agencies active in the health sector included $3.1 million to UNICEF; $0.65 million to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities; $6.3 million to the World Health Organisation (of which the Department of Community Services and Health provided $4.8 million); and $0.9 million and $0.62 million to other international health and population programs respectively.

In addition, major portions of Australia's Budgetary Support to Papua New Guinea ($275 million), emergency food aid ($21.2 million) and aid to non-Government organisations ($8.0 million) would have been spent on health oriented programs, although exact figures on the health components are not available.

(3) In September 1987, the Government initiated a long term strategy for improving the visibility, focus and programming of health sector assistance in Australia's overseas aid program. The strategy reaffirms the need to give priority to assistance at the primary level, and recommends a theme of WATCH (Women and Their Children's Health). To provide additional support to the health strategy, the 1988/89 budget included $3.1 million for the first year of a four year package of health initiatives.

This four year package is estimated to cost approximately $20 million. Therefore, annual funding for health care is expected to increase beyond this year's allocation. The package will be directed towards countries of the South Pacific and South East Asia, as well as international agencies such as UNICEF and WHO. Priority is given to activities which support the WATCH theme, such as immunisation activities which promote improved primary health care systems, as well as integrated community-based primary health care projects.

(4) AIDAB is currently undertaking a review of the focus on poverty in the aid program. It will attempt to gauge how, and to what extent, aid expenditures directly impact on poverty. The review was announced publicly by the former Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden, at AIDAB's World Development Debate in Canberra on 27 July 1988.
(5) The terms of reference for the review are detailed below. It is expected that the study will be completed in May this year.
TERMS OF REFERENCE
Targeting Poverty in the Aid Program
1. Background

1.1 The objective of the aid program is to promote the economic and social advancement of the peoples of developing countries in response to Australia's humanitarian concerns, as well as Australia's foreign policy and commercial interests. There is a strong commitment to these humanitarian principles not only from the Minister and the Government, but the Australian aid constituency as well. One way in which the aid program attempts to meet these humanitarian concerns is through programs designed to alleviate poverty.

1.2 Poverty relief in the aid program was considered at the May meeting of the AIDAB Policy Committee. The Committee decided that an examination of the extent to which the Bureau's current approach helps alleviate poverty in developing countries would be timely. Accordingly the Committee approved a study of poverty alleviation in the aid program.
2. Objectives
2.1 To prepare a paper for the Bureau which
develops a workable definition of poverty,
examines how aid programs can contribute to the process of poverty alleviation in developing countries,
examines the ways and extent to which the Australian aid program contributes to poverty alleviation, and
suggests ways in which the aid program could increase its poverty focus.
3. Specific Issues
3.1 Poverty issues and aid

The paper will examine the ways in which aid donors can contribute to poverty alleviation in developing countries. As part of this examination a classification of poverty alleviation activities will be developed. The classification will encompass a range of aid mechanisms aimed at poverty relief, including those that provide, and improve access to, basic necessities to those that provide more permanent solutions.

The paper will recognize the capacity of aid activities that promote general economic growth to reduce the incidence of poverty. Indeed these activities can be an integral part of an aid recipient's poverty alleviation program. However the main focus will be on aid activities that deliver their benefits to the poor through reasonably direct mechanisms. Thus the paper will examine aid activities that:
provide immediate relief mainly through transfers: e.g. emergency food aid, disaster relief;
provide longer terms solutions:

by raising income gained from home production for consumption or sale: e.g. through land reform, infrastructure development, agricultural extension, agricultural research and other inputs that increase rural productivity;
by raising income gained from sale of labour through creating, and increasing access to, employment: e.g. cooperatives for craft production, rural labour intensive public works.

by raising imputed income gained from public services through the provision of, or increasing access to, public services; these services also have important secondary effects on other types of income manifested in areas such as increased crop production and labour income: e.g. primary health care, basis education, water supply, services in poor urban areas.
The limitations of an aid program in alleviating poverty will also be identified.
3.2 Australian aid
The paper will examine how the current Australian aid program helps alleviate poverty using the classification developed in 3.1. Areas of the program to be reviewed include:
in country programs
project aid: a comparison of different sectors
training
commodity aid
the small grants scheme
DIFF
in global programs
Emergencies
Relief and Refugees
Voluntary Agencies
IFIs
UN organizations
Academic Research.

The paper will discuss the relative effectiveness of AIDAB's various types of aid activities in alleviating poverty with particular emphasis on the relationship between the nature of the aid activity, the development environment in a particular country and effectiveness.
The paper will also examine the appropriateness of the balance in the aid program between the different kinds of aid activity which help to alleviate poverty.
3.3 Prospects in the Australian aid program
The paper will identify ways in which the aid program can further contribute to the alleviation of poverty in developing countries. In particular:
identifying existing activities within the aid program that could be supported further to increase its poverty focus, identifying new aid activities that could increase the poverty focus, and
outlining the next steps that could be taken in each case such as:
increasing resources to particular program elements,
comparative assessment of agencies targeted for greater resource allocation,
regional initiatives,
sectoral reviews, and
packaging of a poverty initiative in the aid program.
4. OUTPUT
4.1 An initial working paper of 10 to 15 pages in length to be circulated for comment followed by a final paper suitable for publication.
(6) The findings of the review will be made public when it is completed.

(7) This review of the poverty focus of the aid program is a policy paper. As such it aims to identify, in a broad context, those aid expenditures that directly assist the poor. It will not involve the collection of data on poverty in specific countries and so does not focus on particular indicators of poverty. AIDAB uses the range of social and economic indicators that are available for particular countries for country programming considerations. Such measures are likely to be more relevant to designing activities that may stem from the poverty review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 9 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the individual items included in the amount of $102,570 expended to 30 June 1988 on the establishment of the Horticultural Policy Council, and referred to on the last page of the Council's Annual Report for 1987, and what were the amounts expended under each item.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The expenditure was incurred by the Department over the period since April 1986 when the Government announced that $10 million had been provided to fund a number of measures to assist the horticultural industries. The amount of $102,312 represents salaries of $76,000 (the equivalent of approximately one staff year over the period) and administrative support services of $26,312 (eg travel, telephone, postage, printing, computing facilities) for officers involved in the development and establishment of the Horticultural Policy Council. The balance of $257 represents the cost of travel undertaken by the Chairman of the Policy Council.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 9 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many women are in the Army Reserve, nationally and per state, over a 5 year period, and what percentage of the total Reserve body do women represent.
(2) What numbers of occupations are open to women reservists in each state and what are they.
(3) Is there a ceiling on the number of women who can serve in the Reserve at any one time, and what is the ceiling.
(4) How many applications are made by women per state to join the Reserves and how many are unsuccessful on the basis of a lack of available spaces.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Table 1 shows the number and percentages of women in the Army Reserve, by Military District, for the financial years 1984-85 to 1987-88 and year to date 1988-89.

(2) The occupations open to women in the Army Reserve are the same as those open to women in the Regular Army. In addition women may be employed in field force units, in the Army Reserve, whereas they are excluded from such units in the Regular Army. Occupations open to women are:

The occupations that are open to women are currently under review, with a view to increasing the employment opportunities for women.

It is not possible to state the numbers of each occupation that are open in each state. Unit commanders are given maximum flexibility in deciding whether positions will be filled by women, within the guidelines of the trades that are open and a requirement that women do not exceed 10% of the unit's authorised manning level.

(3) There is a ceiling on the number of women that can serve in the Army Reserve at one time. That ceiling is 10% of the authorised manning level, which at present stands at 28 000. This ceiling was introduced to enhance the opportunities for women to serve in the Army Reserve. Army Reserve units are geographically based and Reserve soldiers are necessarily drawn from the local community. To apply the same employment criteria to the Reserve which apply to the Regular Army would have denied many women entry to their local unit because most units have a combat or combat related role. However, to ensure that Reserve units were able to sustain operational capabilities, a numerical limit was applied to women serving in the Reserve. As can be seen from the figures in the table, the ceiling is currently being exceeded. The ceiling will be included in the overall review mentioned above.

(4) Detailed statistics on the number of women per state, who apply to join the Army Reserve or who are rejected because there is no vacancy, are not available, due to practical difficulties in aggregating unit statistics at regional level. However more suitable females enquire about Army Reserve service than can be placed in current unit vacancies. If there are no female vacancies at the time of an enquiry, the applicant is placed on a waiting list. An application is then completed when a vacancy becomes available.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday 21 December 1988 (Hansard Page 4765), Senator Reid asked me a question without notice concerning the relationship between SkillShare and the community youth support scheme and, in particular, whether organisations seeking funding under SkillShare are required to enter into joint ventures with community youth support schemes in order to qualify for funding. The Minister for Employment and Education Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: There was no formal requirement within the SkillShare guidelines for potential sponsors to enter into joint ventures with former CYSS Local Management Committees (LMCs) in order to qualify for funding. However, to maximise effective use of funds, a number of amalgamations between MLCs/sponsors of projects funded under the previous programs were encouraged.
